componenttext: Just on the regional jet kind of strategy here, I wonder if you could just elaborate a little bit more about -- I know that the E175 success you've had, but I think the Q400 also kind of served the purpose along the West Coast and maybe even in Alaska. Just wondering what the thinking behind taking down that fleet was? And if you don't get the pilot deal, would you kind of reverse that thinking or -- pilot and flight attendant deal? Or would you kind of go forward with it just maybe with a third-party carrier?

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Savi, it's Brandon. Maybe I'll start and Andrew can jump in. As we think about the regional jets, the opportunity here is as follows: one is they have increased reach versus the Q400 delivers a better passenger experience, especially on those longer-stage
componenttext: Savi, it's Brandon. Maybe I'll start and Andrew can jump in. As we think about the regional jets, the opportunity here is as follows: one is they have increased reach versus the Q400 delivers a better passenger experience, especially on those longer-stage length mission than the Q400. Our competition, frankly, is using those in many of our markets. And I think we want to make sure that we're staying on par or better with that customer experience side. We have a much higher revenue opportunity with a 3-class cabin and actually in excess of 400 miles, the regional jet has a lower trip cost. The Q400 has been a great airplane for us, and it works well in the short-stage length around the Pacific Northwest, but I think there's an opportunity to tap into lots of new revenue opportunities with the regional jets by bringing some of those in-house.

componenttext: Just a question on competitive capacity. It seems like it continues to grow as we look at the next couple of quarters. Can you just talk about why that is? And just in particular, it seems like there's gate constraints at the Seattle Airport, which would tell us that there shouldn't be growth. But it seems like there is. I just like to understand that dynamic. Is that better, if that makes sense?

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rajeev, it's Andrew. Yes, as we've shared competitive capacity is up 13% for the next few quarters. A lot of this is annualization of competitive capacity that was already announced in 2015 and started in 2015. As we've been talking, this is something tha
componenttext: Rajeev, it's Andrew. Yes, as we've shared competitive capacity is up 13% for the next few quarters. A lot of this is annualization of competitive capacity that was already announced in 2015 and started in 2015. As we've been talking, this is something that we spend a lot of time preparing for and equipping ourselves for with our low-cost strong customer base. So we are very much have this in our sides. As it relates to Sea-Tac, I think it's one -- you're right, it's getting a little fuller certainly at the peak times. And it's one, if you want to fly at certain peak times, there's trade-offs to be made. In some of the low period, there's still space. But overall, we think that we still have a lot of good opportunity at Sea-Tac as we continue to grow our network and mature in new markets.

componenttext: No. There is some new -- you'll be obviously aware of the major reasons of the growth. headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Andrew, I appreciate the reiteration of the capacity guidance for '16. But thinking about how 2015 trended, and I think you ended up about 250 bps higher than your original guidance. Q1 is about 50 bps than where you were in October. How are you thinking
componenttext: Andrew, I appreciate the reiteration of the capacity guidance for '16. But thinking about how 2015 trended, and I think you ended up about 250 bps higher than your original guidance. Q1 is about 50 bps than where you were in October. How are you thinking about incremental capacity growth in '16 with crude sub 30 and competitors continuing to aggressively enter Alaska markets?

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Julia. It's a good question, and you're always going to be held accountable for my 8% guidance growing pre ledge. That's actually why I've reiterated it. I think what I would share with you is in 2015, and I think we've sort of been transparent he
componenttext: Thanks, Julia. It's a good question, and you're always going to be held accountable for my 8% guidance growing pre ledge. That's actually why I've reiterated it. I think what I would share with you is in 2015, and I think we've sort of been transparent here, is that a part of that was bringing forward some of the growth to continue to grow Seattle at a higher rate than we initially planned to do. But as we move into 2016, and yes, we're a little higher in the first quarter, we're getting a lot of deliveries this year. We're getting 19 ERs. They're heavily loaded to the front end, and we don't stop pushing out our 400s to the middle of the year, and there's 13 of those. So we're a little higher in the first half of the year than we'd like to. But as we move into the back part of the year, I think we're going to be around 5% or so. And the other thing is we have a lot of mod lines going now putting ATG4, WiFi own as well as mods for premium economy. So we're going to be using a lot of those aircraft to get all that done by the end of the year. So I feel fairly confident about where we sit today with our capacity guidance.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Is there flexibility to delay the retirements on the -400s or even accelerate deliveries if you wanted to? Or is there room still on utilization if you wanted to push your growth above 8%?
componenttext: Is there flexibility to delay the retirements on the -400s or even accelerate deliveries if you wanted to? Or is there room still on utilization if you wanted to push your growth above 8%?

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The Chief Operating Officer is looking at me right now, and if I was to extend the 400s, I might lose some body parts. So the reality is the 400s are going. We really need those to leave because of training and all sorts of other things. New deliveries ar
componenttext: The Chief Operating Officer is looking at me right now, and if I was to extend the 400s, I might lose some body parts. So the reality is the 400s are going. We really need those to leave because of training and all sorts of other things. New deliveries are all fixed. I think the opportunity for us is if we wanted to grow more, we certainly have utilization play. And certainly, if we want to reduce capacity, we can do that by getting things through the mod lines. At the end of the day, we're going to do what's best for Air Group, and we do have that flexibility.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Julia, this is Brad. I might just sort of add on it. If the calculus is sort of risk return, it's -- and as you guys have seen, we have had tremendous success putting this new capacity to markets. The returns have been there. Most of the markets we added
componenttext: Julia, this is Brad. I might just sort of add on it. If the calculus is sort of risk return, it's -- and as you guys have seen, we have had tremendous success putting this new capacity to markets. The returns have been there. Most of the markets we added in 2015 were profitable in the first 3 months. But there's risk to growing at a higher level over a sustained period of time, there's risk. And so we're sitting here trying to balance our presence in Seattle, which is an incredible economic engine for the company, taking advantage of market opportunities while sort of measuring risks. So I think today, we want to reiterate that our long-term mindset is 4% to 8% growth. When we see more opportunities, we'll be at the higher end of that, but that is our mindset and that's what we want you to know.

componenttext: Brandon, you sound very fired up and passionate in your prepared remarks, like more than usual. I'm wondering if that's sort of because you're displeased with the stock performance this year. And the question that I have is how do you think about the buyback? One of the things you guys have done better in the last couple of years has been a little more opportunistic about the timing of when you buy in pullbacks. But do you think about ramping it up significantly when it pulls back like this, unless you're not blacked out tomorrow, not just because you get a chance to buy it cheaper or because you get a chance to sort of send the message that if this happens again and if your stock goes down like it's gone down as much as it has lately, that you'll be there to take advantage of it this quarter. Did you think about that?

componenttext: Hunter, it's Mark Eliasen. We are opportunistic, and we also are also programmatic with our stock buyback. We do buy more shares when it's down and specific actions we might take, but we are aware of where the stock is trading, and we do aggressively buy the stock.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Cool. And then, Andrew, one of the big topics of sort of over the last 6 to 9 months has been this concept of customer segmentation. And it's really been something that's been talked about in the context of the legacy guys competing against ULCCs, a
componenttext: Okay. Cool. And then, Andrew, one of the big topics of sort of over the last 6 to 9 months has been this concept of customer segmentation. And it's really been something that's been talked about in the context of the legacy guys competing against ULCCs, as the goal is to sort of prevent business travelers from buying fares that are designed to sell to leisure travelers. You guys highlighted today that you have about 1/3 of your passengers coming from business travel. So is there a level of self-cannibalization that you're not happy about right now as it relates to sort of how you manage that? And if so, are there any sort of IT-based projects underway -- IT-based projects I'm saying not seat reconfiguration, underway to sort of address it, particularly as you see ULCC growth ramping in markets?

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hunter, I think I'm going to have Shane Tackett, VP of RM, answer that question. She's been spending a lot of time on that subject.
componenttext: Hunter, I think I'm going to have Shane Tackett, VP of RM, answer that question. She's been spending a lot of time on that subject.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Hunter, I hope I answer the right question. We've been in a unique position, maybe not strategically but we have, nonetheless, to be able to watch how other legacy carriers have handled sort of the segmentation at the lower end of the demand curve. An
componenttext: And Hunter, I hope I answer the right question. We've been in a unique position, maybe not strategically but we have, nonetheless, to be able to watch how other legacy carriers have handled sort of the segmentation at the lower end of the demand curve. And we've been sort of interested to see how they -- that has played out, how they developed the different fare products and whether or not we think that we actually need to develop something like that on our own. If we did, I feel like we needed to access that part of the demand curve, we could. There's not a lot of IT hurdle in the way we can develop a product and get it to market pretty quickly. Our sort of history with this, albeit small, certainly out of Portland, where we face ULCC competition, is we haven't felt the need to use those types of products. We think our customers not only appreciate the superior products we have, but recognize we have already very low fares. And so our differences in fare price for that kind of leisure-focused traveler that ULCCs are going after is much closer than maybe some of the other carriers have had to experience in their market. So thus far, we haven't had to do it but we could if we need to.

componenttext: I can't say a whole lot except to say that I read the press like you do. And it's very clear to me that what American is doing is continuing to fortify their position in Los Angeles. I think Seattle is probably in the top 10 largest O&Ds on the planet. And they've decided to serve that with their own model. And again, we have code on each other and we are looking at that. But at the end of the day, they're doing what I see is in their best interests.

componenttextpreview: I think, Andrew, you're saying this. But it might -- we actually need to think about this more ourselves, but I think what could be happening here is this is more about L.A. than Seattle. And there's a couple of airlines that are going to be fighting for
componenttext: I think, Andrew, you're saying this. But it might -- we actually need to think about this more ourselves, but I think what could be happening here is this is more about L.A. than Seattle. And there's a couple of airlines that are going to be fighting for dominance in LAX with the consolidation that's happening in the industry and what's happening with L.A. facilities, and that actually maybe the story here.

componenttext: Helane, it's Brandon. Actually we've thought about it, but right now, we're moving forward with a 76-seat regional jet at Horizon, and we're also comfortable with 737s at Alaska. We love the simplicity of that. We recognize there might be a hole in the market, but we're not doing anything at this point to suggest that we would move forward with a 100-seat type aircraft.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Jamie Baker with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Jamie Baker with JPMorgan.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have 2 questions. When we think about the RASM declines at Alaska, they are comparatively unique to those at the industry in that they're mostly representative of the increased competition as opposed to the elimination of fuel surcharges, a strong dolla
componenttext: I have 2 questions. When we think about the RASM declines at Alaska, they are comparatively unique to those at the industry in that they're mostly representative of the increased competition as opposed to the elimination of fuel surcharges, a strong dollar, a crappy Brazil and so forth. Fuel is obviously a blessing for you here. But if and when fuel escalates, your competitors are actually going to be picking up RASM along the way that you won't save maybe for budgets improving in the State of Alaska. So I'm just wondering if you're content with what appears to be a virtual guarantee of significant margin compression if fuel begins to escalate? And if you're not, does that alter your view on the optimal network contract and/or your opinion on consolidation?

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jamie, it's Brandon. That's a super complicated question. We're not that smart out here in the Pacific Northwest. But I guess what I would say is -- and I addressed it a little bit in my prepared remarks, which is we don't have a belief that fuel is going
componenttext: Jamie, it's Brandon. That's a super complicated question. We're not that smart out here in the Pacific Northwest. But I guess what I would say is -- and I addressed it a little bit in my prepared remarks, which is we don't have a belief that fuel is going to be $28 a barrel WTI forever. And what I would say is that no public company can report record earnings quarter after quarter after quarter. And the other thing I would say is that we're generating really, really, really outstanding returns right now. If fuel goes up, I think it is possible that you could see margins come down. In terms of the broader strategy, what we're -- goes back to something maybe that Brad said, which is we're going to do the right thing for Alaska. We do have a profit hurdle internally. Most of our markets are well above that. Most of our markets would be well above that at $3 a fuel. And so we're going to continue to -- we are very satisfied with the network, and we're going to continue to do what's right. If fuel prices go up, we may adjust capacity. But again, we have a view on what our networks should look like because we have internal profit targets that those -- our routes need to meet.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was going to add. Yes, I think the industry today is different than where it was 6 or 8 or 10 years ago. These are lines that are run by business people. People want to have earnings. They want to have returns on capital. I think if fuel prices go up as
componenttext: I was going to add. Yes, I think the industry today is different than where it was 6 or 8 or 10 years ago. These are lines that are run by business people. People want to have earnings. They want to have returns on capital. I think if fuel prices go up as they did 4, 5 years ago, I think you will see people adjust capacity throughout the industry, and that makes us optimistic. And again, I think our -- to get to your point about margin compression. Alaska's financial performance comes from our competitive advantage. It doesn't come from international exchange rate or Brazilian currency. It comes from us having a cost structure that's 36% lower than the other guys when you factor in fuel and interest costs. It comes from the fact that customers prefer to fly with us. We have incredible loyalty in Seattle. It comes from a very strong balance sheet, the right fleet. So I sort of think whatever, the world's going to move. What we get thrown our way is going to change from time to time. But I personally think this company has pretty strong competitive advantage. It's going to serve us well no matter what environment we're competing in.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Those are all helpful observations. Second question, if you did want to lock in the forward curve or something shaped similar to where the forward curve is today, say for the next 12 months, what sort of premium do you think you would have to pay? In othe
componenttext: Those are all helpful observations. Second question, if you did want to lock in the forward curve or something shaped similar to where the forward curve is today, say for the next 12 months, what sort of premium do you think you would have to pay? In other words, how much would oil have to move against you before a big hedging that became profitable?

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jamie, this is Mark. First of all, I don't think you'd see us taking a big hedging bet. We like the way we're working right now. The forward curve is nice and low. It's something like $50 a barrel or below that looking out for a long time. So we could do
componenttext: Jamie, this is Mark. First of all, I don't think you'd see us taking a big hedging bet. We like the way we're working right now. The forward curve is nice and low. It's something like $50 a barrel or below that looking out for a long time. So we could do something like that, but we kind of like our program the way it's working right now.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I wasn't suggesting that you should or you need to. I'm just kind of -- I'm just trying to gather some information on where hedge premiums might be right now. Because it feels like if you did or if anybody did, it would be less a hedge and more of jus
componenttext: No, I wasn't suggesting that you should or you need to. I'm just kind of -- I'm just trying to gather some information on where hedge premiums might be right now. Because it feels like if you did or if anybody did, it would be less a hedge and more of just a sheer bet that oil prices will be moving higher. So I'm only just trying to quantify the expense.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's exactly it. It's about $3 a barrel is what we're paying right now for hedging. One thing, back to your earlier question, Jamie, I just wanted to comment about what we're doing and what happens if fuel goes up. As you know, we're retiring all o
componenttext: Yes, that's exactly it. It's about $3 a barrel is what we're paying right now for hedging. One thing, back to your earlier question, Jamie, I just wanted to comment about what we're doing and what happens if fuel goes up. As you know, we're retiring all of our 737-400 classics. And those burn about 935 gallons an hour, and we're replacing those with 900ERs, and those burn about 910 gallons an hour. So you can see, we're getting more fuel-efficient as we get rid of those aircraft.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And adding -- from 144 to 181 seats.
componenttext: And adding -- from 144 to 181 seats.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016

componenttext: That's right. And adding 37 more seats, so that's a huge plus. Lower fuel burn with more seats. So that helps us over the long run as well.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jamie, not to buy along here. Just to throw another stat out there. So in a rising fuel environment, we're 25% more efficient than the industry. That helps us. And two, if you go back to '09, we had 8 aircraft that were unencumbered. If fuel spikes up or
componenttext: Jamie, not to buy along here. Just to throw another stat out there. So in a rising fuel environment, we're 25% more efficient than the industry. That helps us. And two, if you go back to '09, we had 8 aircraft that were unencumbered. If fuel spikes up or the economy turns like some people suspect it might, we've got today 86 aircraft that are unencumbered, and we'll be well positioned for that.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016

componenttext: Bran, at the Investor Day, you alluded to the possibility of being a net borrower this year in order to fund the buyback. With the stock market turmoil and concerns about global growth, granted it seems like we're seeing any major effect at the U.S. airlines yet. But have you -- I guess, are you still thinking about your leverage the same way as maybe in the Investor Day? I realize that's very little to begin with but just wondering if you're still thinking about potentially being a net borrower.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Darryl, yes, I think we are. I think that our balance sheet is -- I would call it a fortress balance sheet right now. Our debt-to-cap is low. If there is a recession, there is no better positioned airline than Alaska. But the amount that we were talk
componenttext: Yes. Darryl, yes, I think we are. I think that our balance sheet is -- I would call it a fortress balance sheet right now. Our debt-to-cap is low. If there is a recession, there is no better positioned airline than Alaska. But the amount that we were talking about borrowing I think at the Investor Day, we put up on the slide maybe $100 million to $200 million, that's pretty small in the grand scheme of things. It certainly does not put the company at any more risk recession or not, so we're very open to continuing to look at borrowing to manage the capital structure and would likely do so in 2016.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And then on CapEx, it looked like from your investor rep, that you split some deposits forward into the fourth quarter. We've actually seen that at another airline this quarter as well. Just wondering what's driving that? And if you're getting better pricing as a result of making the deposits earlier?

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016

componenttext: Yes. Darryl, this is Mark. I'll just say that we did do that. It was a favor to one of our manufacturers, and it does help us out. Favors go back and forth. We had a great partnership with both of our manufacturers, and we do that from time to time.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wonder -- can you just talk about demand in the state of Alaska, if there's been any change there? I don't know to what extent it's a source of corporate bookings for you. And then obviously, there's this annual dividend. We get questions on that from tim
componenttext: Wonder -- can you just talk about demand in the state of Alaska, if there's been any change there? I don't know to what extent it's a source of corporate bookings for you. And then obviously, there's this annual dividend. We get questions on that from time to time. Is there any change in demand trends given the decline in energy crisis here?

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Duane, this is Joe Sprague, and since I just got back from [indiscernible] late last night, people are pointing at me to take this one, so I'll give it a shot. I know there's some question about oil activity, oil business-related activity in the State of
componenttext: Duane, this is Joe Sprague, and since I just got back from [indiscernible] late last night, people are pointing at me to take this one, so I'll give it a shot. I know there's some question about oil activity, oil business-related activity in the State of Alaska. And I think the first thing I would just say is despite Alaska, the state being known for its oil reserves and its oil production, our exposure on that front is actually relatively small. We get business, oil-related business obviously flying our scheduled flight up to the crude oil bay. And then we get additional oil-related business because there's so many oilfield workers that actually live outside of Alaska and commute to work. And so we do get revenue from that activity. I would say it's fairly stable. A lot of the oilfield production, workers. Although production is declining, those oilfields still require the same amount of workers to sort of operate the drills and the pipelines and so forth. And so it's actually a very stable business. I think that we probably will see a bit of a reduction in the exploration for new oil deposits, but that's a much smaller portion of our overall oil portfolio. So bottom line is I think that our exposure on the oil side is minimal and stable. Beyond that obviously the state is having some issues because of the fact that they get most of the state revenue from oil reserves, oil royalties and so forth. And so there's a lot of question about this permanent fund dividend check that all of the state residents receive. However, that's tied more to overall market performance at this point than it is to oil prices. So ironically, in 2015, the PFD check that all residents received was over $2,000, and that was actually up from 2014. So some of the proposals floating around in the legislature might take that number down. It won't eliminate it by any means. And I think as you look at some of the other factors for travel in the State of Alaska, a lot of the intra-Alaska travel by residence is nondiscretionary because they just -- they have to go. There's no roads in a lot of cases. And then another big driver over the course of the year for travel in the State of Alaska is tourism, which is actually up. They had their best year ever in 2015 and they're expecting another good year in 2016. So all in all, I think we see fairly stable demand in the State of Alaska.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful color. Just a brand question. Given your excellent product, service and reliability, how do think about balancing that perception for customers that end up on segments operated by your partners? Let's say, it's a hypothetical example. Custo
componenttext: That's helpful color. Just a brand question. Given your excellent product, service and reliability, how do think about balancing that perception for customers that end up on segments operated by your partners? Let's say, it's a hypothetical example. Customer books in Alaska flight that's actually an American codeshare, which is actually operated on RJ by Mesa. So purely hypothetical. How do you think about managing that customer experience?

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Andrew. I think the good news is that as we continue to grow, and I think I've shared in the past just a massive amount of passengers are actually traveling on our own new expanded network. Most of that experience you're referring to is going
componenttext: Yes, this is Andrew. I think the good news is that as we continue to grow, and I think I've shared in the past just a massive amount of passengers are actually traveling on our own new expanded network. Most of that experience you're referring to is going behind big partners' hubs. And we try to be really clear on our confirmation records and everything else who they will be flying and what they will be flying. But from all the surveys and everything we received, we don't see any indication that instances like that have any real impact to our customers.

componenttext: And Duane, we do a lot of business with SkyWest for regional jets. I have folks today with SkyWest reviewing their performance on a quarterly basis. So whether it's safety performance, operation performance, customer satisfaction performance, we hold our CPA carriers to a very high standard. The same high standard in Alaska.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016

componenttext: I guess, a follow-up to Andrew just on the competitive capacity here. Certainly appreciate the update. It seems like the 2Q numbers moving to up 12% from I think it was up 8% as of last quarter is largely coming from Spirit and Southwest routes that were announced. I guess, one, do you have an initial read on 3Q competitive capacity? And then two, with the ULCCs growing more, how do you think about the to pricing in your markets, if any? And what do you plan to do to adjust to these new entrants?

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll take the first part. I'll hand Jamie the second. So Q3 right now, if you just run the numbers recognizing there's still industry changes, it's about up 13% again. So I'm not personally expecting competitive capacity to abate anytime soon, but also as
componenttext: I'll take the first part. I'll hand Jamie the second. So Q3 right now, if you just run the numbers recognizing there's still industry changes, it's about up 13% again. So I'm not personally expecting competitive capacity to abate anytime soon, but also as I shared earlier, as we implement new initiatives as well as dial back our own growth in the back half of the year, I feel very good about where we sit chained on the pricing.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Pricing, I'll just reiterate what I said earlier. We haven't in the past really felt the need to match sort of the published structured price points that ULCCs have brought. We still perform very well. If you actually look at some of the markets out of Po
componenttext: Pricing, I'll just reiterate what I said earlier. We haven't in the past really felt the need to match sort of the published structured price points that ULCCs have brought. We still perform very well. If you actually look at some of the markets out of Portland, we will typically at a market operate more seats than ULCCs do and outperform on both load factor and yield and have done so over a series of quarters. So I think our product has held up very well. Our loyalty has held up very well. We have incredible point of sale strength out of Seattle. I don't really think that, that part of the market, the Seattle part of the market, is where they're focused on. So we've seen stability in the sort of structured price environment even as they've come in and that's sort of what we anticipated. If something changes, obviously, be accurate with the market share if we need to.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016

componenttext: Great. And then one follow-up for Andrew. I think on the last call, you said your forward load factors for November and December were flat to slightly up, but the realized loads were down about a point in those months. Is that something you're anticipating? Or what changed over the course of the quarter that kind of caused -- that caused that to decelerate a bit?

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So this is Shane again. I know we issue at times where we actually are. I don't know that we actually give sort of end of period guidance. So I think the numbers that we've shared are just where we are right now. Anytime we grow capacity at a sizable rate
componenttext: So this is Shane again. I know we issue at times where we actually are. I don't know that we actually give sort of end of period guidance. So I think the numbers that we've shared are just where we are right now. Anytime we grow capacity at a sizable rate, we're always looking to book ahead of the booking curve last year, sort of get out in front of it, get as much leisure traffic as we can. We don't see the same sort of elasticity for the closing traffic. It's more stable. We know that. It's not going to grow at the same rate that capacity does, so we totally anticipate that those early load type of guests would decline towards sort of flattish performance year-over-year. And that's typically what our goal is, is to keep sort of flat load factor performance year-over-year. Sometimes we hit it. We often do. Sometimes, we're a little bit shy of it.

componenttext: Yes. So Dan, I'll just tell you that we don't have an exact number. What we know is that high-quality industrials do have more leverage than we do. They're in the 40% to 45% range. componenttext: I see. And then, Andrew, I appreciate the commentary around competitive capacity. componenttextpreview: Dan, your analysis is spot on. Essentially really for the first 3 quarters, it was 100% associated with 1 carrier. But as we move forward, you have some Southwest and some ULCCs. And the other thing that we're seeing a little bit, too, is that the big net
componenttext: Dan, your analysis is spot on. Essentially really for the first 3 quarters, it was 100% associated with 1 carrier. But as we move forward, you have some Southwest and some ULCCs. And the other thing that we're seeing a little bit, too, is that the big network guys are being added to their hubs, which we fly to many of the hubs. So that's the other piece that's replacing the decline in Delta's impact.

componenttextpreview: Savi, it's Ben. I think the first thing to do between Andrew's group and mine, we just work really closely in Seattle, and what we do we is we just model every time of day not only our schedule but all the other airlines schedule. And we map out by our --
componenttext: Savi, it's Ben. I think the first thing to do between Andrew's group and mine, we just work really closely in Seattle, and what we do we is we just model every time of day not only our schedule but all the other airlines schedule. And we map out by our -- by 15-minute increments how we can best manage the schedule. And if we move things around by 10 minutes or so, that's kind of how we do it. So we have all the departures, all the arrivals. We model it out and then we figure out the best schedule to fit -- to optimize our network.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Melissa, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Alaska Air Group Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2015 Earnings Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded and will be a
componenttext:
Good morning. My name is Melissa, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Alaska Air Group Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2015 Earnings Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded and will be accessible for future playback at www.alaskaair.com. [Operator Instructions] 
I would now like to turn the call over to Alaska Air Group's Managing Director of Investor Relations, Lavanya Sareen.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Melissa, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us for Alaska Air Group's Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2015 Earnings Call.On the call today, our CEO Brad Tilden, will provide an overview of the business; our Chief Commercial Officer,
componenttext:
Thanks, Melissa, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us for Alaska Air Group's Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2015 Earnings Call.
On the call today, our CEO Brad Tilden, will provide an overview of the business; our Chief Commercial Officer, Andrew Harrison, will share the revenue results for the fourth quarter and full year; and then Brandon Pedersen, our CFO, will discuss our financial results for 2015 and outlook for 2016.
Several members of our senior management team are also on hand to help answer your questions.
As a reminder, our comments today will include forward-looking statements regarding our future expectations, which may differ significantly from actual results. Information or risk factors that could affect our business can be found in our SEC filings.
We will refer to certain non-GAAP financial measures such as adjusted earnings and unit costs, excluding fuel. We have provided a reconciliation between the most directly comparable GAAP and non-GAAP measures in our earnings release.
This morning, Alaska Air Group reported a fourth quarter GAAP net profit of $191 million. Excluding mark-to-market fuel hedge losses and certain other items that netted to $5 million, the company recorded fourth quarter 2015 net income of $186 million or $1.46 per diluted share. This result compares to First Call estimate of $1.40 per share and exceeds last year's adjusted net income of $125 million or $0.94 per diluted share.
For the full year, Air Group reported a record adjusted net profit of $842 million, that's up 47%. Earnings per share grew 56% to $6.51 per share, with the incremental growth driven by the significant number of shares repurchased during the year. Additional information about cost expectations, capacity plans, fuel hedging, capital expenditures and other items can be found in our investor update included in our Form 8-K issued this morning and available on our website at alaskaair.com.
And with that, I'll turn the call over to Brad.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Lavanya, and good morning, everyone. I'm sure you've all seen our results by now and have seen that 2015 was a record year on almost every front. While every airline has benefited from low fuel prices, Alaska led the industry in many of the underl
componenttext:
Thanks, Lavanya, and good morning, everyone. I'm sure you've all seen our results by now and have seen that 2015 was a record year on almost every front. While every airline has benefited from low fuel prices, Alaska led the industry in many of the underlying drivers of financial performance. Areas like operational reliability, customer satisfaction, customer growth and low fares, low costs. These are the areas that represent our competitive advantage or our economic moat, and they're also the reasons that our financial performance is what it is. I'd like to start the call by covering a few of these areas.
First, safety. We reduced what we call our risk level 3 events dramatically over the last 5 years. And over the same time period, our lost time injuries are down more than 25%. We're by no means perfect. And safety events, no matter how small, remind us of the enormous responsibility we have towards our customers, our employees and their families. And again, a focus on doing things safely is also a focus on doing things right, and that benefits everyone.
Operationally, Alaska leads the industry. Notwithstanding a tough December at Horizon, 86.1% of our flights in 2015 arrived on time, and that resulted in Alaska being named the #1 North American carrier by FlightStats for the sixth straight year. We also led the industry with the fewest number of customer complaints, and our completion rate of 99.5% was second among the 9 largest domestic airlines. This performance led to the Wall Street Journal ranking us the top airline for the third year in a row and for the fourth out of the last 5 years.
I want to thank Ben and Dave, together with their operational leaders and all of our frontline employees, for their focus on getting it right with more than 900 flights every single day.
Moving to the next item. In 2015, our internal measure of customer satisfaction reached a new record high of 86%, a 2-point improvement over last year and a remarkable 16-point increase since we began collecting this data in 2007. We know that satisfied customers have contributed to record growth in both our Mileage Plan and our credit card. Considering how established these programs are, these record growth rates are extraordinary, and they are huge credit to our people.
And we've spoken to you in the past about Beyond Service, a 2-day customer service workshop for our frontline employees. We've now completed all 66 classes. Long-time company leaders Andy Schneider, Diana Shaw and Jeff Butler led this fantastic effort. And I want to both thank and congratulate them and their teams who put in countless hours putting these classes together. I believe this program is already moving the needle in terms of how we focus on our customers.
On the labor front, with our new dispatcher contracts, we are the only U.S. airline to have no open contracts at this time. The weighted average duration of our agreements is almost 3 years, which compares very favorably to the rest of the industry.
As folks have said before, the airline business is the ultimate team sport. And for an airline to run well, the team has to work together. As you know, this is an area where we spent a lot of time, and our people are incredibly proud of what they've built at Alaska. Or employee engagement store -- scores and our top 100 ranking in the Forbes employer survey are a testament to this.
We're also very proud that when our company does well, our employees benefit. Every employee at Air Group participates in the same gain-sharing plan, which we call PBP. This program, combined with our monthly operational bonus program, will pay out a record $120 million this year, with $98 million of this being paid to our employees tomorrow. This is the seventh consecutive year where our employees will get a full month's pay in performance bonuses. This alignment is very powerful, and we believe it will do nothing but benefit us in future years.
So those areas, combined with our low fares and low costs, our strong balance sheet and our simple and profitable fleet, represent our competitive advantage. Our performance in these areas, together with low fuel prices, drove our financial results. And I'd like to highlight those now.
As Lavanya said, our net income for the quarter was $186 million, up 49% from 2014. And for the year, it was $842 million, up 47%. Our pretax margin expanded 680 basis points to 24% for the year, and our ROIC for the trailing 12 months of 25.2% is more than 3x our cost of capital.
We expect these results will put our pretax margin and ROIC both in the top 10% of the S&P 500. Our cash flows from operations were almost $1.6 billion. Free cash flow was $760 million. And of this total, over $600 million was returned to shareholders. We bought back 5.5% of our stock this year, and we bought back 35% since 2007.
We were very excited to announce this morning our third dividend event [ph]. Our dividend yield is 1.6%, bringing us closer to our goal of having a dividend that resembles high-quality industrials.
And with respect to the quality and diversity of our route network, I thought you might be interested in knowing that even if we adjusted our fuel prices to $3 a gallon, markets representing 95% of our revenue would still be profitable.
2015 was a great year for all of our constituents: customers, employees, communities and owners. And as you know, this continues a longer-term trend. So we feel good about our performance. There's obviously some concern in the industry about the revenue environment. And on that score, I would like to say that we're quite optimistic about 2016, and we feel good about both our geographies and our customer segments. 90% of our revenue is generated in the domestic U.S. market, which is a good place to be. And 2/3 of our revenue has a leisure focus, which is more resilient in a downturn and more stable through the cycle.
As we move forward in 2016, we're focused on a number of new initiatives, which will -- which we expect will bring value to both customers and shareholders. These include: launching our new premium economy product; continuing to reconfigure our fleet, with renewal of the 737 fleet at Alaska and preparation for the possible introduction of regional jets at Horizon; growing the 20 new markets that we added in 2015; enhancing our alliance relationships, primarily in the international arena; better marketing our Mileage Plan and credit card, which have new benefits for members; and finally, further lowering our cost structure and making our fare advantage better known to customers.
As I close, I want to thank our team of 15,000 people for an incredible year. And with that, I'll turn the call over to Andrew.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Brad, and good morning, everyone. We were very pleased with our 2015 passenger revenue, which grew 4.7%. This is in contrast to the industry's revenue decline of 1%. We were within 1 point of industry unit revenue performance, despite competitive
componenttext:
Thanks, Brad, and good morning, everyone. We were very pleased with our 2015 passenger revenue, which grew 4.7%. This is in contrast to the industry's revenue decline of 1%. We were within 1 point of industry unit revenue performance, despite competitive capacity headwinds of 12%. For the fourth quarter, our revenue was up 5.5% against a backdrop of 9% increase in competitive capacity. That drove our PRASM down 6.6% but well within our expectations.
We added 18 new markets in the second half of 2015, and 11 of those were in the fourth quarter. This is the largest number of new markets added in any single quarter in over a decade. And we understand there continue to be questions around our growth, so we went back and looked at a few data points that I want to share with you. These reinforce for us that we continue to take the right actions.
First, our launch of 20 new markets over the last year brings our total North America destinations served from Seattle to 86. That's more than 2x our closest competitor at 39. And this creates the best schedule utility for customers in Seattle and the Pacific Northwest.
Second, notwithstanding a competitive onslaught, our growth has helped us maintain our Seattle market share at 51%. This is unchanged from 3 years ago, and our Seattle hub is performing exceptionally well.
Third, our new markets are maturing quickly. The portfolio of new markets launched in the last 12 months are profitable. More importantly, half of these markets have only operated for 1 quarter, being our seasonally weakest, Q4.
And then finally, as we highlighted at Investor Day, over the last 5 years, we've added 90 new markets, grown capacity at a compounded annual growth rate of 7.6% and revenue at 7.9%. Industry's revenue grew at a rate of less than 3% over the same period.
If you're asking, "Andrew, what is your point here?" The point is this. Our total capacity growth over the past 5 years accounts for $1.8 billion or 1/3 of our revenues. Margins on this revenue are in line with system average. Said another way, our earnings per share would be approximately $2 lower than what we've reported today had we decided to keep capacity flat.
The bottom line is this. Growth has been good for our customers, our employees and unquestionably, for our shareholders. And we believe that a thoughtful growth as a low-cost carrier that enjoys strong customer loyalty will increase our network utility, diversify our revenue base and create durable earning streams. These outcomes far outweigh the short-term impact of RASM comps, which we're experiencing today, and we will likely see through the first half of 2016.
Moving to the performance of the broader commercial business. Our partnerships are growing. Over the last year, we provided our customers with access to an incremental 60 international destinations and 3,600 flights per day, on which to earn and redeem miles. In fact, passengers on Alaska metal coming from Hainan, Icelandair and Emirates increased 43% in the fourth quarter as a result of our new agreements, coupled with our partners' expanded service.
Customer loyalty is growing at unprecedented rates even in the face of competition. Active Mileage Plan members are up 15.5% this year, outstripping passenger growth of 8.9%. This is the second consecutive year of double-digit growth in our Mileage Plan members. More impressive, our elite members grew 19%, pointing to increased stickiness with our brand. And our credit card members increased 11.6%, making 2015 the strongest year for card member growth since we started tracking this data.
Our Affinity program generated nearly $700 million of cash flow in 2015 and will continue to grow in 2016. A very important initiative that we announced at Investor Day in December that will further grow our revenue.
First, we'll introduce a premium cost product on our 737s and our regional jets, adding at least $85 million in annual profit by 2018. We'll start to retrofit existing aircraft in the second half of 2016 and will complete 75 aircraft by year-end.
Second, our new agreement with Bank of America will add $60 million in new annual revenue starting in the first quarter of '16. And our Affinity Visa card offers industry-leading benefits like no first-bag fee, no international transaction costs, a companion fare and the lowest annual fee amongst comparable cards. We are confident that our card will remain top of wallet for existing holders and help us continue to grow the cardholder base and related revenues.
And then finally, we'll be adding 2 more regional jets to our network this month to fill a market need for an aircraft that can serve longer-haul markets with demands that doesn't justify a 737. We'll also be replacing our 8 CRJ-700 with Embraer 175s, as they have an 8.5% more capacity and allow us to sell premium seats and give us greater range. This is an area where we think we have plenty of room for profitable growth in 2016 and beyond. The 4 markets we launched thus far are already profitable with 6 months -- within 6 months of launch. And Brandon's going to talk a bit more about this in a moment.
Looking forward at capacity growth. Q1 is expected to be up 13.5%, given a heavy new delivery schedule that meters down to 10.8% as we enter the seasonally strongest second quarter and we move to retire our 737-400s.
Today, I am reiterating our 2016 full year growth expectation of 8%. We expect growth in the second half of 2016 to be in the neighborhood of 5%.
Moving to competitive capacity. Other airline capacity, competitive capacity is expected to be up 13% and 12% in Q1 and Q2, respectively. To reiterate what Brad said, we're optimistic about 2016. Underlying demand in our geography is strong. New markets continue to deliver. And loyalty and credit card programs are growing. New revenue initiatives we're implementing will deliver an annual run rate of $150 million. This gives us confidence that our growth is sound and that we will continue to deliver on shareholder returns.
With that, I'll turn the call over to Brandon.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Andrew, and good morning, everyone. As Brad said, fourth quarter adjusted earnings grew by 49% to $186 million, and earnings per share grew by 55% to $1.46 per share. The record fourth quarter result brings our full year net profit to $842 million
componenttext:
Thanks, Andrew, and good morning, everyone. As Brad said, fourth quarter adjusted earnings grew by 49% to $186 million, and earnings per share grew by 55% to $1.46 per share. The record fourth quarter result brings our full year net profit to $842 million and earnings per share to $6.51 per share.
Earnings per share has almost doubled since 2012, even in the face of unprecedented competition in our Seattle hub since that time.
Similarly, our after-tax return on invested capital has grown from 13% in 2012 to 25.2% this year. Our net operating profit has more than doubled over that period, yet our invested capital base has grown by only 11%. We expect our ROIC to lead about 90% of the companies in the S&P 500 and all but 10 industrials in the index.
Fourth quarter pretax profit grew by $86 million led by a $100 million decline in economic fuel costs. We recognized that low fuel prices will probably not last forever, so we remain focused on creating a permanent sustainable advantage by lowering nonfuel unit costs and increasing the fuel efficiency of our fleet.
Fourth quarter ex fuel unit costs declined by another 1.3%, bringing full year nonfuel unit costs down 0.8%. 2015 marks the sixth year in a row of nonfuel unit cost reduction and the 13th year out of the last 14 for the mainline.
Looking ahead into 2016, we expect nonfuel unit costs to be down 1% on the 8% ASM growth, consistent with our Investor Day guidance.
I might offer some thoughts on that track record. Every year now for 14 years, we've been chipping away at unit costs. And while each year -- in each individual year, like 0.5% or 1.5% of cost reduction doesn't sound like a lot, the cumulative impact is enormous, especially when the competition has unit costs that are growing, albeit slowly. Because of that focus on productivity, our emphasis on low overhead and a general culture of frugality that's growing throughout Air Group, our cost structure today looks a lot like the low-cost carriers and it's nearly 25% lower than the legacy carriers. And if you include fuel and nonoperating expenses, our cost gap widens to 36%. To borrow Brad's phrase that he used on Investor Day, our economic moat is getting wider and it's giving us confidence about the sustainability of our results.
As we mentioned, we remain focused on having one of the most fuel-efficient fleets in the industry. In 2015, our fuel efficiency on an ASM per gallon basis improved by another 2%, with much of that coming from the delivery during the year of 11 737-900ERs and the installation of split-scimitar winglets across the majority of the Boeing fleet. This year's improvement extends the cumulative fuel efficiency improvement over the last 10 years to 24%. And the trend should continue in 2016, as we take delivery of 19 new 737-900ERs, phase out 13 older, less-efficient and maintenance intensive 737-400s and add longer-stage length to regional flying.
And speaking of regional flying. Andrew mentioned in the -- Andrew mentioned the profitable growth opportunities we see with large regional jets. In order to fund that growth and replace 15 Q400s that are scheduled for lease return in 2018, we're in the final phase of a regional jet campaign. It's likely that we'll place an order for 30 large regional jets in the first quarter of 2016, with delivery starting in 2017, if we can reach acceptable commercial terms with the parties involved. Our intent is for those jets to be flown by Horizon if our pilots and flight attendants approve changes to their collective bargaining agreements that will make them cost-competitive with other CPA providers. Voting is taking place now.
SkyWest does a great job operating regional jets for us today, and they'll continue to operate them in our network despite us potentially bringing some of that jet flying back in-house.
Alaska ended the year with $1.3 billion in cash. Operating cash flow increased by 54% to almost $1.6 billion. 2015 marks the second year in a row of operating cash flow in excess of $1 billion. CapEx was just under $800 million, resulting in free cash flow of almost $800 million. We used that considerable free cash flow to buy back 7.2 million shares of our common stock or about 5.5% of the shares outstanding. It's noteworthy that going back to 2007, we've bought back 35% of the company.
In addition, we paid $102 million in dividends, bringing total return to shareholders to $607 million. Our announcement today that we're increasing our dividends by 38% reaffirms our board's confidence in the sustainability of our cash flows, is consistent with our goal of creating a track record of dividend increases like other high-quality industrial companies and makes Alaska the highest yielding stock among U.S. airlines that pay a regular dividend.
Normal principal payments of $116 million brought our long-term debt balance to $686 million. We're now in a $300 million net cash position even after including operating leases. Alaska's adjusted debt-to-cap ratio stands at 27%. This compares with the media and S&P 500 debt-to-cap ratio of 45%. We have 78 unencumbered mainline aircraft and 86 unencumbered aircraft overall. Our pensions are 92% funded on a GAAP basis, and we have no required contributions again in 2016. Alaska remains 1 of only 2 U.S. airlines to have an investment-grade balance sheet.
And of course, in a rising interest rate environment, our low debt levels will further widen our cost GAAP versus competitors who are more highly leveraged. We expect to generate very strong cash flow again in 2016. We currently project CapEx to be $705 million next year, including options but excluding CapEx associated with a regional jet order, which could add up to $90 million next year, bringing the total close to $800 million. Using consensus estimates, that would imply free cash flow of nearly $650 million and free cash flow yield of over 7%.
We still expect to return more capital to owners in 2016 than we did in 2015, both through our higher dividend and through share buybacks. We have $880 million remaining on our $1 billion repurchase authorization.
As we enter 2016, our business is working well. We're safe. We run the most reliable operation in the business. We're delivering award-winning service. Customer preference has never been higher, our labor relations are excellent and contracts have an average length of just under 3 years. Our costs are low, and they're getting lower. Our investment-grade balance sheet is getting stronger. Our new cash flow streams are earnings accretive. We're returning record amounts of cash to our shareholders. And more importantly, and most importantly, our people are engaged, and we're confident in their ability to continue to do great things in 2016.
And with that, we'd like to open it up to questions that you may have.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from Savi Syth with Raymond James.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from Savi Syth with Raymond James.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just on the regional jet kind of strategy here, I wonder if you could just elaborate a little bit more about -- I know that the E175 success you've had, but I think the Q400 also kind of served the purpose along the West Coast and maybe even in Alaska. Ju
componenttext: Just on the regional jet kind of strategy here, I wonder if you could just elaborate a little bit more about -- I know that the E175 success you've had, but I think the Q400 also kind of served the purpose along the West Coast and maybe even in Alaska. Just wondering what the thinking behind taking down that fleet was? And if you don't get the pilot deal, would you kind of reverse that thinking or -- pilot and flight attendant deal? Or would you kind of go forward with it just maybe with a third-party carrier?

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Savi, it's Brandon. Maybe I'll start and Andrew can jump in. As we think about the regional jets, the opportunity here is as follows: one is they have increased reach versus the Q400, it delivers a better passenger experience, especially on those longer-s
componenttext: Savi, it's Brandon. Maybe I'll start and Andrew can jump in. As we think about the regional jets, the opportunity here is as follows: one is they have increased reach versus the Q400, it delivers a better passenger experience, especially on those longer-stage length mission than the Q400. Our competition, frankly, is using those in many of our markets. And I think we want to make sure that we're staying on par or better with that customer experience side. We have a much higher revenue opportunity with a 3-class cabin and actually in excess of 400 miles, the regional jet has a lower trip cost. The Q400 has been a great airplane for us, and it works well in the short-stage length around the Pacific Northwest, but I think there's an opportunity to tap into lots of new revenue opportunities with the regional jets by bringing some of those in-house.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Rajeev Lalwani with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Rajeev Lalwani with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a question on competitive capacity. It seems like it continues to grow as we look at the next couple of quarters. Can you just talk about why that is? And just in particular, it seems like there's gate constraints at the Seattle Airport, which would
componenttext: Just a question on competitive capacity. It seems like it continues to grow as we look at the next couple of quarters. Can you just talk about why that is? And just in particular, it seems like there's gate constraints at the Seattle Airport, which would tell us that there shouldn't be growth. But it seems like there is. I just like to understand that dynamic a bit better, if that makes sense?

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rajeev, it's Andrew. Yes, as we've shared competitive capacity is up 13% for the next few quarters. A lot of this is annualization of competitive capacity that was already announced in 2015 and started in 2015. As we've been talking, this is something tha
componenttext: Rajeev, it's Andrew. Yes, as we've shared competitive capacity is up 13% for the next few quarters. A lot of this is annualization of competitive capacity that was already announced in 2015 and started in 2015. As we've been talking, this is something that we spend a lot of time preparing for and equipping ourselves for with our low-cost strong customer base. So we are very much have this in our sights. As it relates to Sea-Tac, I think it's one -- you're right, it's getting a little fuller certainly at the peak times. And it's one, if you want to fly at certain peak times, there's trade-offs to be made. In some of the lull period, there's still space. But overall, we think that we still have a lot of good opportunity at Sea-Tac as we continue to grow our network and mature in new markets.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Andrew, in terms of the competitive capacity, I mean, is most of it just lapping? It seems like we've been hearing announcements from folks like Spirit and American, and I guess I'm just wondering if it's more than just a lapping dynamic?
componenttext: Andrew, in terms of the competitive capacity, I mean, is most of it just lapping? It seems like we've been hearing announcements from folks like Spirit and American, and I guess I'm just wondering if it's more than just a lapping dynamic?

componenttext: No. There is some new -- you'll be obviously aware of the major reasons of the growth. But as we look at the Q1 and Q2, of the 13% in the second quarter, about 2.5 points of that 13% is actually ULCC growth, and we've also seen some Southwest growth as well. So there is some new growth in those figures for sure as we move forward.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Andrew, I appreciate the reiteration of the capacity guidance for '16. But thinking about how 2015 trended, and I think you ended up about 250 bps higher than your original guidance. Q1 is about 50 bps than where you were in October. How are you thinking
componenttext: Andrew, I appreciate the reiteration of the capacity guidance for '16. But thinking about how 2015 trended, and I think you ended up about 250 bps higher than your original guidance. Q1 is about 50 bps than where you were in October. How are you thinking about incremental capacity growth in '16 with crude sub 30 and competitors continuing to aggressively enter Alaska markets?

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Julia. It's a good question, and I knew I was going to be held accountable for my 8% guidance growing pretty large. That's actually why I've reiterated it. I think what I would share with you is in 2015, and I think we've sort of been transparent
componenttext: Thanks, Julia. It's a good question, and I knew I was going to be held accountable for my 8% guidance growing pretty large. That's actually why I've reiterated it. I think what I would share with you is in 2015, and I think we've sort of been transparent here, is that a part of that was bringing forward some of the growth to continue to grow Seattle at a higher rate than we initially planned to do. But as we move into 2016, and yes, we're a little higher in the first quarter, we're getting a lot of deliveries this year. We're getting 19 ERs. They're heavily loaded to the front end, and we don't stop pushing out our 400s until the middle of the year, and there's 13 of those. So we're a little higher in the first half of the year than we'd like to. But as we move into the back part of the year, I think we're going to be around 5% or so. And the other thing is we have a lot of mod lines going now putting ATG4, WiFi on as well as mods for premium economy. So we're going to be using a lot of those aircraft to get all that done by the end of the year. So I feel fairly confident about where we sit today with our capacity guidance.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Is there flexibility to delay the retirements on the -400s or even accelerate deliveries if you wanted to? Or is there room still on utilization if you wanted to push your growth above 8%?
componenttext: Is there flexibility to delay the retirements on the -400s or even accelerate deliveries if you wanted to? Or is there room still on utilization if you wanted to push your growth above 8%?

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The Chief Operating Officer is looking at me right now, and if I was to extend the 400s, I might lose some body parts. So the reality is the 400s are going. We really need those to leave because of training and all sorts of other things. New deliveries ar
componenttext: The Chief Operating Officer is looking at me right now, and if I was to extend the 400s, I might lose some body parts. So the reality is the 400s are going. We really need those to leave because of training and all sorts of other things. New deliveries are all fixed. I think the opportunity for us is if we wanted to grow more, we certainly have utilization play. And certainly, if we want to reduce capacity, we can do that by getting things through the mod lines. At the end of the day, we're going to do what's best for Air Group, and we do have that flexibility.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Julia, this is Brad. I might just sort of add on it. If the calculus is sort of risk return, it's -- and as you guys have seen, we have had tremendous success putting this new capacity to markets. The returns have been there. Most of the markets we added
componenttext: Julia, this is Brad. I might just sort of add on it. If the calculus is sort of risk return, it's -- and as you guys have seen, we have had tremendous success putting this new capacity to markets. The returns have been there. Most of the markets we added in 2015 were profitable in the first 3 months. But there's risk to growing at a higher level over a sustained period of time, there's risk. And so we're sitting here trying to balance our presence in Seattle, which is an incredible economic engine for the company, taking advantage of market opportunities while sort of measuring risks. So I think today, we want to reiterate that our long-term mindset is 4% to 8% growth. When we see more opportunities, we'll be at the higher end of that, but that is our mindset and that's what we want you to know.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Brandon, you sound very fired up and passionate in your prepared remarks, like more than usual. I'm wondering if that's sort of because you're displeased with the stock performance this year. And the question that I have is how do you think about the buyb
componenttext: Brandon, you sound very fired up and passionate in your prepared remarks, like more than usual. I'm wondering if that's sort of because you're displeased with the stock performance this year. And the question that I have is how do you think about the buyback? One of the things you guys have done better in the last couple of years has been a little more opportunistic about the timing of when you buy in pullbacks. But do you think about ramping it up significantly when it pulls back like this, unless you're not blacked out tomorrow, not just because you get a chance to buy it cheaper or because you get a chance to sort of send the message that if this happens again and if your stock goes down like it's gone down as much as it has lately, that you'll be there to take advantage of it and to support it. Did you think about that?

componenttext: It's Brandon. I had a triple latte on the way to work, that's why I'm fired up, and I do have a high degree of anxiety about the decline of the stock price since the start of the year. But in terms of execution, Mark's the guy to talk about that.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hunter, it's Mark Eliasen. We are opportunistic, and we also are also programmatic with our stock buyback. We do buy more shares when it's down and you've seen our behavior in the past. I can't comment on specific actions we might take, but we are aware o
componenttext: Hunter, it's Mark Eliasen. We are opportunistic, and we also are also programmatic with our stock buyback. We do buy more shares when it's down and you've seen our behavior in the past. I can't comment on specific actions we might take, but we are aware of where the stock is trading, and we do aggressively buy the stock.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the algebra of buying back the stock at lower prices rather than higher prices is very good for the owners of this business.
componenttext: And the algebra of buying back the stock at lower prices rather than higher prices is very good for the owners of this business.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Cool. And then, Andrew, one of the big topics of sort of over the last 6 to 9 months has been this concept of customer segmentation. And it's really been something that's been talked about in the context of the legacy guys competing against ULCCs, a
componenttext: Okay. Cool. And then, Andrew, one of the big topics of sort of over the last 6 to 9 months has been this concept of customer segmentation. And it's really been something that's been talked about in the context of the legacy guys competing against ULCCs, as the goal is to sort of prevent business travelers from buying fares that are designed to sell to leisure travelers. You guys highlighted today that you have about 1/3 of your passengers coming from business travel. So is there a level of self-cannibalization that you're not happy about right now as it relates to sort of how you manage that? And if so, are there any sort of IT-based projects underway -- IT-based projects I'm saying not seat reconfiguration, underway to sort of address it, particularly as you see ULCC growth ramp in your markets?

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hunter, I think I'm going to have Shane Tackett, VP of RM, answer that question. He's been spending a lot of time on that subject.
componenttext: Hunter, I think I'm going to have Shane Tackett, VP of RM, answer that question. He's been spending a lot of time on that subject.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Hunter, I hope I answer the right question. We've been in a unique position, maybe not strategically but we have, nonetheless, to be able to watch how other legacy carriers have handled sort of the segmentation at the lower end of the demand curve. An
componenttext: And Hunter, I hope I answer the right question. We've been in a unique position, maybe not strategically but we have, nonetheless, to be able to watch how other legacy carriers have handled sort of the segmentation at the lower end of the demand curve. And we've been sort of interested to see how they -- that has played out, how they developed the different fare products and whether or not we think that we actually need to develop something like that on our own. If we did, I feel like we needed to access that part of the demand curve, we could. There's not a lot of IT hurdle in the way we can develop a product and get it to market pretty quickly. Our sort of history with this, albeit small, certainly out of Portland, where we face ULCC competition, is we haven't felt the need to use those types of products. We think our customers not only appreciate the superior products we have, but recognize we have already very low fares. And so our differences in fare price for that kind of leisure-focused traveler that ULCCs are going after is much closer than maybe than some of the other carriers have had to experience in their market. So thus far, we haven't had to do it but we could if we need to.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from Michael Linenberg with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
