componenttext: I guess, a couple of questions here. I just -- I want to go back to your competitive capacity. I think you said 13%, March quarter; 12%, June quarter. Does that -- and I realize -- I'm not sure if this is in the number or not, but American put out some new markets yesterday, and it looks like things like L.A.-Anchorage, L.A.-Portland, L.A.-Seattle. Is that in that number?

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, it is not. I understand, it will be starting maybe in June. So that would need to be added to our number.
componenttext: No, it is not. I understand, it will be starting maybe in June. So that would need to be added to our number.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, Andrew, since I have you on, I mean, when I think about kind of your relationship and how you're sort of moving away from Delta and moving closer to American, I was actually surprised by the number of frequency that American is putting in
componenttext: Okay. And then, Andrew, since I have you on, I mean, when I think about kind of your relationship and how you're sort of moving away from Delta and moving closer to American, I was actually surprised by the number of frequency that American is putting in those markets. I mean, those are important markets for you. When I think about L.A.-Seattle, L.A.-Portland, I mean, those markets are pretty well served. I mean, so it just was a bit of a surprise. I mean, any thoughts on that? Or maybe you can't say anything about that.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I can't say a whole lot except to say that I read the press like you do. And it's very clear to me that what American is doing is continuing to fortify their position in Los Angeles. I think Seattle is probably in the top 10 largest O&Ds on the planet. An
componenttext: I can't say a whole lot except to say that I read the press like you do. And it's very clear to me that what American is doing is continuing to fortify their position in Los Angeles. I think Seattle is probably in the top 10 largest O&Ds on the planet. And they've decided to serve that with their own metal. And again, we have code on each other and we are looking at that. But at the end of the day, they're doing what I see is in their best interests.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, Andrew, you're saying this. But it might -- we actually need to think about this more ourselves, but I think what could be happening here is this is more about L.A. than Seattle. And there's a couple of airlines that are going to be fighting for
componenttext: I think, Andrew, you're saying this. But it might -- we actually need to think about this more ourselves, but I think what could be happening here is this is more about L.A. than Seattle. And there's a couple of airlines that are going to be fighting for dominance in LAX with the consolidation that's happening in the industry and what's happening with L.A. facilities, and that actually may be the story here.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016

componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And then just lastly, the large regional jets that you're looking at to replace the Q400s, are those large regional jets of a similar size? Or could we be looking at larger aircraft, 90-seaters, 100-seaters, being flown at Horizon?

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Helane, it's Brandon. Actually we've thought about it, but right now, we're moving forward with a 76-seat regional jet at Horizon, and we're also comfortable with 737s at Alaska. We love the simplicity of that. We recognize there might be a hole in the ma
componenttext: Helane, it's Brandon. Actually we've thought about it, but right now, we're moving forward with a 76-seat regional jet at Horizon, and we're also comfortable with 737s at Alaska. We love the simplicity of that. We recognize there might be a hole in the market, but we're not doing anything at this point to suggest that we would move forward with a 100-seat type aircraft.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Jamie Baker with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Jamie Baker with JPMorgan.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have 2 questions. When we think about the RASM declines at Alaska, they are comparatively unique to those at the industry in that they're mostly representative of the increased competition as opposed to the elimination of fuel surcharges, a strong dolla
componenttext: I have 2 questions. When we think about the RASM declines at Alaska, they are comparatively unique to those at the industry in that they're mostly representative of the increased competition as opposed to the elimination of fuel surcharges, a strong dollar, a crappy Brazil and so forth. Fuel is obviously a blessing for you here. But if and when fuel escalates, your competitors are actually going to be picking up RASM along the way that you won't save maybe for budgets improving in the State of Alaska. So I'm just wondering if you're content with what appears to be a virtual guarantee of significant margin compression if fuel begins to escalate? And if you're not, does that alter your view on the optimal network construct and/or your opinion on consolidation?

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jamie, it's Brandon. That's a super complicated question. We're not that smart out here in the Pacific Northwest. But I guess what I would say is -- and I addressed it a little bit in my prepared remarks, which is we don't have a belief that fuel is going
componenttext: Jamie, it's Brandon. That's a super complicated question. We're not that smart out here in the Pacific Northwest. But I guess what I would say is -- and I addressed it a little bit in my prepared remarks, which is we don't have a belief that fuel is going to be $28 a barrel WTI forever. And what I would say is that no public company can report record earnings quarter after quarter after quarter. And the other thing I would say is that we're generating really, really, really outstanding returns right now. If fuel goes up, I think it is possible that you could see margins come down. In terms of the broader strategy, what we're -- goes back to something maybe that Brad said, which is we're going to do the right thing for Alaska. We do have a profit hurdle internally. Most of our markets are well above that. Most of our markets would be well above that at $3 a fuel. And so we're going to continue to -- we are very satisfied with the network, and we're going to continue to do what's right. If fuel prices go up, we may adjust capacity. But again, we have a view on what our networks should look like because we have internal profit targets that those -- our routes need to meet.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was going to add. Yes, I think the industry today is different than where it was 6 or 8 or 10 years ago. These airlines are run by business people. People want to have earnings. They want to have returns on capital. I think if fuel prices go up as they
componenttext: I was going to add. Yes, I think the industry today is different than where it was 6 or 8 or 10 years ago. These airlines are run by business people. People want to have earnings. They want to have returns on capital. I think if fuel prices go up as they did 4, 5 years ago, I think you will see people adjust capacity throughout the industry, and that makes us optimistic. And again, I think our -- to get to your point about margin compression. Alaska's financial performance comes from our competitive advantage. It doesn't come from international exchange rate or Brazilian currency. It comes from us having a cost structure that's 36% lower than the other guys when you factor in fuel and interest costs. It comes from the fact that customers prefer to fly with us. We have incredible loyalty in Seattle. It comes from a very strong balance sheet, the right fleet. So I sort of think whatever, the world's going to move. What we get thrown our way is going to change from time to time. But I personally think this company has pretty strong competitive advantage. It's going to serve us well no matter what environment we're competing in.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Those are all helpful observations. Second question, if you did want to lock in the forward curve or something shaped similar to where the forward curve is today, say for the next 12 months, what sort of premium do you think you would have to pay? In othe
componenttext: Those are all helpful observations. Second question, if you did want to lock in the forward curve or something shaped similar to where the forward curve is today, say for the next 12 months, what sort of premium do you think you would have to pay? In other words, how much would oil have to move against you before a big hedging that became profitable?

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jamie, this is Mark. First of all, I don't think you'd see us taking a big hedging bet. We like the way we're working right now. The forward curve is nice and low. It's something like $50 a barrel or below that looking out for a long time. So we could do
componenttext: Jamie, this is Mark. First of all, I don't think you'd see us taking a big hedging bet. We like the way we're working right now. The forward curve is nice and low. It's something like $50 a barrel or below that looking out for a long time. So we could do something like that, but we kind of like our program the way it's working right now.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I wasn't suggesting that you should or you need to. I'm just kind of -- I'm just trying to gather some information on where hedge premiums might be right now. Because it feels like if you did or if anybody did, it would be less a hedge and more of jus
componenttext: No, I wasn't suggesting that you should or you need to. I'm just kind of -- I'm just trying to gather some information on where hedge premiums might be right now. Because it feels like if you did or if anybody did, it would be less a hedge and more of just a sheer bet that oil prices will be moving higher. So I'm only just trying to quantify the expense.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's exactly it. It's about $3 a barrel is what we're paying right now for hedging. One thing, back to your earlier question, Jamie, I just wanted to comment about what we're doing and what happens if fuel goes up. As you know, we're retiring all o
componenttext: Yes, that's exactly it. It's about $3 a barrel is what we're paying right now for hedging. One thing, back to your earlier question, Jamie, I just wanted to comment about what we're doing and what happens if fuel goes up. As you know, we're retiring all of our 737-400 classics. And those burn about 935 gallons an hour, and we're replacing those with 900ERs, and those burn about 910 gallons an hour. So you can see, we're getting more fuel-efficient as we get rid of those aircraft.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And adding -- from 144 to 181 seats.
componenttext: And adding -- from 144 to 181 seats.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's right. And adding 37 more seats, so that's a huge plus. Lower fuel burn with more seats. So that helps us over the long run as well.
componenttext: That's right. And adding 37 more seats, so that's a huge plus. Lower fuel burn with more seats. So that helps us over the long run as well.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jamie, not to buy along here. Just to throw another stat out there. So in a rising fuel environment, we're 25% more efficient than the industry. That helps us. And two, if you go back to '09, we had 8 aircraft that were unencumbered. If fuel spikes up or
componenttext: Jamie, not to buy along here. Just to throw another stat out there. So in a rising fuel environment, we're 25% more efficient than the industry. That helps us. And two, if you go back to '09, we had 8 aircraft that were unencumbered. If fuel spikes up or the economy turns like some people suspect it might, we've got today 86 aircraft that are unencumbered, and we'll be well positioned for that.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Darryl Genovesi with UBS.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Darryl Genovesi with UBS.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Brandon, at the Investor Day, you alluded to the possibility of being a net borrower this year in order to fund the buyback. With the stock market turmoil and concerns about global growth, granted it doesn't seem like we're seeing any major effect at the
componenttext: Brandon, at the Investor Day, you alluded to the possibility of being a net borrower this year in order to fund the buyback. With the stock market turmoil and concerns about global growth, granted it doesn't seem like we're seeing any major effect at the U.S. airlines yet. But have you -- I guess, are you still thinking about your leverage the same way as maybe in the Investor Day? I realize that's very little to begin with but just wondering if you're still thinking about potentially being a net borrower.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Darryl, yes, I think we are. I think that our balance sheet is -- I would call it a fortress balance sheet right now. Our debt-to-cap is low. If there is a recession, there is no better positioned airline than Alaska. But the amount that we were talk
componenttext: Yes. Darryl, yes, I think we are. I think that our balance sheet is -- I would call it a fortress balance sheet right now. Our debt-to-cap is low. If there is a recession, there is no better positioned airline than Alaska. But the amount that we were talking about borrowing I think at the Investor Day, we put up on the slide maybe $100 million to $200 million, that's pretty small in the grand scheme of things. It certainly does not put the company at any more risk recession or not, so we're very open to continuing to look at borrowing to manage the capital structure and would likely do so in 2016.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on CapEx, it looked like from your investor rep, that you split some deposits forward into the fourth quarter. We've actually seen that at another airline this quarter as well. Just wondering what's driving that? And if you're getting bette
componenttext: Okay. And then on CapEx, it looked like from your investor rep, that you split some deposits forward into the fourth quarter. We've actually seen that at another airline this quarter as well. Just wondering what's driving that? And if you're getting better pricing as a result of making the deposits earlier?

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Darryl, this is Mark. I'll just say that we did do that. It was a favor to one of our manufacturers, and it does help us out. Favors go back and forth. We had a great partnership with both of our manufacturers, and we do that from time to time.
componenttext: Yes. Darryl, this is Mark. I'll just say that we did do that. It was a favor to one of our manufacturers, and it does help us out. Favors go back and forth. We had a great partnership with both of our manufacturers, and we do that from time to time.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Duane Pfennigwerth with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Duane Pfennigwerth with Evercore ISI.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wonder -- can you just talk about demand in the state of Alaska, if there's been any change there? I don't know to what extent it's a source of corporate bookings for you. And then obviously, there's this annual dividend. We get questions on that from tim
componenttext: Wonder -- can you just talk about demand in the state of Alaska, if there's been any change there? I don't know to what extent it's a source of corporate bookings for you. And then obviously, there's this annual dividend. We get questions on that from time to time. Is there any change in demand trends given the decline in energy crisis here?

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Duane, this is Joe Sprague, and since I just got back from Juno late last night, people are pointing at me to take this one, so I'll give it a shot. I know there's some question about oil activity, oil business-related activity in the State of Alaska. And
componenttext: Duane, this is Joe Sprague, and since I just got back from Juno late last night, people are pointing at me to take this one, so I'll give it a shot. I know there's some question about oil activity, oil business-related activity in the State of Alaska. And I think the first thing I would just say is despite Alaska, the state being known for its oil reserves and its oil production, our exposure on that front is actually relatively small. We get business, oil-related business obviously flying our scheduled flight up to Prudhoe Bay. And then we get additional oil-related business because there's so many oilfield workers that actually live outside of Alaska and commute to work. And so we do get revenue from that activity. I would say it's fairly stable. A lot of the oilfield production workers. Although production is declining, those oilfields still require the same amount of workers to sort of operate the drills and the pipelines and so forth. And so it's actually a very stable business. I think that we probably will see a bit of a reduction in the exploration for new oil deposits, but that's a much smaller portion of our overall oil portfolio. So bottom line is I think that our exposure on the oil side is minimal and stable. Beyond that obviously the state is having some issues because of the fact that they get most of the state revenue from oil reserves, oil royalties and so forth. And so there's a lot of question about this permanent fund dividend check that all of the state residents receive. However, that's tied more to overall market performance at this point than it is to oil prices. So ironically, in 2015, the PFD check that all residents received was over $2,000, and that was actually up from 2014. So some of the proposals floating around in the legislature might take that number down. It won't eliminate it by any means. And I think as you look at some of the other factors for travel in the State of Alaska, a lot of the intra-Alaska travel by residents is nondiscretionary because they just -- they have to go. There's no roads in a lot of cases. And then another big driver over the course of the year for travel in the State of Alaska is tourism, which is actually up. They had their best year ever in 2015 and they're expecting another good year in 2016. So all in all, I think we see stable demand in the State of Alaska.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful color. Just a brand question. Given your excellent product, service and reliability, how do think about balancing that perception for customers that end up on segments operated by your partners? Let's say, it's a hypothetical example. Custo
componenttext: That's helpful color. Just a brand question. Given your excellent product, service and reliability, how do think about balancing that perception for customers that end up on segments operated by your partners? Let's say, it's a hypothetical example. Customer books in Alaska flight that's actually an American codeshare, which is actually operated on RJ by Mesa. So purely hypothetical. How do you think about managing that customer experience?

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Andrew. I think the good news is that as we continue to grow, and I think I've shared in the past just a massive amount of passengers are actually traveling on our own new expanded network. Most of that experience you're referring to is going
componenttext: Yes, this is Andrew. I think the good news is that as we continue to grow, and I think I've shared in the past just a massive amount of passengers are actually traveling on our own new expanded network. Most of that experience you're referring to is going behind big partners' hubs. And we try to be really clear on our confirmation records and everything else who they will be flying and what they will be flying. But from all the surveys and everything we received, we don't see any indication that instances like that have any real impact to our customers.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Duane, we do a lot of business with SkyWest with regional jets. I have folks today with SkyWest reviewing their performance on a quarterly basis. So whether it's safety performance, operation performance, customer satisfaction performance, we hold our
componenttext: And Duane, we do a lot of business with SkyWest with regional jets. I have folks today with SkyWest reviewing their performance on a quarterly basis. So whether it's safety performance, operation performance, customer satisfaction performance, we hold our CPA carriers to a very high standard. The same high standard in Alaska.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Andrew Didora with Bank of America.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Andrew Didora with Bank of America.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, a follow-up to Andrew just on the competitive capacity here. Certainly appreciate the update. It seems like the 2Q numbers moving to up 12% from I think it was up 8% as of last quarter is largely coming from Spirit and Southwest routes that were
componenttext: I guess, a follow-up to Andrew just on the competitive capacity here. Certainly appreciate the update. It seems like the 2Q numbers moving to up 12% from I think it was up 8% as of last quarter is largely coming from Spirit and Southwest routes that were announced. I guess, one, do you have an initial read on 3Q competitive capacity? And then two, with the ULCCs growing more, how do you think about the impact to pricing in your markets, if any? And what do you plan to do to adjust to these new entrants?

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll take the first part. I'll hand Shane the second. So Q3 right now, if you just run the numbers recognizing there's still industry changes, it's about up 13% again. So I'm not personally expecting competitive capacity to abate anytime soon, but also as
componenttext: I'll take the first part. I'll hand Shane the second. So Q3 right now, if you just run the numbers recognizing there's still industry changes, it's about up 13% again. So I'm not personally expecting competitive capacity to abate anytime soon, but also as I shared earlier, as we implement new initiatives as well as dial back our own growth in the back half of the year, I feel very good about where we sit. Shane, on the pricing?

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Pricing, I'll just reiterate what I said earlier. We haven't in the past really felt the need to match sort of the published structured price points that ULCCs have brought. We still perform very well. If you actually look at some of the markets out of Po
componenttext: Pricing, I'll just reiterate what I said earlier. We haven't in the past really felt the need to match sort of the published structured price points that ULCCs have brought. We still perform very well. If you actually look at some of the markets out of Portland, we will typically at a market operate more seats than ULCCs do and outperform on both load factor and yield and have done so over a series of quarters. So I think our product has held up very well. Our loyalty has held up very well. We have incredible point of sale strength out of Seattle. I don't really think that, that part of the market, the Seattle part of the market, is where they're focused on. So we've seen stability in the sort of structured price environment even as they've come in and that's sort of what we anticipated. If something changes, we'll obviously react to it and defend our market share if we need to.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then one follow-up for Andrew. I think on the last call, you said your forward load factors for November and December were flat to slightly up, but the realized loads were down about a point in those months. Is that something you're anticipatin
componenttext: Great. And then one follow-up for Andrew. I think on the last call, you said your forward load factors for November and December were flat to slightly up, but the realized loads were down about a point in those months. Is that something you're anticipating? Or what changed over the course of the quarter that kind of caused -- that caused that to decelerate a bit?

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So this is Shane again. I know we issue at times where we actually are. I don't know that we actually give sort of end of period guidance. So I think the numbers that we've shared are just where we are right now. Anytime we grow capacity at a sizable rate
componenttext: So this is Shane again. I know we issue at times where we actually are. I don't know that we actually give sort of end of period guidance. So I think the numbers that we've shared are just where we are right now. Anytime we grow capacity at a sizable rate, we're always looking to book ahead of the booking curve last year, sort of get out in front of it, get as much leisure traffic as we can. We don't see the same sort of elasticity for the close in traffic. It's more stable. We know that it's not going to grow at the same rate that capacity does, so we totally anticipate that those early load factor gaps would decline towards sort of flattish performance year-over-year. And that's typically what our goal is, is to keep sort of flat load factor performance year-over-year. Sometimes we hit it. We often do. Sometimes, we're a little bit shy of it.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from David Fintzen with Barclays.
componenttext: Your next question comes from David Fintzen with Barclays.

componenttextpreview: Question on that sort of third of your volume that's corporate, particularly technology travel. I would think you guys are sort of overweight technology travel versus the industry. I'm just curious, are you getting any sense of fear or concern that maybe

componenttext: David, this is Joe again. Nothing too specific there. I've already sort of covered our exposure on energy stuff, it's largely tied to the State of Alaska, so you've got the background on that. Certainly here in Seattle where we have far and away our greatest utility for corporate travelers, we have the benefit of a lot of technology companies here in Seattle, and they are traveling a lot. They're doing quite well, and we're seeing good strength on that front.

componenttext: Yes. So Dan, I'll just tell you that we don't have an exact number. What we know is that high-quality industrials do have more leverage than we do. They're in the 40% to 45% range. As you know, we're down at 27. So we don't have a target. We know that we've got some room to grow there, and we will be borrowing in the next couple of years.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I see. And then, Andrew, I appreciate the commentary around competitive capacity. But as I look at the schedules data, it doesn't look like Delta's impacting any new revenue streams sequentially in the first quarter. So as I look at the DOT data here, I b
componenttext: I see. And then, Andrew, I appreciate the commentary around competitive capacity. But as I look at the schedules data, it doesn't look like Delta's impacting any new revenue streams sequentially in the first quarter. So as I look at the DOT data here, I believe Delta impacted about 69% of Alaska's local revenue at Seattle in the fourth quarter. And that same 69% that's really affected in the first quarter. So -- and if we move to second quarter, it looks like it might tick up to 71%. So if we're trying to really isolate the incremental revenue headwinds from Delta, it seems like the damage has mostly been done. But first, is my analysis close or correct? And then secondly, what do we really need to keep in mind because the competitive growth -- the growth in competitive capacity sounds a lot worse than what it might actually be as I look at the underlying data.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dan, your analysis is spot on. Essentially really for the first 3 quarters, it was 100% associated with 1 carrier. But as we move forward, you have some Southwest and some ULCCs. And the other thing that we're seeing a little bit, too, is that the big net
componenttext: Dan, your analysis is spot on. Essentially really for the first 3 quarters, it was 100% associated with 1 carrier. But as we move forward, you have some Southwest and some ULCCs. And the other thing that we're seeing a little bit, too, is that the big network guys are being added to their hubs, which we fly to many of the hubs. So that's the other piece that's replacing the decline in Delta's impact.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Savi, it's Ben. I think the first thing to do between Andrew's group and mine, we just work really closely in Seattle, and what we do we is we just model every time of day not only our schedule but all the other airlines schedule. And we map out by our --
componenttext: Savi, it's Ben. I think the first thing to do between Andrew's group and mine, we just work really closely in Seattle, and what we do we is we just model every time of day not only our schedule but all the other airlines schedule. And we map out by our -- by 15-minute increments how we can best manage the schedule. And if we move things around by 10 minutes or so, that's kind of how we do it. So we have all the departures, all the arrivals. We model it out and then we figure out the best schedule to fit -- to optimize our network.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Sean, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I'd like welcome everyone to the Alaska Air Group First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded and will be accessible for future play
componenttext:
Good morning. My name is Sean, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I'd like welcome everyone to the Alaska Air Group First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded and will be accessible for future playback at www.alaskaair.com. [Operator Instructions] 
I would now like to turn the call over to Alaska Air Group's Managing Director of Investor Relations, Lavanya Sareen.  Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Sean. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us for Alaska Air Group's First Quarter 2016 Earnings Call.On the call today, our CEO, Brad Tilden, will provide an overview of the business. Our Chief Commercial Officer, Andrew Harrison,
componenttext:
Thanks, Sean. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us for Alaska Air Group's First Quarter 2016 Earnings Call.
On the call today, our CEO, Brad Tilden, will provide an overview of the business. Our Chief Commercial Officer, Andrew Harrison, will share the revenue results for the quarter, followed by Brandon Pedersen, our CFO, who will provide the capital allocation plans and outlook for 2016.
Several members of our senior management team are also on hand to help answer your questions.
As a reminder, our comments today will include forward-looking statements regarding our future expectations, which may differ significantly from actual results. Information on risk factors that could affect our business can be found in our SEC filings.
We will refer to certain non-GAAP financial measures such as adjusted earnings and unit costs, excluding fuel. We have provided a reconciliation between the most directly comparable GAAP and non-GAAP measures in our earnings release.
In addition, today's call may be deemed a solicitation in respect of Alaska Air Group's contemplated acquisition of Virgin America. The information discussed today is qualified in its entirety by the proxy statement that Virgin America will be filing in the future, and that will be available on Virgin America's Investor Relations page at ir.virginamerica.com. 
All right, with that lengthy disclosure done, let's look at results. This morning Alaska Air Group reported a first quarter GAAP net profit of $184 million. Excluding the small impact of mark-to-market adjustments related to our fuel hedge portfolio, Air Group reported a record adjusted net income of $183 million. That's up 23%.
Earnings per share grew by 29.5% to $1.45 per share. A higher growth rate in EPS is driven by over 7.3 million shares that we have repurchased during the last 12 months. Additional information about cost expectations, capacity plans, fuel hedging capital expenditures and other items can be found in our investor update included in our Form 8-K issued this morning and available on our website at alaskaair.com.
And now, I'll turn the call over to Brad

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Lavanya, and good morning, everyone. Before I jump into the results for this quarter, I want to talk for a minute about our proposed acquisition of Virgin America. Virgin America and Alaska share similar philosophies about building alignment with
componenttext:
Thanks, Lavanya, and good morning, everyone. Before I jump into the results for this quarter, I want to talk for a minute about our proposed acquisition of Virgin America. Virgin America and Alaska share similar philosophies about building alignment with and taking care of our people and about putting customers first. Both of us run strong operations, we're both recognized for our terrific customer service, we both have a great onboard product, and we're 2 of the youngest and fuel-efficient planes in the industry. We're excited about bringing together 2 great airlines to create an airline that will have a national footprint and one that we believe will be the premier airline for people who live anywhere along the West Coast. The next steps on the process involves a vote by Virgin America shareholders sometime in the second quarter and a review by the Department of Justice. We believe this competition strengthens our 2 airlines and enhances competition from the innovative and low-fare segment of the market. So we are hoping for swift clearance to close, which could be in 60 days or less. Even if the DOJ decides that the deal warrants a closer look, we hope to have clearance well before the end of the year.
In the meantime, we remain focused on execution and integration planning. On that front, I want to share that Ben Minicucci, our Chief Operating Officer will be leading the charge on integration. He understands operations very well. And while he drives hard for results, he cares a lot about people, and that is the real key to success. We are all fully invested in this, but we are also very excited to see Ben do great things with his responsibility.
We're working hard to lay out the groundwork for swift integration, and part of that is making sure our stand-alone business is humming along nicely. So let's talk about the business that our team of 15,000 people is running today. Lavanya just shared the numbers, and it's evidence that we're performing well financially. But it's also important to note that industry as a whole is a lot healthier and producing strong results. What I'm really proud of is that our team is continuously moving the ball forward. We're off to a strong start in 2016 on almost every front.
Let's start with the operations. Our people continue to do a great job of running a good operation. 87.5% of our mainline flights arrived on time in the quarter, and that's up 2.5 points from 2015, and I think Horizon's on-time performance -- on-time performance will be even higher than that. And our completion rate was 99.3%. We expect that both our mainline on-time performance and our completion rate will lead the 8 largest the domestic airlines.
Now let's talk about customer service, which we believe is what really differentiates airlines. Our people are taking great care of our customers in providing them experience that is unique in this industry. Our customer's satisfaction rating of 86.3% is a new record for the first quarter and reflects the time and effort spent by our team last year conducting customer service workshops, which we call Beyond Service. Our customers are rewarding us with their loyalty and voting with their wallets literally by signing up to the Alaska Airlines credit card. Both programs continue to grow at unprecedented rates and is providing us loyal customers, which make our network growth more successful and more profitable. Andrew will talk more about this in a moment.
Our growth is providing greater options to our customers and generating strong returns for our owners. Our network team does a great job of identifying demand and then matching that demand with the right amount of capacity or supply. Sometimes, this means getting out of routes the don't meet return targets like L.A. to Vancouver. Sometimes, this means making refinements -- making small refinements to the schedule, and sometimes it means tapping into new opportunities.
We've added 41 new markets over the last 2 years, and 5 of them came in the most recent quarter. 41 markets in the aggregate are not only profitable but are producing fully allocated returns that are meaningful to our overall business and well above our cost of capital. What's more remarkable is that the 5 markets added in the last quarter are already profitable, and 3 of them are producing returns that are higher than our cost of capital. So our strategy is working. Our folks are running a strong operation and taking care of customers on board and on the ground. And we're deploying capacity in markets where we enjoy strong customer loyalty and our assets of producing returns that exceed our cost of capital. And these returns are reflected in the numbers that you saw this morning.
Now let's look at those numbers. Our net income for the quarter was $183 million, which was 23% higher than 2015. When we factor in the 7.3 million shares we bought back over the last 12 months, our earnings per share of $1.45 increased 29.5%. We expect this EPS growth to lead all but 36 companies in the S&P 500. In fact, our strong EPS growth stands in contrast to the average company in the S&P 500 where earnings are expected to shrink by 3.5%.
Our pretax margin grew by 260 basis points to 21.5%, bringing our trailing 12-month pretax margin to 24.5%. We expect this to be one of the best margins in the industry, and we also expect it to lead about 80% of the companies in the S&P 500.
And finally, our ROIC for the trailing 12 months of 25.6% is more than 3x our cost of capital and substantially higher than high-quality industrials in the S&P 500.
As we look forward, our 15,000 employees are operating safely and are taking care of our customers and each other. Our core business is strong, and we're seeing robust demand for our product. And as a result, our business is producing the sort of returns they should expect from high-quality industrials.
I want to thank everybody here. Our very talented and dedicated frontline employees as well as a terrific leadership team, all of whom are working very hard to produce these strong results and just as importantly, to position us to continue to do so in the future.
With that, I'll turn the call over to Andrew

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thinks Brad, and good morning, everyone. Our first quarter revenue performance was solid, especially when compared to the industry. We grew revenues by $78 million or 6.1%, while industry revenues declined 1%. We're able to achieve these revenue results i
componenttext:
Thinks Brad, and good morning, everyone. Our first quarter revenue performance was solid, especially when compared to the industry. We grew revenues by $78 million or 6.1%, while industry revenues declined 1%. We're able to achieve these revenue results in the face of 13% competitive capacity [indiscernible].
Our load factors remain high while growing our own capacity at 12.9%. Despite expanding capacity over 2x the industry, our RASM decline of 6.1% was within 50 basis points of the industry. Our growth is enabling us to continue to offer our customers more destinations, grow our revenues and most importantly, grow a diverse and stable earnings stream. Our strong business performance is a result of a number of key drivers.
First, adding new markets is giving our customers more nonstop choices as well as providing greater options for connecting passengers. In the last 12 months, we've added 23 new markets to our network. In retail power lines, we're putting new products on the shelf, and they're selling.
Second, we have new regional jets that enable us to provide customers with nonstop service to destinations they previously could only access via 1 or 2 stops seven of our 23 markets launched in the past 12 months were only made available through the introduction of the Embraer 175. This aircraft delivers the trip costs and range to ensure long end markets can be served profitably. We're excited about the possibility of this aircraft, and Brandon will share a little more about our delivery stream in just a minute.
Third, our cost have come down approximately 1% for the 12-month period ending March 2016. While we expect industry costs have risen by about 3%. That's a net gap of 4 points in just 1 year. Our low costs are a sustainable advantage, allowing us to offer low fares and enabling our growth.
Fourth, the combination of a reliable operation, customer-friendly service, growing destinations and low fares is helping us continue to grow our loyalty customer base. Our loyalty program gives members access to over 950 destinations worldwide. We grew our active membership another 12% on the heels of 15.5% [ph] growth in 2015. Our base of loyalty members is actually 30% larger today than it was 2 years ago. This is remarkable for a mature program, especially in the face of vigorous competition.
And then lastly with respect to the credit card accounts, they're up over 12% for the quarter. That's the highest growth since 2010. In addition, the revised economics of our new us credit card agreement is helping our revenue performance. For the first quarter, we are tracking ahead of plan and on track to achieve our annual run rate of $60 million.
We expect our growth in card members to remain strong because come June 1, we'll be able to go to market with new cardholder products we negotiated with our new agreement. That includes a 30,000 bonus miles on approval. That's an increase of 20% from today and a free bag. In addition, new and existing members will no longer incur international transaction fees. We believe that this is the best airline credit card offering in the market bar none.
As we shift our focus to the second quarter, I want to highlight a few data points around capacity and demand. Let's start with capacity. Alaska's capacity will be up approximately 11% in the second quarter. Almost half of that growth is driven by new markets we launched over the last year, and about 1/3 is driven by the increase in [indiscernible]. Said another way, ASM growth from core departures will only contribution 2%, which we believe is in line with the strength of the economy in the markets we serve. We expect capacity growth in the second half of 2016 to slow down to 5.5% to 6.5%, which puts our expectation for the full year capacity growth at 8%.
Moving to competitive outlook. We expect competitive capacity to remain elevated through the summer, up 14% for Q2 and Q3. This is 1 point higher than competitive capacity in the first quarter. Also, as a reminder, the shift of the Easter holiday to March is expected to reduce April PRASM by about a point.
As we look ahead to the rest of 2016, we will continue to grow our revenue base and deliver strong results. And here's why. First, over 90% of our capacity is deployed in domestic markets. Nearly all U.S. point-of-sale and demand continues to remain solid. Secondly, you might recall that 18 of the 21 new markets added last year started in the last 6 months of 2015. So as we move through this year, the percentage of our capacity end markets that have operated less than 12 months drops from 5.5% in the first half of this year to 2.5% in the second half of 2016. Third, we expect to introduce premium class in September with 75 aircraft in service by year end. This will help with both revenue and loyalty growth. While the contribution in 2016 is marginal, we expect premium class add about $85 million in annual profit by 2018.
So in summary, we're running a solid operation, taking great care of our customers. The first quarter saw us adding new aircraft, cities, customers, loyalty members, revenue and profit, all against the backdrop of an industry that shrank revenue this quarter.
And with that, I'll turn the call over to Brandon.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Andrew, and hey, everyone. As you heard Air Group's adjusted net profit improved by 23%, and EPS grew by 29% to $1.45 a share. Our trailing 12-month ROIC of 25.6% was 550 basis points higher than at the end of this point last year.On an adjusted
componenttext:
Thanks, Andrew, and hey, everyone. As you heard Air Group's adjusted net profit improved by 23%, and EPS grew by 29% to $1.45 a share. Our trailing 12-month ROIC of 25.6% was 550 basis points higher than at the end of this point last year.
On an adjusted pretax basis, we earned $290 million, a $50 million or 21% increase over prior year. Revenues grew by $78 million. Yield costs declined by $66 million, and those gains were offset by a $94 million increase in nonfuel costs. This is the seventh consecutive year of profitability in the seasonally weak first quarter, and profit has increased steadily for each of those 7 years.
Consolidated nonfuel unit costs were down 1.2%. Our leaders are doing a good job managing the virtual cost of budget and hitting productivity metrics. For example, our broadest measure of productivity passengers per FTE, is tracking at 1.8% better than plan on mainline. Our flights ops group is spot on their hard plan, and our maintenance division productive is tracking ahead of plan, just to name a few. Our people understand how high productivity is an important source of our cost advantage.
For the second quarter, we forecast unit costs ex fuel to be down 1%. And for the full year, we now expect ex fuel cost to decline by 0.5%. There are 3 main drivers from the change from our initial full year guidance.
First, we have changed our performance base pay or PBP plan to increase the participation level for our supervisors and our managers. These are incredibly important roles, and our board wanted to have their PBP participation better reflect their level of responsibility. PBP has been and continues to be a very strong driver of engagement among our employees.
Next, third party regional expense was understated in our initial guidance. The new guidance now properly reflects the increase in SkyWest CPA flying costs through the year. And finally, new minimum wage requirements in certain markets are having a greater impact than we initially modeled. In addition, our results in Q1 and, thus, our full year forecast includes some costs associated with our Virgin America deal.
Going forward, we will be excluding deal and integration costs from our guidance since the timing and amount of these costs are variable. We'll also begin excluding them from our adjusted results.
Even with the revised cost guidance, 2016 will be the 14th year out of the last 15 for mainline cost reduction and the seventh year in a row for Air Group. As a result, our cost advantage over the legacy carriers will further widen in this year.
Turning to fuel. Our economic fuel cost per gallon was $1.29, down from $1.98 in Q1 of last year, which contributed to the $66 million decline in economic fuel expense. Our fuel burn on an ASM per gallon basis improved by another 1.8% since Q1 last year and will just continue to get better as we work through the retirement of the 737-400 classics by the end of 2017 and replace them with 737-900ERs, which are 25% more fuel efficient.
Our cash flow from operations was $527 million, and we ended the quarter with nearly $1.6 billion in cash. Even after adjusting for leases, we're in a net cash position of almost $600 million. Our debt to cap including leases now stands at 26%. Our net cash position, the 95 unencumbered aircraft in our fleet, our investment-grade balance sheet and our long track record of conservative financial management processes in a strong position to raise the capital necessary to fund the proposed acquisition of Virgin America. Our treasury team is hard art work with potential lenders. Initial results are very encouraging in terms of the number of and diversity of lenders that want to work with us.
Andrew mentioned the order for E175s. We're excited to have this jet for the Horizon fleet and the profit opportunity that it opens up in new markets. We're impressed with Embraer's commitment to working by our side as the Horizon team incorporates the E175 efficiently into our operation. We currently have 7 SkyWest E175s operating in our network and expect to have 15 by the end of the year. Horizon will start taking delivery of the E175 in 2017. The Q400 will continue to fly our shorter routes, and Bombardier will remain an important business partner of ours.
In the mainline operation, we took delivery of 6 737-900ERs in the first quarter and will take another 13 by year-end. 
On an Air Group stand-alone basis, we're currently expecting CapEx to be approximately $750 million this year, which includes $685 million of CapEx associated with firm orders and $70 million of CapEx for Boeing 737 options that we are likely to exercise. We've produced over $400 million of free cash flow in the first quarter of 2016 alone, further strengthening our balance sheet while allowing us to continue to return capital to our owners. Through yesterday, we've repurchased a total of 2.1 million shares for $161 million or 1.7% of the shares outstanding as of the beginning of the year. We also paid $34 million in dividends so far this year.
As we announced on April 4, the slow share repurchases in order to help fund the acquisition, we expect total share repurchases for 2016 to be between $190 million and $200 million. So when combined with our dividend, which will continue and is currently yielding 1.4%, we expect total return to shareholders to be about $325 million this year.
We're off to a great start in 2016, but we have much work ahead as we get integration. Although there's a lot going on, we're mindful the we need to remain focused in the core business. We're going to maintain the same level of discipline and budget rigor, so that we hit our operational and financial results. I'm super focused on the risk that we lose a bit of budget disciplined with integration work, and we're setting up controls that ensure that, that does not happen.
I want to thank everyone involved in the integration in advance for the huge effort that they're about to undertake to combine Alaska and Virgin America into the premier airline for people on the West Coast.
And with that, let's get to questions.

I'm wondering if you could provide a little bit more color [indiscernible] in the next couple of years on CapEx and the likelihood of those options? And then also maybe on the funding side. I know there's $2 billion related to the acquisition. Are you planning to raise any more debt beyond that? And with the E175, any chance of the sale leaseback or is that step financing?

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Brandon. Maybe I'll start with the first, and Mark can take the second. In terms of CapEx, specifically for 2017, if you look at our old guidance on the firm, it was about $620 million. Our new guidance on firm is $925 million. That changes about $30
componenttext: It's Brandon. Maybe I'll start with the first, and Mark can take the second. In terms of CapEx, specifically for 2017, if you look at our old guidance on the firm, it was about $620 million. Our new guidance on firm is $925 million. That changes about $300 million. Nearly all of that is related to the E175 purchase. So if you just look at those 30 firms, kind of the way it staggers out is $40 million in 2016, $280 million in 2017 and roughly $250 million in 2018 and 2019. So the big increase in CapEx is simply related to the regional jet order that we placed.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Savi, this is Mark. On the financing side, we are going to raise the $2 billion as we talked about a couple of weeks ago, and that process is going very well. We're getting strong demand. We've got exceptional collateral, and it's a rare opportunit
componenttext: Great. Savi, this is Mark. On the financing side, we are going to raise the $2 billion as we talked about a couple of weeks ago, and that process is going very well. We're getting strong demand. We've got exceptional collateral, and it's a rare opportunity really for a lot of these lenders to work with Alaska because, as you know, we haven't been borrowing over the last 6 or 7 years. Going forward, we're going to manage the leverage in that 40% to 50% range and borrow for some aircraft and pay cash for some aircraft.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: Very helpful. And just for the second question on the State of Alaska, I know there's been some concerns with the budgetary cuts there and the kind of oil and gas sector that there might be some demand impact. Can you talk about what you seeing there and how that's impacted demand?

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Savi, this is Joe. If I screw something, Andrew can correct me on the demand, but I don't see raising anything appreciable up or down with respect to demand in the State of Alaska. We're heading into the summer months, and they are expecting a record summ
componenttext: Savi, this is Joe. If I screw something, Andrew can correct me on the demand, but I don't see raising anything appreciable up or down with respect to demand in the State of Alaska. We're heading into the summer months, and they are expecting a record summer for tourism. So I think our numbers over the next few months are likely to be quite strong, but with respect to the oil and gas traffic, there's still a fair bit of exploration activity happening on the north slope, and I think things have been more or less steady.

componenttext: Rajeev, it's Andrew. From our perspective, the competitive capacity hasn't materially changed as it relates to the ULCCs in both Portland and Seattle about 8 [indiscernible] a day. If you look at our competitive capacity numbers, which we've been dealing with double-digit numbers since the fourth quarter of 2015, over 70% of that is actually from the big network carriers. So again, we remain vigilant as it relates to competition, but there's been no material changes for us since last time we spoke.

componenttext: Yes, Rajeev, yes. In Vegas and L.A., it's a little hard to say it's all the ULCCs because there's been a lot of capacities from others coming into this markets. There's full flights. Is that right? Or is there some sort of one-off numbers I'm missing?

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: Robert, this is David Campbell. What you're seeing there is the restructuring cost from our commitment to compete. Our exercise [indiscernible] $7 million worth of costs from severance pay form the reduction enforced as well as the signing bonuses. That's the bulk of the shift that you're seeing operationally. The revenue, I think, is still very solid there. We were down a little bit in terms of capacity for the first 2 months of the year. We actually pulled down 2 lines of flight just to make sure we have been focused on taking care of our customers.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And my second question is -- and this is to Mark. Mark, when you mentioned the $2 billion of financing and there was a positive response in the market, you talked about -- you mentioned exceptional collateral. Is the $2 billion financing that
componenttext: Okay, great. And my second question is -- and this is to Mark. Mark, when you mentioned the $2 billion of financing and there was a positive response in the market, you talked about -- you mentioned exceptional collateral. Is the $2 billion financing that's being used for the Virgin deal, is that all secured? Or are you going to look to do a mix of secured and unsecured? What's going on there?

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Mike, that's a great question. I would say it will be all secured. We are able to do unsecured. We just like the pricing frankly better on the secured borrowing. The 737-800 and 900s that we have are very new. We have over 70 of those really desirabl
componenttext: Yes, Mike, that's a great question. I would say it will be all secured. We are able to do unsecured. We just like the pricing frankly better on the secured borrowing. The 737-800 and 900s that we have are very new. We have over 70 of those really desirable aircraft that are unencumbered, and it's just a sort source of borrowing.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I've addressed this question several times, so we'll be doing some unsecured and the pricing does look attractive, but it's just not good enough to take you there instead of 2 [ph] secured financing.
componenttext: And I've addressed this question several times, so we'll be doing some unsecured and the pricing does look attractive, but it's just not good enough to take you there instead of 2 [ph] secured financing.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And we will be an unsecured borrower at some point. Just for this transaction, it made sense to use that collateral we have.
componenttext: Yes. And we will be an unsecured borrower at some point. Just for this transaction, it made sense to use that collateral we have.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: Okay, great. Is that just all -- is that aircraft assets? Or would you consider -- I mean, I know you do have some slots like airports like Reagan National. I'm sure you also have probably some hard assets maybe you could potentially pledge. Is that that -- or is that 100% aircraft.

componenttext: This will be 100% aircraft. We do have a lot of assets, but the aircraft is what will get us the lowest rate frankly.

componenttext: Andrew, as we look at your own growth slowing and your competitive capacity growth, I don't know maybe slowing a little bit in the fourth quarter, is there a scenario where Alaska actually starts outperforming the industry on RASM again in the second half or towards the end of the year in sort of an [indiscernible] environment. And let me give you an out if you don't want to answer it that way. Is there a scenario where maybe the improvement in the rate of change in PRASM actually moves faster than your capacity decelerates for whatever reason as you move through the year?

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you for testing my intellectual ability here, Hunter. What I can tell you is that when we look at this, we do still believe that really the pricing environment is somewhat connected to the price of fuel today. As you know, we don't give guidance tha
componenttext: Thank you for testing my intellectual ability here, Hunter. What I can tell you is that when we look at this, we do still believe that really the pricing environment is somewhat connected to the price of fuel today. As you know, we don't give guidance that far out. But what I will tell you though is that our book load factors are based flat in March, they will be flat in April, and they'll be flat in May. So we've been seeing good solid demand as we come into the peak season for us.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. All right. that's cool. I only have 2 questions, so I'm going to ask sort of a loaded one. Could you talk to membership line of attack consideration at a higher level? Are you going to using consultants and some targets maybe that you're not going
componenttext: Got it. All right. that's cool. I only have 2 questions, so I'm going to ask sort of a loaded one. Could you talk to membership line of attack consideration at a higher level? Are you going to using consultants and some targets maybe that you're not going to see underneath the surface? And as you ramp up the integration process, are you going to be more inclined to maybe slow organic growth a little bit? And then also a separate question for Brad, can you talk to us about how the meetings went with the DOJ?

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll get Ben to answer the first one, and I can't talk to you because I wasn't in them, but we'll get Kyle Levine and see what he can say about the DOJ meetings.
componenttext: We'll get Ben to answer the first one, and I can't talk to you because I wasn't in them, but we'll get Kyle Levine and see what he can say about the DOJ meetings.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Ben. Yes, I'm really excited so far have about how we began this integration process. We're -- at this point, we've created the structure of which how we're going to attack the integration. We're starting to fill the structure with strong team member
componenttext: It's Ben. Yes, I'm really excited so far have about how we began this integration process. We're -- at this point, we've created the structure of which how we're going to attack the integration. We're starting to fill the structure with strong team members. I've been down to San Francisco 6 times. I met with their folks. So we've got a lot of strong momentum. I will tell you that we are focused on, and we're going to be disciplined in achieving the revenue and cost synergies that we identified through our due diligence. And you know a little bit about us, little bit about me, we're going to be extreme with disciplined with metrics and scorecards as we drive this thing through, but we're going to be also very sensitive to the cultural and the brand that we have to bring together as well. So I'm extremely positive and optimistic we're going to do this well, and our goal is to do this hopefully in a way that people can look back and say, "This is  one of the best integrations that's been executed in a long time."

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hunter, this is Kyle. So as you know, the regulatory review situation is just getting started. But I will tell you so far so good. I'm not going to presume to say what the DOJ is going -- how they're going to view it or what timing they're going to impose
componenttext: Hunter, this is Kyle. So as you know, the regulatory review situation is just getting started. But I will tell you so far so good. I'm not going to presume to say what the DOJ is going -- how they're going to view it or what timing they're going to impose. But I'll tell you we're answering your questions and we're working really hard to show them when you think this is such a good combination for consumers and competition. And we are hoping, conservatively, that we're going to have closing before the end of the year.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Brandon. Just I'll add one more thing. You asked about our use of consultants. Yes, we are going to be using consultants. But one of the controls that I talk about in my prepared remarks is how much we're going to some consultants? We're going to tak
componenttext: It's Brandon. Just I'll add one more thing. You asked about our use of consultants. Yes, we are going to be using consultants. But one of the controls that I talk about in my prepared remarks is how much we're going to some consultants? We're going to take a very tight lid on that. Price matters a lot. We're going to build the talent internally and take ownership internally. And so while there will be consultants, the budget for consultants is going to be tightly controlled.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Helane Becker with Cowen & Company.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Helane Becker with Cowen & Company.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: One of the things that we are seeing a lot up here in the East Coast and we're seeing it in Seattle really is increased security lines. I mean, people having to wait more than maybe 20 minutes up to an hour sometimes, and I'm just kind of wondering how yo
componenttext: One of the things that we are seeing a lot up here in the East Coast and we're seeing it in Seattle really is increased security lines. I mean, people having to wait more than maybe 20 minutes up to an hour sometimes, and I'm just kind of wondering how you guys are thinking about handling that as you go into the busy summer months. Because Sea-Tac is pretty close to full capacity at this point, and you got a lot of people wanted to fly and yet you don't really have the staffing that you need. The PSA actually doesn't have the staffing you need to process all these customers. How are you thinking about that this summer?

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Ben. We actually met with the TSA administrator, and we had a really positive meeting. I came away feeling a lot more optimistic than I went into it. They are on top of the problem. They understand the staffing issues, they're looking at technology.
componenttext: It's Ben. We actually met with the TSA administrator, and we had a really positive meeting. I came away feeling a lot more optimistic than I went into it. They are on top of the problem. They understand the staffing issues, they're looking at technology. They're looking at dogs, adding more dogs, which actually accelerates the screening process. What I will say from a month ago to now, we have seen improvements in Seattle, and I'm actually -- we're actually going to use also third-party vendors in certain parts of the screening process to help TSA move their staffing where it's critical. So we're looking at all our key airports and working hand-in-hand with the TSA. This is not just not a TSA problem. This is everyone's problem. And I'm actually more optimistic than I was going into the summer. They know it's a big issue, and they're focused on it.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: Okay. Is that going to cost you more money?

componenttext: There will be some costs. Not -- I don't think it's going to be material, just to help with some screening, identification -- personal identification prior to entering the screening process.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Brandon, I just have a question about interest expense. It was $13 million in the quarter, up from $11 million yet your went down a little bit. So why did that extra $2 million occur? And can you also say what the credit card contributed in the firs
componenttext: Okay. Brandon, I just have a question about interest expense. It was $13 million in the quarter, up from $11 million yet your went down a little bit. So why did that extra $2 million occur? And can you also say what the credit card contributed in the first quarter?

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Helane, go ahead. Chris is going to take that.
componenttext: Helane, go ahead. Chris is going to take that.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Chris. On the interest expense line item, one of the things that happened you might recall at the end of the year last year, we had -- this Proposition 1 here in Seattle, we had to accrue some back wages associated with that. There's some statutor
componenttext: This is Chris. On the interest expense line item, one of the things that happened you might recall at the end of the year last year, we had -- this Proposition 1 here in Seattle, we had to accrue some back wages associated with that. There's some statutory interests on these back wages that we've recorded in the first quarter. So that's why the interest is up even though debt is down. So that's related to that. And then the credit card, really the Mileage Plan overall sort of on the other line item really was up about $25 million, $30 million for the quarter. So that was kind of the contribution there. And a lot of that was driven by again the new credit card deal that we had in the new economics on that deal started in January and then just the volume. And as Andrew mentioned in his remarks, credit cardholders are up 12%. So that really drove volume and the number of miles we sold to the Affinity card partner. So overall, it's really good economics, really good results for the quarter on that.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jamie Baker with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jamie Baker with JPMorgan.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: As you know, I happened to be in the Bay Area when the deal was announced. And I must say as a New Yorker, I grossly underestimated just how strong of a cultlike following Virgin has built out there. And I don't ordinarily allowing my earnings model to be
componenttext: As you know, I happened to be in the Bay Area when the deal was announced. And I must say as a New Yorker, I grossly underestimated just how strong of a cultlike following Virgin has built out there. And I don't ordinarily allowing my earnings model to be influenced by passenger preference and stuff like that, but I'm thinking I might have to make an exception this time. I know it's only been 2.5 weeks, but does your analysis still assume that you retain 100% of the Virgin loyalists? It really seems to me that you might be -- you might want to be modeling for some spill there.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jamie, it's Brad. Maybe Andrew wants to pop in. I think its really good question. We were attracted to Virgin because they have built an incredible company. In 9 years, you're right, there is a very, very strong allegiance to that company. The employees f
componenttext: Jamie, it's Brad. Maybe Andrew wants to pop in. I think its really good question. We were attracted to Virgin because they have built an incredible company. In 9 years, you're right, there is a very, very strong allegiance to that company. The employees feel tremendous amount of passion for the company and the customers do. And that's -- I'll just say why the company so attractive to us because of the biggest challenge right thing for this leadership team isn't -- we're going to have all kinds of challenges, bringing the together, doing it safely, integrating collective bargaining agreements come lists and all that, the biggest challenge are going to be bringing the customers together, and that's what we're focused on. And that's why we talked a lot about the brand. We're going to go into this with approach. We're going to do both products, the tangible product features, and we're going to look at Virgin's approach, look at Alaska's approach and over 12 or 18 months, make a decision about what's best for our collective customers. As we look at the brand, we're going to think about the brand and do what's best. But our goal -- I guess, what I just wanted to reassure you we are aware of the value that, that company has brought to its customers, and our goal isn't to lose that. Our goal is to gain that as a foothold in the State of California as something that we grow in the decade or 2 I had. In terms of specific modeling, I haven't done any specific modeling on this. Maybe your team has, but I think the long-term idea isn't to lose passengers. It's to grow them substantially over the next [ph] 15 years that they're in front of us.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Have you put any thought into what the cost will be to retrofit your current flying with much of the hard product that makes Virgin so curiously popular to me?
componenttext: Have you put any thought into what the cost will be to retrofit your current flying with much of the hard product that makes Virgin so curiously popular to me?

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: There's a lot to be done there. We are really just starting that now, Jamie. We are starting to look at the service out of San Francisco and L.A. to JFK, in particular. The product offering is different than what we [indiscernible]. But it's -- will be a
componenttext: There's a lot to be done there. We are really just starting that now, Jamie. We are starting to look at the service out of San Francisco and L.A. to JFK, in particular. The product offering is different than what we [indiscernible]. But it's -- will be a complex analysis. There's RASM implications. There's [indiscernible] costs implications. And we're going to try to do this in a way where we are known for innovation, we're known for great service, we're known for low fares and for the analyst community, we're known for making money and making returns. So with that, we got our work cut out for us, but that's what we're going to be thinking about.

componenttext: Okay. componenttext: This is Mark. I'll just start by saying we have a fabulous partnership with Boeing. We have a terrific partnership and really with all the manufacturers we work with. componenttext: As Mark has said, so we couldn't be more appreciative of the relationship we have with Boeing. We get treated an airline that is much bigger than we actually are, and they've been fantastic to us.

componenttext: I'm going to try a crack at Hunter's first question a little differently. So Andrew, you mentioned you've added 23 new markets in the network in the last 12 months. And as new market additions well in the back half of the year and perhaps into '17, when do you expect to see a tailwind to your unit revenues from the market maturation dynamic and how meaningful could that be?

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Julie, I think we're already seeing good tailwinds as we go in and as Brad mentioned in his remarks, I think the bigger issue honestly is where do competitive capacity numbers continue to be over the remainder of the year and then, really, the industry pr
componenttext: Julie, I think we're already seeing good tailwinds as we go in and as Brad mentioned in his remarks, I think the bigger issue honestly is where do competitive capacity numbers continue to be over the remainder of the year and then, really, the industry pricing environment. I think those 2 things are the biggest variables for us. At the end of the day, as we look at the back half of the year, we're entering into very strong demand periods for us. We feel very confident about how we've set up the summer, how we set up our network, so we feel very good about that.

componenttext: No. We'll take a look at that. Honestly, especially with Southwest, they're not all nailed down. So I looked at that, and it's a little bit elevated, but I don't believe it. There's a lot of cleanup and true-up that's going to happen over the next few months for the fourth quarter.
