headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Sally, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Alaska Air Group Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded and will be accessible for fu
componenttext: Good morning. My name is Sally, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Alaska Air Group Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded and will be accessible for future playback at www.alaskaair.com [Operator Instructions] Thank you. I would now like to turn the call over to Alaska Air Group's Managing Director of Investor Relations, Lavanya Sareen.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Sally, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us for Alaska Air Group's second quarter 2016 earnings call. On the call today, our CEO, Brad Tilden, will provide an overview of the business and share our progress on the proposed acquisit
componenttext:
Thanks, Sally, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us for Alaska Air Group's second quarter 2016 earnings call. On the call today, our CEO, Brad Tilden, will provide an overview of the business and share our progress on the proposed acquisition of Virgin America; our Chief Commercial Officer, Andrew Harrison, who will share revenue results for the quarter; followed by Brandon Pedersen, our CFO, who will discuss our financial results, capital allocation plans and outlook for the second half of 2016. Several members of our senior management team are also on hand to help answer your questions.
As a reminder, our comments today will include forward-looking statements regarding our future expectations, which may differ significantly from actual results. Information on risk factors that could affect our business can be found in our SEC filings.
We will refer to certain non-GAAP financial measures such as adjusted earnings and unit costs, excluding fuel. We have provided a reconciliation between the most directly comparable GAAP and non-GAAP measures in our earnings release.
In addition, today's call may be deemed a solicitation in respect of Alaska Air Group's contemplated acquisition of Virgin America. The information discussed today is qualified in its entirety by Virgin America's definitive proxy statement that was filed with the SEC on June 20, [ph] along with other relevant solicitation tables, which are all available on Virgin America's Investor Relations page at ir.virginamerica.com.
And now that I have complied with our GC's request in [indiscernible], we will move to the results. This morning, Alaska Air Group reported a second quarter GAAP net profit of $260 million. Excluding the $6 million impact of mark-to-market adjustments related to our fuel hedge portfolio and a $9 million impact associated with merger-related cost, Air Group recorded a record adjusted net income of $263 million, up 14%. Earnings per share grew by 20% to $2.12 per share. Additional information about cost expectations, capacity plans, fuel hedging, capital expenditures and other items can be found in our Investor Update included in our Form 8-K issued this morning and available on our website at alaskaair.com. Now, I'll turn the call over to Brad.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Lavanya, and good morning, everybody. As we progress through 2016 and look forward to the second half of the year, we know that investors have a lot in their minds and the equity market certainly reflect that. As you know, we try to stay focused a
componenttext:
Thanks, Lavanya, and good morning, everybody. As we progress through 2016 and look forward to the second half of the year, we know that investors have a lot in their minds and the equity market certainly reflect that. As you know, we try to stay focused and concentrated our efforts here on building a fundamentally good business. As we look ahead, we feel very good about our underlying business, and all of us here are very said about the future. The fundament of our business are strong, we're running a great airline, and we believe the merger with Virgin America is going to create a very strong airlines, with reach across the entire country and with real strength in originating traffic up and down the West Coast. 
I'll start up today by talking about the underlying business and then share an update on the merger. First, we are operating safely and on time. Our folks are doing an outstanding job, and I want to thank them. 88.7% of our flights arrived on time in the second quarter, and we did this with much less block time than the average airlines, which is a credit to how efficient and consistent we are in the ground. We expect this on-time performance will lead the 6 largest domestic airlines. We also completed 99.8% of our flights in the second quarter, canceling on average only one mainline flight per day. 
Second, our employees are taking great care of our customers. We spent a lot of time with our frontline employees building alignment and talking with them about the sort of airline we want to be for our customers. We're seeing substantial evidence that these investments are paying off. Our customer satisfaction scores, which have been on the 7 or 8-year run continue to improve. In fact, our score for the second quarter was the highest second quarter score ever. And as you know, we also won our ninth consecutive J.D. Power award for customer service during the quarter. We earned the highest score of any airline included in the survey in each of the 7 areas measured, including a move from fourth place to first place for in-flight service, which reflects investments we've made in food and beverage service, in-flight entertainment, seating, seat power and bins. This award is a fantastic recognition for our employees, and I want to congratulate them and thank them for everything they are doing to make Alaska stand out in the eyes of our customers. 
Our model is based on building preference for our airlines, and we build this preference with on-time operations, fantastic customer service and, of course, low [indiscernible] This model has worked, not only in the last couple of years, but in the last 15 to 20 years. 
Since the first quarter of 2010, we have launched 100 new markets and we've outpaced industry revenue growth by a factor of 3. This in the midst of one of the bigger competitive Anchorage in this industry has seen in years. This growth would have been possible without our mentality of continually reducing cost, which allows us to offer customers low fares, while still maintaining industry-leading margins. Brendan is going to share more detail in a moment on what the compounding effects of cost reductions since 2008 has meant to our financial performance. 
But to give you a sense of how powerful a low-cost structure is, even if we adjust our fuel prices to $2 a gallon, markets representing 97% of our revenue for the last 12 months would still be profitable. And it's important to know that this is done with the full allocation of all cost. 
This model is also delivering returns that are consistently in excess of our cost to capital. In fact, our trailing 12-month ROIC of 25.9% puts us in a top 10% of all S&P 500 companies. Our successful growth showed that providing customers with a high value experience at low fares is a winning formula that, especially in the upper end leisure in business segments or what we call the leisure market. And this is a great platform for our future, combining our network, which has strengthened the Pacific Northwest and Alaska, with Virgin America's strength in California. We will be a very strong airline with strength up-and-down the West Coast and, of course, we will have a national reach. For example, in the future, will have 25 flights a day to New York City from 7 West Coast airports and 10 flights a day to Boston from 5 West Coast airports. 
We also see the increased choice and competition the merger will provide that's fundamentally good for consumers. Speaking of bringing the 2 to come to this together, I want to share a few thoughts around timing and the integration process. First, timing. We have an agreement in place with the Justice Department concerning the timing of their review, and we're forecasting the close will occur in the fourth quarter. When the deal closes, Virgin America will operate as a subsidiary of Alaska Air Group until achieve a single operating certificate, which we expect in the first quarter of 2018. We are committed to making this a very successful integration. 
During the post-close transition period, Ben will be the CEO of Virgin America and in addition to his role as President and CEO of Alaska Airlines. And Peter Hunt, who is currently virgin America's CFO, will be his President, and is responsible for day-to-day operations. Ben and Peter are proven leaders who will do a great job leading Virgin America during this time. The integration management office is up and running and is being led by [indiscernible] While there's a lot of functional work going on behind the scenes, I want to share a brief update with you on the key areas of culture, labor and brand. 
Starting with culture. We know that when mergers don't succeed especially in our industry, often people, or in other words, the culture, is the culprit. This in an area where we're spending a lot of time. Our high level goal is simply to retain the best of Alaska Airlines and the best of Virgin America and position the new combined company to be aligned, to be bold and to grow successfully well into the future. 
Moving to labor, we're meeting with labor leaders and have a positive discussions. We appreciate all the work the labor relations team and our labor leaders are doing to make this a smooth integration, and we are optimistic that the process will go well. 
And finally, I know a lot of you were curious about the brand. And as we said before, the Alaska brands is staying. We're also doing in-depth aftermarket research to better understand the elements of Virgin America's product and brand that customers love most, especially in California, and we expect to have a final decision on the brand in early 2017. 
To summarize, whether we're talking about Alaska as it stands today or the combined company post-merger, we're focused on the same bedrock principles. First, we want to be safe and on-time; second, we want to get the culture right and we want to build alignment with our people; third, we want to protect and grow our customer base; fourth, we want to maintain our low-cost structure and low fares; and finally, we want to consistently generate the level of returns that you expect from high-quality industrial companies. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Andrew.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Brad, and good morning, everyone. Total second quarter revenue increased $57 million or 4%. This contrast with the industry revenue shrinking by about 2%. Over the past 5 years, our revenues are growing 35%, outpacing the industry by 3 to 1. This
componenttext:
Thanks, Brad, and good morning, everyone. Total second quarter revenue increased $57 million or 4%. This contrast with the industry revenue shrinking by about 2%. Over the past 5 years, our revenues are growing 35%, outpacing the industry by 3 to 1. This growth comes with strong return that resemble high-quality companies. 
Our second quarter PRASM was down 7.7%. We are very pleased that although our unti revenue performance was within the 150 basis points in the industry, notwithstanding the fact that we grew capacity by 11% with competitive capacity growing 13%. We're also very pleased to see our load factor at 85%, which was flat for the first time since the first quarter of 2013. That said, closing pricing has been showing weakness for reasons you are already familiar with. 
While we remain mindful of the environment we operate in, the fundamentals of Alaska are sound for several reasons. First, we're offering a high value product to customers at low fares. Our low fares are enabled by low costs and have allowed us to grow profitably. The 100 new markets Brad referenced earlier, in aggregate, our [indiscernible] margins at system average levels and represents approximately 20% of our annual revenues. I am also pleased to announce that we just learned we received approval for 4 additional flights to [indiscernible]. We plan to launch Portland and San Diego [indiscernible] this November and then San Jose and the third Seattle [indiscernible] in March and May, respectively. Secondly, when speaking of operate options our customers, partnerships are key. Earlier in June, we launched new Mileage Plan partnership with the Japan Airlines, making it the third international partner we've added in the last 12 months, Hainan and Iceland there being the other 2. That brings our total partners to 17, and allows us to serve over 950 destinations worldwide. A combination of greater reach and targeted promotion has helped increase the number of our members flying on our international partners by 32%. It is an interesting fact, our international partners, along with American Airlines on a combined basis, account for 34% of all international seats in the U.S. That's more than 81 of the global alliances. We expect the benefits of this offering to our customers to take a step change forward with our acquisition of Virgin America. This acquisition will result in us having a strong presence in the largest international West Coast gateways of Los Angeles and San Francisco. 
And lastly, membership in our Frequent-Flier Program is up 11%, and our credit card portfolio grew by 12%, both outpacing passenger growth in our network. Our loyalty program generated $200 million in cash for the second quarter, that's an increase of 16%. We expect this growth to continue giving our card offering, which includes 30,000 bonus miles, annual companion ticket, free bags, no international transaction fees and the lowest annual fees of 80 comparable airtime card. In addition, Costco, an iconic Pacific Northwest brand was a strong West Coast presence, moved to exclusive acceptance of Visa card at its warehouses last month, which has come as no surprise that our customers also shop at Costco for its great products and prices. We have seen spend on our card increasing diffidently as a result. 
Shifting our focus to the back half of the year. Here are a few things to be mindful of. We expect competitive capacity in our markets to be up 13% in Q3 and 12% in Q4, that's about the same as we face for more than a year and a half now. As others make post summer [indiscernible] to their schedules, competitive capacity has come down by 1 point in the third quarter and by 4 points for the fourth quarter since we last spoke to you in April. 
Moving to Alaska's capacity. It will moderate significantly as we move through the rest of the year. Our capacity will be up about 8% in the third quarter and only 3% in the fourth quarter, which is a significant reduction from the 12% we grew during the first half of the year. Our full year guidance sits at about 8.5%, which includes the New York flight I just mentioned, as well as Cuba. 
In summary, the fundamentals of our delight business are strong. We're growing and diversifying revenues, while continuing to build brand loyalty. We have confidence in our process model to continue to grow profitably and strong returns for our owners. I'm personally excited about speaking with you next quarter as we expect to have closed on Virgin America, which will begin the next chapter of our journey. 
And with that, I'll turn the call over to Brandon.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Andrew, and good morning, everyone. It's a fabulous sunny morning here in Seattle, and it's great to be speaking with you today. As Brad said, Air Group's adjusted net profit improved by 14% to $263 million and earnings per share improved by more
componenttext:
Thanks, Andrew, and good morning, everyone. It's a fabulous sunny morning here in Seattle, and it's great to be speaking with you today. As Brad said, Air Group's adjusted net profit improved by 14% to $263 million and earnings per share improved by more than 20%. Our pretax margin was a strong 28.4% and grew by 260 basis points and should be among the best in the domestic industry. 
Trailing 12 ROIC grew by a nearly 400 basis points to just under 26%. On an adjusted pretax basis, we are in $424 million, an increase of $54 million over the second quarter of last year. As Andrew said, revenues grew by 4% or $57 million, a result that we're happy with considering aggregate revenues across the S&P 500 are projected to shrink by 0.6% in the second quarter. Fuel cost declined by $56 million and nonfuel cost increased by about the same amount. Our unit -- our nonfuel unit costs performance in the quarter was really strong, with unit cost declining by 3.7%. We did see a shift in some of the cost into the back half of the year, so our full year guidance remains unchanged at this point. 
We continue to believe that our model of high productivity and low overhead is a winning combination to keep nonfuel costs in check. Passengers per FTE, our broadest measure of productivity, improved by another 2.7% to $1.99, a new Q2 record for us. And it's working at a division level, too. I want to gave a shout out to our flight ops team, pilots hard time this quarter was better in both budget and prior year. 
We've been shipping away on our costs slowly each year going back to 2009 and, in fact, even back to 2003, and sometimes it helps to go up to 41,000 feet to look at the progress we've made. Recently, our FDA team [indiscernible] that and made a really important observation. If our ex- fuel unit cost had grown in line with the rest of the industry instead of the gradual decline we've seen each year since 2009, our pretax profit this year would be almost $800 million lower. That translates to about $4 a share or more than $4 billion of market cap accurate multiples. So while each individual year of 0.5%  or 1% cost reduction doesn't sound like a lot, the cumulative impact is enormous. 
Looking forward, we'll see the backside of that cost shift and currently expect ex fuel cost to be up about 3% in Q3 and up about 0.5% in Q4, which keeps our full year unit cost declines to about 0.5% in line with prior guidance, as I said. 
Cash flow from operations for the first half of the year was $900 million, and we ended the June quarter with over $1.6 billion of cash on hand. Adjusted for leases, we have a net cash position of approximately $700 million, and our debt to cap is at the 25%. Our balance sheet is in the best shape it's ever been, and it positions us well for our planned merger with Virgin America in the fourth quarter. Our treasury team has now obtains committed financing for the deal. Interest was very strong, we ended up over subscribed, and we were able to partner with a diverse set of leading aviation lenders. I want to thank our lenders for their partnership and support. We're finding that it's an excellent time to raise money, market rates are at historic lows and spreads for investment grade secured loans are tight. Alaska's all-in interest rate will be low. I want to compliment  our treasury and legal teams for doing such a fabulous job in this process. 
Air Group  has built a repetition with both lenders and investors as a conservatively managed company with a strong balance sheet, and that's not going to change. After we complete the transaction, we'll still have about 20 unencumbered Nexgen Boeing 737s, and we're going to redeleveraging the balance sheet. 
And speaking of fleet, we've taken delivery of 12 737-900ER so far this year, and have 7 additional 900ERs coming in the back half of the year. As a reminder, many of these deliveries are replacements for older 737-400s. 
During the quarter, we also exercised 3 options for E175s for deliver in 2017. This is not new capital. Instead, we've chosen to buy them rather than lease them because we prefer the economics of buying. 
We expect total CapEx for the year to be approximately $750 million, consistent with prior guidance. As a result of the 3 E175 auctions I just talked about, our CapEx for 2017 ticks up slightly to just above $1 billion. And again, this is not new capital in our plan. As a reminder, we have 2 big fleet initiatives in process. Four retirement of the 737-300s by the end of 2017, which will be good for reliability, passenger comfort and costs, and introduction of 33 E175s into the Horizon fleet, which will help us grow into it longer, thinner markets, where we believe we have significant opportunity to expand profitably. 
So far this year, we've generated $559 million of free cash flow. We paused on the share repurchase program following the announcement of our planned merger, but continue to pay a meaningful dividend, which is currently yielding about 1.7%. I agree with Andrew. Our business is humming along nicely, and we're taking advantage of the profitable growth opportunities. The resulting strong cash flow and our fortress balance sheet have positioned us well to complete the planned merger and set us set up for long-term success. Everyone around the company is working extra hard as we prepare to combine 2 great airlines, and I want to thank our 15,000 employees for their efforts and congratulate them once again on a record, fabulous quarter. 
And with that, we'd like to open it up to questions.

As you know, we've got real strength at Alaska. We fly to 35 states, 115 cities, but real strength of originating traffic in Alaska, Washington and Oregon. And then Virgin gives us California. So we try to not focus too much of the short term on what's happening with PRASM and more thinking if you think about fundamentally what's going to happen in this industry over 5, 10, 15 years, and all of us are just enormous the excited about what we're going to do bringing these 2 great companies together. So that's where it is.

As you'd expect some of the things they're looking at right now between now and ultimate clearance date, and if that does come, it's that route overlaps, great story there, we have only 7 route overlaps and, of course, they're interested in our fair philosophies. We have -- that's the story that we love to tell as an low fare, high-value airline. So all said and done, we're on track for a Q4 close and that things are going well.

Well, what we've said is first quarter 2017, when we actually have a view point, when we have a perspective on this, we will share it. So sorry cannot give you a better more information, but I just think that might be best for all right now.

In the event that the DOJ does move to block or tries to extract some sort of concessions, do you walk or do you fight?

componenttext: Jamie, it's Kyle again. I guess, I would say, neither. Obviously, I can't speak for the department, but again, we're talking about a pro-consumer situation, where there are 7 overlap routes, non-touching, it's like a contrained airport.

componenttext: Yes, Helane. This is Mark. We won't know the exact rate until we close. What we can say is that margins are very tight. And that's about all the guidance I can give your right now.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016

componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then my other question is on actually on the income statement and the operating expense line. And may be, Brandon, this might be for you. Given that you've turned over the fleet, why is your maintenance -- or started to retire older aircraft, why is the maintenance cost of 25% in the quarter, was there something going on last year that caused this increase to be so substantial this year?

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Helane, this is Chris. I'll answer that one. Last year, as you might recall, in the second quarter of last year, we had some maintenance credits that were related to some engine work we have done in previous periods. So we've got all of those credits that
componenttext: Helane, this is Chris. I'll answer that one. Last year, as you might recall, in the second quarter of last year, we had some maintenance credits that were related to some engine work we have done in previous periods. So we've got all of those credits that recognize last year. That was about $10 million. So when you look at a year-over-year, if you take away that $10 million difference between the 2 period, then [indiscernible] normalized quite a bit. So that's really the big difference.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I get a little frustrated when I hear airlines talking about PRASM as some sort of like short term only metric, as it puts some sorts of like hedge fund only thing that matters and like [indiscernible] don't care about it because it just not true. I wa
componenttext: So I get a little frustrated when I hear airlines talking about PRASM as some sort of like short term only metric, as it puts some sorts of like hedge fund only thing that matters and like [indiscernible] don't care about it because it just not true. I was going to give you a fourth year where PRASM is basically down or flat or something like that for you guys, and that's not sustainable. Ben, you talked about the compounding effect of CASM, does the compounding effect of PRASM, too? So is there a thought to maybe thinking about this as you reevaluate a whole lot of things post-merger, whether it's guidance, conventions or long-term targets to may be making PRASM a long-term metric somehow? And by that, I mean, we're going to have a target of roughly inflationary like growth of PRASM, plus or minus 20 basis points or something like that, because I just I don't know why PRASM has to be so short term oriented, and I feel like you guys might be in a position out to sort of reevaluate things after the merger closes to do something about that?

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Brandon, may be I'll take that. I agree with you. I don't know why there is so much focus on PRASM. What I would do if I were investors as I would focus on profit and I think, as you think about our business going forward, either as the last stand-al
componenttext: It's Brandon, may be I'll take that. I agree with you. I don't know why there is so much focus on PRASM. What I would do if I were investors as I would focus on profit and I think, as you think about our business going forward, either as the last stand-alone or as the combined company. We're going to make profit maximizing decisions, and some of that is going to come from PRASM and some of that is going to come from CASM. I think, the danger in focusing just on PRASM is that you don't know what happens in any particular market, you don't know what happens with fuel prices, and I think, you're seeing a lot of that now but I then day, it's really MASM that matters and profit on the bottom line and the actual cash that goes into your checking account that you can use to delever the balance sheet and payback debt and returning capital to shareholders. So I agree with you...

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Brandon, I'm sorry to interrupt you, but I think you misheard me. I'm saying the exact opposite to be clear. I think PRASM matters a lot because it's a proxy for pricing power. And that's just what would get this group to the rate?
componenttext: Brandon, I'm sorry to interrupt you, but I think you misheard me. I'm saying the exact opposite to be clear. I think PRASM matters a lot because it's a proxy for pricing power. And that's just what would get this group to the rate?

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was going to jump on Brandon's answer as well. So I think you're making a great point, and I thinking Brandon does agree with you. If you look at this industry 15 years ago, people didn't know what CASM was. So when we start talking about CASM, now ever
componenttext: I was going to jump on Brandon's answer as well. So I think you're making a great point, and I thinking Brandon does agree with you. If you look at this industry 15 years ago, people didn't know what CASM was. So when we start talking about CASM, now every airline have 3-year objectives for CASM, 2-year, 1 year, we give really good and I think reliable guidance on CASM. That I would say there's roughly 10 years ago, ROIC came in at a focus, and we started talking about that. I think you're giving us another management [indiscernible] a great challenge. If you were to -- Andrew Harrison and Shane Tackett, if you were to give these guys sort of a longer-term metric to say what are going to do for the revenue side of the business, how would you construct that goal? And the Virgin, it's a -- as we sort of thought about these things, they're hard questions look at, I mean, it's got our head around it. It was hard to start producing CASM objectives. But I personally given as a good challenge, and we should take that away and think about it. We might come away as a stronger airline, and we had a way of of articulating our revenue objectives.

componenttext: This is actually Cathy O'Brian filling in for Mike. And I believe [indiscernible] that corporate was outpacing system revenue. I was just wondering, has that trend continuing to the June quarter? And if so, do you think you've been gaining share because of your relative value proposition versus some of your network carrier competitors?

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Cath, this is Joe Sprague. Short answer is, yes. For the quarter just ended, we did see continuing strength in the corporate sector. In fact, corporate customer activity was up both on flights and revenue. And particularly here in Seattle, really good gro
componenttext: Cath, this is Joe Sprague. Short answer is, yes. For the quarter just ended, we did see continuing strength in the corporate sector. In fact, corporate customer activity was up both on flights and revenue. And particularly here in Seattle, really good growth from companies sort of the key local corporations that we do business with here in the Seattle area. And then just from a sector standpoint, I think some of the underlying strength in addition to us delivering a great product to our customers, our sales team really getting after it, it's the tech sector that we benefit from here on the West Coast is doing especially well right now.

componenttext: Okay. And what about your share? You've seen that go up with some of your other markets?

componenttext: Yes, yes, we have. That share is up across all of our key markets.

componenttext: Maybe I'll start with one for Andrew. Andrew, you have highlighted an outlook for  13% and 12% competitive growth in the next quarters, and you have commented that, that was sort of similar to what you had been saying. But it looks like the mix changes a bit, right, because most of the competitive growth that you guys have been seeing has been from delta, which is -- wer just building interconnected hub over Seattle, whereas the mix seems to be moving away from Delta as we move into the end of the year. So just wondering, is that emphasis on perhaps a little bit more of the local market by the competitor that are going to be growing in Seattle and your other markets in the second half, does that put more pressure on Alaska revenue perhaps than what you have been saying?

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think you're spot on with the mix. And I think, really, the competitive pressure we're seeing a little bit is some of the network carriers with the hubs into Pacific Northwest. And then to a much lesser extent, some of the ULCCs. So it's not -- it's a l
componenttext: I think you're spot on with the mix. And I think, really, the competitive pressure we're seeing a little bit is some of the network carriers with the hubs into Pacific Northwest. And then to a much lesser extent, some of the ULCCs. So it's not -- it's a little bit fragmented across various markets that we compete in. So at then of the day, add competitive capacities,competitive capacity but from our perspective, there's no real changes to the dynamic through our network even if it's changed.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. All right. And then maybe if I could get a quick follow up for Brandon. Brandon, I think, we've seen something like over 75 basis points rushing in. I think your treasury this year. I'm just looking at your 10-K where you disclosed a $128 million im
componenttext: Okay. All right. And then maybe if I could get a quick follow up for Brandon. Brandon, I think, we've seen something like over 75 basis points rushing in. I think your treasury this year. I'm just looking at your 10-K where you disclosed a $128 million impact to the pension deficit with every 50 basis points move in the discount rate. Is that a good number to use on a prospective basis?

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Mark. I can just tell you that rates have gone down. And as we already mentioned, that's really going to help us with the financing as we financed the $2 billion acquisition. So it will impact the liability aspect of our pensions, but it real
componenttext: Yes, this is Mark. I can just tell you that rates have gone down. And as we already mentioned, that's really going to help us with the financing as we financed the $2 billion acquisition. So it will impact the liability aspect of our pensions, but it really is what those rates end up at year-end. We don't know whether  it will be -- they're already going back, I think, that they're already up 20 basis points from where they ended up in the quarter. So not sure where they're going, but it will have an impact on the liability, yes.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016

componenttext: Yes, it would be. And I'll just tell you that on the asset side of the pension, they're growing, and as you know, we're virtually or nearly fully funded at year-end, and we are still remaining about that status. So no big story there for us.

componenttextpreview: Andrew, you talked about weakness in closing yields. And my question is, I think some of it related to an earlier question, but just yet demand is pretty good year. So I'm wondering if you could just elaborate a little bit more on that. Is the weakness in
componenttext: Andrew, you talked about weakness in closing yields. And my question is, I think some of it related to an earlier question, but just yet demand is pretty good year. So I'm wondering if you could just elaborate a little bit more on that. Is the weakness in closing yields just simply a function of competitive capacity? Is it more of a spirit effect? Is it simply Alaska growing little bit too fast to absorb the demand? What really has to happen? Well, I guess you can't really talk about pricing, but just wondering if you just provide a little bit more perspective on what's really been probably the biggest culprit for that from your perspective?

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, kind of a whole a lot more, but probably not hopeful for anyone. I think, fundamentally, what I will share we do is that we've seen and its changes in traditionally [indiscernible] and just revenue management practices close in, and I think there
componenttext: I think, kind of a whole a lot more, but probably not hopeful for anyone. I think, fundamentally, what I will share we do is that we've seen and its changes in traditionally [indiscernible] and just revenue management practices close in, and I think there, in some part, reaction to a changing dynamics of how people are flowing passengers across their network, across the country. It certainly ULCC dynamics in here, and there's certainly new products being launched by some of the network carriers. And I think when you put all of that together, you're getting what you're getting today. And so I don't have a whole lot more insight than that, Dan, but as [indiscernible] said,  we are dealing with that, we are managing it well, we don't put this stuff is close in.We have no Q1 what it would be in 3 months time because by definition of closing we don't know until we're 3 months from now. So I know that's probably only half of an answer of a half, but I apologize, but that's notable what we're seeing, but we're not immune to what the rest of the industry is seeing.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I appreciate that. That was actually -- that was helpful. And then, Brandon, I think, what stood out to me in the earnings release was mainline CASM of $0.0688 [ph] down 4% year-over-year. And obviously, that factors in some deferred expenses in the quart
componenttext: I appreciate that. That was actually -- that was helpful. And then, Brandon, I think, what stood out to me in the earnings release was mainline CASM of $0.0688 [ph] down 4% year-over-year. And obviously, that factors in some deferred expenses in the quarter. Kind of given that just some of our key labor contracts are on the way and just kind of give in your commentary of walk-in your non-field CASM down a little each year, what goal, if any, do you have with wearing that metric lands over the next year or 2?

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's really just to continue to drive it down. We have a long streak of CASM reduction that, I think, this year will be 15 out of the last 16. As we close the acquisition with Virgin America in the fourth quarter, everything sort of resets. But the philos
componenttext: It's really just to continue to drive it down. We have a long streak of CASM reduction that, I think, this year will be 15 out of the last 16. As we close the acquisition with Virgin America in the fourth quarter, everything sort of resets. But the philosophy of the company does not reset, which is continuing to drive cost down. So we can be more competitive, increase the gap between us and the legacy carriers and offer low fares to our customers.

componenttext: Does it rather make sense to talk about the brand in terms of a Net Promoter Score, sort of talking about that's publicly, because just, I think, there is a broad recognition that there is a very high correlation between where that score sits in and revenue protection?

componenttext: Yes, Dan, I don't think we want to say a lot more about the brand, but I think I will say to you that we do like the Net Promoter Score. componenttext: This is Shane. Thanks for the question. Yes, premium [indiscernible] is sort  of the name that we're using [indiscernible] and it is on track. We are still on track to begin configuring aircraft in late September. And so we'll have, I think, 6 of the aircraft down or 7 of the aircraft down by the end of the year. We did push the date that we decided to presell the actual product from the summer to Q4. There's just a lot going on right now, and we wanted to pay attention to the right things and make sure we deliver this really well when we get there in Q4. So all of the economics are going to roll into 2017, but they will be up and running by January and very consistent with what we had shared at Investor Day some months ago.

componenttext:
Good morning. My name is Sally, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Alaska Air Group Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded and will be accessible for future playback at www.alaskaair.com. [Operator Instructions]  
I would now like to turn the call over to Alaska Air Group's Managing Director of Investor Relations, Lavanya Sareen.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Sally, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us for Alaska Air Group's Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. On the call today, our CEO, Brad Tilden, will provide an overview of the business and share our progress on the proposed acquisit
componenttext:
Thanks, Sally, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us for Alaska Air Group's Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. On the call today, our CEO, Brad Tilden, will provide an overview of the business and share our progress on the proposed acquisition of Virgin America; our Chief Commercial Officer, Andrew Harrison, who will share revenue results for the quarter; followed by Brandon Pedersen, our CFO, who will discuss our financial results, capital allocation plans and outlook for the second half of 2016. Several members of our senior management team are also on hand to help answer your questions.
As a reminder, our comments today will include forward-looking statements regarding our future expectations, which may differ significantly from actual results. Information on risk factors that could affect our business can be found in our SEC filings.
We will refer to certain non-GAAP financial measures such as adjusted earnings and unit costs, excluding fuel. We have provided a reconciliation between the most directly comparable GAAP and non-GAAP measures in our earnings release.
In addition, today's call may be deemed a solicitation in respect of Alaska Air Group's contemplated acquisition of Virgin America. The information discussed today is qualified in its entirety the Virgin America's definitive proxy statement that was filed with the SEC on June 20, along with other relevant solicitation materials, which are all available on Virgin America's Investor Relations page at ir.virginamerica.com.
And now that I have complied with our GC's request in sleekness, we will move to the results. This morning, Alaska Air Group reported a second quarter GAAP net profit of $260 million. Excluding the $6 million impact of mark-to-market adjustments related to our fuel hedge portfolio and a $9 million impact associated with merger-related costs, Air Group recorded a record adjusted net income of $263 million, up 14%. Earnings per share grew by 20% to $2.12 per share. Additional information about cost expectations, capacity plans, fuel hedging, capital expenditures and other items can be found in our investor update included in our Form 8-K issued this morning and available on our website at alaskaair.com. 
Now I'll turn the call over to Brad.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Lavanya, and good morning, everybody. As we progress through 2016 and look forward to the second half of the year, we know that investors have a lot in their minds, and the equity market certainly reflects that. As you know, we try to stay focused
componenttext:
Thanks, Lavanya, and good morning, everybody. As we progress through 2016 and look forward to the second half of the year, we know that investors have a lot in their minds, and the equity market certainly reflects that. As you know, we try to stay focused and concentrated our efforts here on building a fundamentally good business. As we look ahead, we feel very good about our underlying business, and all of us here are very excited about the future. The fundamentals of our business are strong. We're running a great airline, and we believe the merger with Virgin America is going to create a very strong airlines, with reach across the entire country and with real strength in originating traffic up and down the West Coast.
I'll start off today by talking about the underlying business and then share an update on the merger. First, we are operating safely and on time. Our folks are doing an outstanding job, and I want to thank them. 88.7% of our flights arrived on time in the second quarter, and we did this with much less block time than the average airline, which is a credit to how efficient and consistent we are in the ground. We expect this on-time performance will lead the 6 largest domestic airlines. We also completed 99.8% of our flights in the second quarter, canceling on average only one mainline flight per day.
Second, our employees are taking great care of our customers. We spent a lot of time with our frontline employees building alignment and talking with them about the sort of airline we want to be for our customers. We're seeing substantial evidence that these investments are paying off. Our customer satisfaction scores, which have been on the 7 or 8-year run continue to improve. In fact, our score for the second quarter was the highest second quarter score ever. And as you know, we also won our ninth consecutive J.D. Power award for customer service during the quarter. We earned the highest score of any airline included in the survey in each of the 7 areas measured, including a move from fourth place to first place for in-flight service, which reflects investments we've made in food and beverage service, in-flight entertainment, seating, seat power and bins. This award is a fantastic recognition for employees, and I want to congratulate them and thank them for everything they are doing to make Alaska stand out in the eyes of our customers.
Our model is based on building preference for our airlines, and we build this preference with on-time operations, fantastic customer service and, of course, low fares. This model has worked not only in the last couple of years, but in the last 15 to 20 years.
Since the first quarter of 2010, we've launched 100 new markets, and we've outpaced industry revenue growth by a factor of 3. This in the midst of one of the bigger competitive [indiscernible] this industry has seen in years. This growth would not have been possible without our mentality of continually reducing costs, which allows us to offer customers low fares, while still maintaining industry-leading margins. Brandon is going to share more detail in a moment on what the compounding effect of cost reductions since 2008 has meant to our financial performance.  But to give you a sense of how powerful a low-cost structure is, even if we adjust our fuel prices to $2 a gallon, markets representing 97% of our revenue for the last 12 months would still be profitable. And it's important to know that this is done with a full allocation of all costs. 
This model is also delivering returns that are consistently in excess of our cost to capital. In fact, our trailing 12-month ROIC of 25.9% puts us in a top 10% of all S&P 500 companies. Our successful growth shows the providing customers with a high-value experience at low fares is a winning formula, especially in the upper-end leisure in business segments or what we call the leisure market. And this is a great platform for our future, combining our network, which has strengthened the Pacific Northwest and Alaska with Virgin America's strength in California. We will be a very strong airline with strength up and down the West Coast and, of course, we'll have national reach. For example, in the future we will have 25 flights a day to New York City from 7 West Coast airports and 10 flights a day to Boston from 5 West Coast airports.
We also see the increased choice and competition the merger will provide that's fundamentally good for consumers. Speaking of bringing the 2 companies together, I want to share a few thoughts around timing and the integration process. 
First, timing. We have an agreement in place with the Justice Department concerning the timing of their review, and we're forecasting the close will occur in the fourth quarter. When the deal closes, Virgin America will operate as a subsidiary of Alaska Air Group until we achieve a single operating certificate, which we expect in the first quarter of 2018. We are committed to making this a very successful integration.
During the post-close transition period, Ben will be the CEO of Virgin America, in addition to his role as President and COO of Alaska Airlines. And Peter Hunt, who is currently Virgin America's CFO, will be his President and responsible for day-to-day operations. Ben and Peter are proven leaders who will do a great job leading Virgin America during this time. The integration management office is up and running and is being led by Torque Zubeck. While there's a lot of functional work going on behind the scenes, I want to share a brief update with you on the key areas of culture, labor and brand.
Starting with culture. We know that when mergers don't succeed, especially in our industry, often people, or in other words, the culture, is the culprit. This in an area where we're spending a lot of time. Our high-level goal is simply to retain the best of Alaska Airlines and the best of Virgin America and position the new combined company to be aligned, to be bold and to grow successfully well into the future.
Moving to labor. We're meeting with labor leaders and have positive discussions. We appreciate all the work the labor relations team and other -- our labor leaders are doing to make this a smooth integration, and we are optimistic that the process will go well. 
And finally, I know a lot of you are curious about the brand. And as we said before, the Alaska brand is staying. We're also doing in-depth market research to better understand the elements of Virgin America's product and brand that customers love most, especially in California. And we expect to have a final decision on the brand in early 2017.
To summarize, whether we're talking about Alaska as it stands today or the combined company post-merger, we're focused on the same bedrock principles. First, we want to be safe and on time; second, we want to get the culture right, and we want to build alignment with our people; third, we want to protect and grow our customer base; fourth, we want to maintain our low-cost structure and low fares; and finally, we want to consistently generate the level of returns that you expect from high-quality industrial companies.
With that, I'll turn the call over to Andrew.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Brad, and good morning, everyone. Total second quarter revenue increased $57 million or 4%. This contrast with the industry revenue shrinking by about 2%. Over the past 5 years, our revenues are growing 35%, outpacing the industry by 3 to 1. This
componenttext:
Thanks, Brad, and good morning, everyone. Total second quarter revenue increased $57 million or 4%. This contrast with the industry revenue shrinking by about 2%. Over the past 5 years, our revenues are growing 35%, outpacing the industry by 3 to 1. This growth has come with strong returns that resemble high-quality companies.
Our second quarter PRASM was down 7.7%. We are very pleased now that our unit revenue performance was within 150 basis points in the industry, notwithstanding the fact that we grew capacity by 11%, with competitive capacity growing 13%. We're also very pleased to see our load factors at 85%, which was flat for the first time since the first quarter of 2013. That said, closing pricing has been showing weakness for reasons you are already familiar with.
While we're always mindful of the environment we operate in, the fundamentals of Alaska are sound for several reasons. First, we're offering a high-value product to customers at low fares. Our low fares are enabled by low costs and have allowed us to grow profitably. The 100 new markets Brad referenced earlier, in aggregate, our owning margins are at system average levels and represent approximately 20% of our annual revenues. I'm also pleased to announce that we just learned we've received approval for 4 additional flights to Newark [ph]. We plan to launch Portland and San Diego and Newark [ph] this November and then San Jose and a third Seattle-Newark [ph] in March and May, respectively. Secondly, when speaking of offering options to our customers, partnerships are key. 
Earlier in June, we launched new Mileage Plan partnership with Japan Airlines, making it the third international partner we've added in the last 12 months, Hainan and Iceland there being the other 2. That brings our total partners to 17 and allows us to serve over 950 destinations worldwide. A combination of greater reach and targeted promotion has helped increase the number of our members flying on our international partners by 32%. It is an interesting fact, our international partners, along with American Airlines, on a combined basis, account for 34% of all international seats in the U.S. That's more than 81 of the global alliances. We expect the benefit of this offering to our customers to take a step change forward with our acquisition of Virgin America. This acquisition will result in us having a strong presence in the largest international West Coast gateways of Los Angeles and San Francisco.
And lastly, membership in our Frequent-Flier Program is up 11%, and our credit card portfolio grew by 12%, both outpacing passenger growth in our network. Our loyalty program generated $200 million in cash for the second quarter, that's an increase of 16%. We expect this growth to continue giving our card offering, which includes 30,000 bonus miles, annual companion ticket, free bags, no international transactions fees and the lowest annual fees of 80 comparable airline card. In addition, Costco, an iconic Pacific Northwest brand with a strong West Coast presence, moved to exclusive acceptance of Visa Cards at its warehouses last month. It should come as no surprise that our customers also shop at Costco for its great products and prices. We've seen spend on their card increased significantly as a result.
Shifting our focus to the back half of the year. Here are a few things to be mindful of. We expect competitive capacity in our markets to be up 13% in Q3 and 12% in Q4, that's about the same as we face for more than 1.5 years now. As others make post-summer trims to their schedules, competitive capacity has come down by 1 point in the third quarter and by 4 points for the fourth quarter since we last spoke to you in April.
Moving to Alaska's capacity. It will moderate significantly as we move through the rest of the year. Our capacity will be up about 8% in the third quarter and only 3% in the fourth quarter, which is significant reduction from the 12% we grew during the first half of the year. Our full year guidance sits at about 8.5%, which includes the New York flight I just mentioned as well as Cuba. 
In summary, the fundamentals of our underlying business are strong. We're growing and diversifying revenues, while continuing to build brand loyalty. We've confidence in our business model to continue to grow profitably and owning strong returns for our owners. I'm personally excited about speaking with you next quarter as we expect to have closed on Virgin America, which will begin the next chapter of our journey.
And with that, I'll turn the call over to Brandon.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Andrew, and good morning, everyone. It's a fabulous sunny morning here in Seattle, and it's great to be speaking with you today. As Brad said, Air Group's adjusted net profit improved by 14% to $263 million, and earnings per share improved by more
componenttext:
Thanks, Andrew, and good morning, everyone. It's a fabulous sunny morning here in Seattle, and it's great to be speaking with you today. As Brad said, Air Group's adjusted net profit improved by 14% to $263 million, and earnings per share improved by more than 20%. Our pretax margin was a strong 28.4% and grew by 260 basis points and should be among the best in the domestic industry.
Trailing 12 ROIC grew by a nearly 400 basis points to just under 26%. On an adjusted pretax basis, we are in $424 million, an increase of $54 million over the second quarter of last year. 
As Andrew said, revenues grew by 4% or $57 million, a result that we're happy with considering aggregate revenues across the S&P 500 are projected to shrink by 0.6% in the second quarter. Fuel cost declined by $56 million, and nonfuel cost increased by about the same amount. Our unit -- our nonfuel unit cost performance in the quarter was really strong with unit cost declining by 3.7%. We did see a shift in some of the cost into the back half of the year. So our full year guidance remains unchanged at this point.  We continue to believe that our model of high productivity and low overhead is a winning combination to keep nonfuel cost in check. 
Passengers per FTE, our broadest measure of productivity, improved by another 2.7% to 199 [ph], a new Q2 record for us. And it's working at a division level, too. I want to gave a shout out to our flight ops team, pilots hard time this quarter was better than both budget and prior year. 
We've been shipping away at our costs slowly each year going back to 2009 and, in fact, even back to 2003. And sometimes it helps to go up to 41,000 feet to look at the progress we've made. Recently, our FP&A team just add and made a really important observation. If our ex fuel unit cost had grown in line with the rest of the industry instead of the gradual decline we've seen each year since 2009, our pretax profit this year would be almost $800 million lower. That translates to about $4 a share or more than $4 billion of market cap at current multiples. So while each individual year of 0.5%  or 1% cost reduction doesn't sound like a lot, the cumulative impact is enormous.
Looking forward, we'll see the backside of that cost shift and currently expect ex fuel cost to be up about 3% in Q3 and up about 0.5% in Q4, which keeps our full year unit cost declined to about 0.5% in line with prior guidance, as I said.
Cash flow from operations for the first half of the year was $900 million, and we ended the June quarter with over $1.6 billion of cash on hand. Adjusted for leases, we have a net cash position of approximately $700 million, and our debt-to-cap is at the 25%. Our balance sheet is in the best shape it's ever been, and it positions us well for our planned merger with Virgin America in the fourth quarter. Our treasury team has now obtained committed financing for the deal. Interest was very strong. We ended up over subscribed, and we were able to partner with a diverse set of leading aviation lenders. I want to thank our lenders for their partnership and support. We're finding that it's an excellent time to raise money, market rates are at historic lows and spreads for investment-grade secured loans are tight. Alaska's all-in interest rate will be low. I want to compliment  our treasury and legal teams for doing such a fabulous job in this process.
Air Group has built a repetition with both lenders and investors as a conservatively managed company with a strong balance sheet, and that's not going to change. After we complete the transaction, we'll still have about 20 unencumbered next-gen Boeing 737s, and we're going to return to redeleveraging the balance sheet.
Speaking of fleet, we've taken delivery of 12 737-900ERs so far this year and have 7 additional 900ERs coming in the back half of the year. As a reminder, many of these deliveries are replacements for older 737-400s.
During the quarter, we also exercised 3 options for E175s for delivery in 2017. This is not new capital. Instead, we've chosen to buy them rather than lease them because we prefer the economics of owning.
We expect total CapEx for the year to be approximately $750 million, consistent with prior guidance. As a result of the 3 E175 auctions I just talked about, our CapEx for 2017 kicks up slightly to just about $1 billion. And again, this is not new capital in our plan. As a reminder, we have 2 big fleet initiatives in process. Full retirement of the 737-400s by the end of 2017, which will be good for reliability, passenger comfort and costs; and introduction of 3 -- 33 E175s into the Horizon fleet, which will help us grow into longer, thinner markets, where we believe we have significant opportunity to expand profitably.
So far this year, we've generated $559 million of free cash flow. We paused on the share repurchase program following the announcement of our planned merger, but continue to pay a meaningful dividend, which is currently yielding about 1.7%. I agree with Andrew. Our business is humming along nicely, and we're taking advantage of profitable growth opportunities. The resulting strong cash flow and our fortress balance sheet have positioned us well to complete the planned merger and set us up for long-term success. Everyone around the company is working extra hard as we prepare to combine 2 great airlines, and I want to thank our 15,000 employees for their efforts and congratulate them once again on a record, fabulous quarter.
And with that, we'd like to open it up to questions.

componenttext: Yes, I'll start off, and Shane may have something to add.  But we're not experiencing anything materially different bound in the industry, Savi. But I will tell you is that our close-in bookings, from a business volume, is actually up. We still continue to see strong volume and demand closer in. Big picture, I think the industry is in a place where there's been consolidation, and there's new products like basic fares into the marketplace. And I think there's just some adjustments going along. But as we've shared in our remarks, we still very -- feel very confident in how we're managing our revenues and building this business. But, Shane, do you have any comments there?

componenttext: Yes, I'll start with capacity, and let Brandon touch on the fleet. But you're right. In fact, the 3% in the fourth quarter and I think you if you look into the booking scheduling into the first quarter, it's quite low. As I did share, we're going to have some very exciting opportunities with some new opportunities in Cuba. But we are going to be firming up. And as you know, we normally set our guidance for 2017 later in the year. And of course, with the proposed Virgin America acquisition, we're going to be taking a long hard look at 2017 capacity. So for now, I would just say that you keep focused on the next few quarters. 2017 will be much more information coming on that.

componenttext: Joe, it's Brandon. Just a follow-up on the fleet question. We'll end this year with 153 airplanes on the mainline as you see in the investor update. At the end of 2017, we'll actually only have 1 more at 154 based on what we see right now. A big delivery year next year with 14 new 737-900s coming in. However, if this year we finish returning all the 737-400. So net growth of 1, we'll have some gauge growth that we can use for capacity growth, but on the fleet side, not much.

componenttext: Rajeev, thanks for the question. We continue to be super excited about Virgin America. We take ourselves back up to 35,000 feet or 41,000 feet. I mean, this, I think the -- this business is actually a better business than it was 5 or 10 years ago. We're very confident in our own company our ability to do well with the assets we have. As you know, we've got real strength at Alaska. We fly to 35 states of 115 cities, but real strength of originating traffic in Alaska, Washington and Oregon. And then Virgin gives us California. So we try to not focus too much on the short term or what's happening with PRASM and more thinking -- think about fundamentally what's going to happen in this industry over 5, 10, 15 years. And all of us are just enormously excited about what we're going to do bringing these 2 great companies together. So that's where it is.

componenttext: Okay. And then quick questions for Andrew. componenttext: Yes, I think it's been sometime since we've grown at this lower level. So I think you have to go back to the history. But I think the other -- Rajeev, the other dynamic that's going on too is just the change in the competitive landscape. So I'm not sure history would be the best teller of the future. I think right now, the lower growth is going to be a good move for us in the fourth quarter as we get raised and set ourselves decide on 2017. That's the best I can give you.

componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then just a second. You guys mentioned an agreement with the DOJ around the close for the fourth quarter. Is there any update following the second information with that [indiscernible] over the next data point to look for really be in app
componenttext: Okay, great. And then just a second. You guys mentioned an agreement with the DOJ around the close for the fourth quarter. Is there any update following the second information with that [indiscernible] over the next data point to look for really be in approval position?

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Julie, this is Kyle. We're making great progress with the second request. And as we've said before, DOJ is looking really closely as we expect it. We're still really confident that we can close in Q4, and what's going to come into focus for the department
componenttext: Julie, this is Kyle. We're making great progress with the second request. And as we've said before, DOJ is looking really closely as we expect it. We're still really confident that we can close in Q4, and what's going to come into focus for the department is this is great for consumer combination. As you'd expect some of the things they're looking at right now between now and ultimate clearance date. If that does come, is that route overlaps, great story there. We have only 7 route overlaps and, of course, they're really interested in our fare philosophies. We have -- that's the story we love to tell as a low-fare, high-value airline. So all said and done, we're on track for a Q4 close if things are going well.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jamie Baker with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jamie Baker with JPMorgan.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Brad, you spoke at the Wings Club about the potential for retaining the Virgin America brand. As a separate entity, today it sounds more like you're studying which aspects of the brand you might want to retain. In the event that you're actually serious ab
componenttext: Brad, you spoke at the Wings Club about the potential for retaining the Virgin America brand. As a separate entity, today it sounds more like you're studying which aspects of the brand you might want to retain. In the event that you're actually serious about the possibility of keeping it separate, could you identify any airline within an airline construct anywhere in the world where margins approach those of Alaska Air Group?

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jamie, thank you for the question. We've actually thought about this quite a lot. I think we're not going to see a lot more at this point about this consideration. I'll just tell you what we are doing is we're looking at a lot of data, we have built clean
componenttext: Jamie, thank you for the question. We've actually thought about this quite a lot. I think we're not going to see a lot more at this point about this consideration. I'll just tell you what we are doing is we're looking at a lot of data, we have built clean teams with Virgin and Alaska. We're looking at what's attractive in California to customers about the Virgin America offering. We're just trying to think about what might be best for our company going forward. And I just think the best things for our -- the owners of this company might be for us to sort of do this work in quiet-- quietly. And then when we have something to say, I don't think it's going to be all that long. Well, what we said is first quarter 2017. When we actually have a view point, when we have a perspective on this, we will share it. So sorry to not give you a better more information, but I just think that might be best for all right now.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, okay, okay. I'll give you a chance to make it up to me on my second question then. I know that -- and we'll see if I get lucky. I know that on paper, the merger raises very few regulatory red flags. But I still can't escape the sort of nagging feelin
componenttext: Yes, okay, okay. I'll give you a chance to make it up to me on my second question then. I know that -- and we'll see if I get lucky. I know that on paper, the merger raises very few regulatory red flags. But I still can't escape the sort of nagging feeling that DOJ may prove susceptible to its own emotions when it comes to the subject of airline M&A. In the event that the DOJ does move to block or tries to extract some sort of concessions, do you walk or do you fight?

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jamie, it's Kyle again. I guess I would say neither. We entered this contract expecting to enter a long marriage with Virgin America, and our position really wouldn't change even if DOJ challenges or acquires of divestitures, which, by the way, just looki
componenttext: Jamie, it's Kyle again. I guess I would say neither. We entered this contract expecting to enter a long marriage with Virgin America, and our position really wouldn't change even if DOJ challenges or acquires of divestitures, which, by the way, just looking at President, I think that's highly unlikely. Obviously, I can't speak for the department. But again, we're talking about a pro-consumer situation, where there are 7 overlap routes, none touching, a slot-constrained airport.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I definitely agree with everything on paper. It's just -- I don't know, it's maybe having been here before that led me to answer the question or ask the question, but I definitely appreciate the 1.5 answers that I got today. I'll pass it on to the ne
componenttext: Yes, I definitely agree with everything on paper. It's just -- I don't know, it's maybe having been here before that led me to answer the question or ask the question, but I definitely appreciate the 1.5 answers that I got today. I'll pass it on to the next guy.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Helane Becker with Cowen & Company.

componenttextpreview: My first question is, can you share what the interest rate is on the deal financing?
componenttext: My first question is, can you share what the interest rate is on the deal financing?

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Helane. This is Mark. What we can tell you is, obviously, we won't know the exact rate until we close. What we can say is that margins are very tight, and you know that market rates are down and as Brandon said, at historic low levels. So what I can
componenttext: Yes, Helane. This is Mark. What we can tell you is, obviously, we won't know the exact rate until we close. What we can say is that margins are very tight, and you know that market rates are down and as Brandon said, at historic low levels. So what I can say is we will be comfortably below 3%, and that's about all the guidance I can give you right now.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And then my other question is on -- actually on the income statement and the operating expense line. And may be, Brandon, this might be for you. Given that you've turned over the fleet, why is your maintenance -- you've started to re
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And then my other question is on -- actually on the income statement and the operating expense line. And may be, Brandon, this might be for you. Given that you've turned over the fleet, why is your maintenance -- you've started to retire older aircraft, why is the maintenance cost of 25% in the quarter? Was there something going on last year that caused this increase to be so substantial this year?

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Helane, this is Chris. I'll answer that one. Yes, last year -- if you might recall, in the second quarter of last year, we had some maintenance credits that were related to some engine work we had done in previous periods. So we got all those credits and
componenttext: Helane, this is Chris. I'll answer that one. Yes, last year -- if you might recall, in the second quarter of last year, we had some maintenance credits that were related to some engine work we had done in previous periods. So we got all those credits and recognized those last year. That was about $10 million. So when you look at  year-over-year, if you take away that $10 million difference between the 2 periods, then maintenance normalizes quite a bit. So that's really the big difference.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Hunter Keay with Wolfe Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Hunter Keay with Wolfe Research.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I get a little frustrated when I hear airlines talking about PRASM as some sort of like short-term only metric, as if it's some sort of like hedge fund only thing that matters and like why we guys don't care about it because it's just not true. And it'
componenttext: So I get a little frustrated when I hear airlines talking about PRASM as some sort of like short-term only metric, as if it's some sort of like hedge fund only thing that matters and like why we guys don't care about it because it's just not true. And it's going to be a fourth year where PRASM is basically down or flat or something like that for you guys, and that's not sustainable. Brandon, you talked about the compounding effect of CASM. There is a compounding effect of PRASM, too. So is there a thought to maybe thinking about this as you reevaluate a whole lot of things post-merger, whether it's guidance, conventions or long-term targets to may be making PRASM a long-term metric somehow? And by that, I mean, we're going to have a target of roughly inflationary-like growth of PRASM, plus or minus 200 basis points or something like that. Because I just -- I don't know why PRASM has to be so short-term oriented, and I feel like you guys might be in a position out to sort of reevaluate things after the merger closes to do something about that?

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Hunter, it's Brandon, maybe I'll take that. I agree with you. I don't know why there is so much focus on PRASM. What I would do if I were a investor as I would focus on profit and I think, as you think about our business going forward, either as Alas
componenttext: Yes, Hunter, it's Brandon, maybe I'll take that. I agree with you. I don't know why there is so much focus on PRASM. What I would do if I were a investor as I would focus on profit and I think, as you think about our business going forward, either as Alaska stand-alone or as a combined company. We're going to make profit-maximizing decisions, and some of that is going to come from PRASM and some of that's going to come from CASM. I think the danger in focusing just on PRASM is that you don't know what happens in any particular market, you don't know what happens with fuel prices and I think you're seeing a lot of that now. But at the end of the day, it's really MASM that matters and profit on the bottom line and the actual cash that goes into your checking account that you can use to delever the balance sheet and payback debt and returned capital of the shareholder. So I agree with you. I [indiscernible]

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Brandon, I'm sorry to interrupt you, but I think you misheard me. I'm saying the exact opposite, to be clear. I think PRASM matters a lot because it's a proxy for pricing power and that is what you get [indiscernible]?
componenttext: Brandon, I'm sorry to interrupt you, but I think you misheard me. I'm saying the exact opposite, to be clear. I think PRASM matters a lot because it's a proxy for pricing power and that is what you get [indiscernible]?

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was going to jump on Brandon's answer as well. So I think you're making a great point, and I think Brandon does agree with you. If you look at this industry 15 years ago, people didn't know what CASM was. We started talking about CASM. Now every airline
componenttext: I was going to jump on Brandon's answer as well. So I think you're making a great point, and I think Brandon does agree with you. If you look at this industry 15 years ago, people didn't know what CASM was. We started talking about CASM. Now every airline has 3-year objectives for CASM, 2-year, 1-year. We give really good and, I think, reliable guidance on CASM. Then I would say roughly 10 years ago, ROIC came into focus, and we started talking about that. I think you're giving us another great challenges. If you were to -- Andrew Harrison and Shane Tackett, if you were to give these guys a sort of a longer-term metric to say, what are going to do for the revenue side of the business, how would you construct that goal? And the Virgin, it's a -- as we sort of thought about these things, they're hard questions to look at. I mean, it's got our head around. It was hard to start producing CASM objectives. But I present to give an as a good challenge, and we should take that away and think about it. We might come away as a stronger airline, and we had a way of articulating our RASM objectives.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
