componenttext: So Brad, you talked about in your -- I think one of the first things you said about people asking you about long-term margins, and you said they're going to be better than everybody else but you didn't give a number. If I were to think about the average pretax margins you guys did in '12, '13 and '14, it's about 14% pretax. So is that good? Sort of all else equal guideposts to how I think about long-term margins? Or will be a little bit lower than that given some likely dilution from Virgin? You can answer the stand-alone or pro forma however you want.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think if this is the place where we're all expecting higher [ph], you guys probably have a better view of what's going to happen with long-term margins in our industry than we do. But we do look at other industries. We look at higher -- other high-
componenttext: Yes. I think if this is the place where we're all expecting higher [ph], you guys probably have a better view of what's going to happen with long-term margins in our industry than we do. But we do look at other industries. We look at higher -- other high-quality industrials. We look at sort of gaps that people are earning over their cost of capital. And so I think the industry, you would hope that as we settle down and have capacity controll and have consolidation that we settle into a place where we're earning as an industry margins that are several hundred points above our cost of capital. And then what we're saying is Alaska should be above that. That's sort of how we see ourselves. That's what we want to do. How you do that math, I don't think I want to be the one -- I think I told you what we know and we've won -- We've always done is try to talk about what we know and not talk about what we don't know. So I think that's where I might leave it. Is the Virgin just be really candidate, you add the 2 together. We're not issuing 1 new share for this acquisition. So any profit that they bring into the company is accretive to our profit. But I think you have seen the math versus historical margins are lower than Alaska. So I would expect that our company-wide margins will dilute a little bit. And Brandon, I can't remember the exact numbers, but it's not huge. Once the synergies are realized, it's not a significant decrease as I recall.

componenttext: Yes, right. Okay. And then what's on the table in terms of assuming this deal gets done, how you guys might think about communicating with The Street? Have you ever considered talking about -- I know we talked about this a few months ago about long-term RASM guidance, but is there -- are you guys giving any thoughts how you might think about communicating financial guidance in general once the deal closes and in particular, giving something like annual EPS guidance like all the high-quality industrial companies do so you could, too? I mean, like -- I'm serious. You can prove -- so if you give me a range and you hit it year-over-year, your multiple will go higher. If you believe this fuel and fares are correlated, for example, you should be able to hit a range of EPS. So as you guys think about this, are you giving thought to how you communicate guidance longer term in general, not just RASM, but guidance in general.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we are thinking about it. What I will tell you is we were on the cusp of giving a lot more forward-looking disclosure and then we went in to deal with Virgin, and so we're not going to do that right now. And what I would say is I recognize that, that
componenttext: Yes, we are thinking about it. What I will tell you is we were on the cusp of giving a lot more forward-looking disclosure and then we went in to deal with Virgin, and so we're not going to do that right now. And what I would say is I recognize that, that's what good high-quality industrials do. I would love to get there at some point. What I will tell you is that the reality of putting business a together with business b, we're going to have numbers that are unfamiliar to us for a while. And I think what we'll do is we'll wait until we get more familiar with those numbers and we'll get really confident on what the comps look like from our own perspective. And then once we're confident with that, we'll start to giving more to you guys.

componenttextpreview: When the merger was announced, you talked about redeleveraging. And I'm wondering if you've dug deeper into the integration planning process, have you established any timing or sort of annual progress that you hope to make in that regard? I mean, is it a
componenttext: When the merger was announced, you talked about redeleveraging. And I'm wondering if you've dug deeper into the integration planning process, have you established any timing or sort of annual progress that you hope to make in that regard? I mean, is it a 5-year goal to return to where you currently are premerger or where you were in March or some other time frame? Is there some annual number in terms of how much you'd like to -- how many turns of leverage you might want to decline? Anything like that?

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jamie, it's Brandon. Good morning. Maybe I'll start, and then Ben can tell you about the integration progress that we're making. We have modeled the redeleveraging that we talked about. And when we come out of the gates, we should have debt to cap, right,
componenttext: Jamie, it's Brandon. Good morning. Maybe I'll start, and then Ben can tell you about the integration progress that we're making. We have modeled the redeleveraging that we talked about. And when we come out of the gates, we should have debt to cap, right, 59%, 60% and -- but our goal would be to get down into the mid-40s within, say, 3 years or so. That's obviously dependent on the economic environment. But if we do it right, that's where we'll be. And I think we're going to stay there for a while. I think we like leverage in the mid -- low to mid-40% range. I don't see us going back down to 28% like we were pre-deal, but I think we can get there quick. And at that level, we'll have a balance sheet that looks a lot like another high -- or other high-quality industrials and it will look very favorable compared to the other carriers in the industry.

componenttext: Very helpful. I do appreciate that. Second question, and this is not uniquely tied to merger specifics or another negotiations. So hopefully, you'll choose to answer. Or get the deal done only if you can assure that the [indiscernible] metric -- ROIC remains above X? And have you established a floor internally, not asking you what the floor is, just trying to dig into the thought process there.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jamie, it's Brad. I think what we will say is that we've always run this business for the long term. We think about what's going to be good for all of the people that's been on this place over the long term for customers, for our employees, for all of you
componenttext: Jamie, it's Brad. I think what we will say is that we've always run this business for the long term. We think about what's going to be good for all of the people that's been on this place over the long term for customers, for our employees, for all of you for the [indiscernible] the business. And that, that's the minds that we're taking as we have this conversation with the Justice Department. And so we are pushing. There are some things that we feel are important to our future success and our ability to do good things for customers, and that's what's motivating us here. And I'd also say we do have a pretty strong internal campus about what has worked for us and what will work for us in the future. So if that's an answer to your question, there you have it, but there's just not a lot more that we can say about this.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016

componenttext: No, that will suffice. And if I could just sneak in a housekeeping question and, I guess, somewhat revenues in what Hunter was asking about in terms of guidance. I'm just thinking about how do I rebuild my model.

componenttext: Yes. How about you, Jamie? All right, what we'll do is we'll probably report regional and mainline, I would say. But until we have a single operating certificate, Virgin America and Alaska Airline separate results will be available on the [indiscernible] as well.

componenttext: Your next question comes from Michael Linenberg from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just follow up on Jamie's question about Brandon, where you would want to get to with respect to get to Cap, is getting back to the low to mid-40s still didn't get you back to an ID rating? Would that be -- would that matter? Or is it at the very least, y
componenttext: Just follow up on Jamie's question about Brandon, where you would want to get to with respect to get to Cap, is getting back to the low to mid-40s still didn't get you back to an ID rating? Would that be -- would that matter? Or is it at the very least, you want to do what you need to do in order to get back to the coveted investment-grade credit rating?

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mike, this is Mark Eliasen. Maybe I'll take a shot at that one. First of all, we're not changing our principles, and our principle got us to the investment-grade rating, and that is generating good cash flow, a conservative balance sheet, running a good c
componenttext: Mike, this is Mark Eliasen. Maybe I'll take a shot at that one. First of all, we're not changing our principles, and our principle got us to the investment-grade rating, and that is generating good cash flow, a conservative balance sheet, running a good company, good high-quality industrial company. So we're going to get there, and we're confident that the rating agencies will come around when they see that and they know us well, and they'll see that we're going to just revert back to our pattern. One point I'll make about the -- aren't going to have additional debt. But because the interest rate is quite a bit lower, then what we had before, our actual interest expense will be right in the range of what we've had historically. So that's a good thing even though our leverage is a little bit higher.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then just a second question, and this is probably -- I don't know if it's for Brad or Ben, but we had the new -- I guess, another face from the DOT as it relates to consumer protection regulation. And while there is kind of a lot of verbi
componenttext: Okay, great. And then just a second question, and this is probably -- I don't know if it's for Brad or Ben, but we had the new -- I guess, another face from the DOT as it relates to consumer protection regulation. And while there is kind of a lot of verbiage, a lot of noise, it seemed like there were a couple of things that are going to come into play here, and one of it has to deal with the on-time performance. And I'm just curious, I know that under the new rules, Horizon doesn't meet the new threshold, but it looks like it's actually very close to the threshold. So maybe it's a 2017, 2018 type event. But if you were to include Horizon and with the Alaska numbers, where would you stack up on on-time completion factor? Like how would you compare -- and I realize probably after the announcements for the other carriers, but does it enhance? Does it -- is it neutral? Or does it take away from the numbers?

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mike, that's a great question, and it's not -- and you guys wouldn't expect that from me, I track that every day, Alaska, Horizon. I actually track every other carrier in the industry and how it's stack up. I would tell you today, if the combined Alaska a
componenttext: Mike, that's a great question, and it's not -- and you guys wouldn't expect that from me, I track that every day, Alaska, Horizon. I actually track every other carrier in the industry and how it's stack up. I would tell you today, if the combined Alaska and Horizon, we would still lead the industry in on-time and combined completion rates, hands down. So Horizon, I'm looking forward to Horizon to get in the 175, the more reliable airplane. In fact, we'd include SkyWest in that [indiscernible] as well. So I think it's a good thing, what the DOT has done. I mean, the customer when they book on an airline, they really don't distinguish whether they're flying a regional airplane or a mainline airplane, and it's our commitment. It's been our philosophy all the time here in Alaska that whether you fly mainline or regional, we will look after you like the same across all touch points.

We've seen a non -- [indiscernible] 7% improvement so far this year on DOT performance towards getting [indiscernible] on on-time performance for getting at the gate [indiscernible] 5% improvement as far as on-time arrival. One of the challenge I think we have here is the [indiscernible] is really dealing with agency delays. But everything else that we can control we're driving a much, much stronger process in place. So I'm pretty excited about the focus. I think you're going to see a continued progress on performance from Horizon. I think the second piece of this, the E175 is such a reliable great airplane that actually help with a great feeling as well. So that's going to be a really good tool in our toolbox is to really take care of our customers.

componenttext: Andrew, taking a step back, I'm wondering if you can help us understand how codeshare agreements work more broadly. There's a broad view that [indiscernible] like a light switch either, however, you don't, you turn them on, you turn them off. So the question here is, is how do they really work? What are the various components? How easy are they to customize it? And where does the value really come from? It's [indiscernible] that you don't serve but your partner does? Or is it on the markets that you both serve?

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dan, that's a very good big question. I'll keep it high level I think, and I'll just speak for Alaska Air Group. A couple of key things here that codeshares provide us. Firstly, domestically, we can connect into our partners' hubs in the middle of the cou
componenttext: Dan, that's a very good big question. I'll keep it high level I think, and I'll just speak for Alaska Air Group. A couple of key things here that codeshares provide us. Firstly, domestically, we can connect into our partners' hubs in the middle of the country and then connect our customers to anywhere in the rest of the country. So firstly, these codeshare agreements domestically give us a lot of ability to be able to get our passengers everywhere they need to go at the times they need to go and give them plenty of choice of fares when they need to go. I think the other key component of that is also obviously the loyalty side so our customers can still accrue [indiscernible] that miles when they fly when our partners medal or on their own medal. And of course, redemptions. Our customers want to redeem -- 85% of our customers redeem on us still. And the last piece is really international. And the international is really, really important. For our international partners, we provide huge value to help them fill our airplanes. I mean, the statistics are quite significant in our hubs, especially on how many passengers we put on our foreign flag friend. But for Alaska customers, it allows them to both redeem globally 800-plus destinations globally as well as earn and redeem miles. So overall, I would say that these codeshare relationships provide great utility. But at the end of the day, Alaska Air Group is built on its fundamental product and the majority of customers, majority of loyalty, the majority of revenue is all based on Alaska Air Group's medal and what we do.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016

componenttext: Got it. But I need to just kind of backup, Andrew, just a little bit there. How easy is it to customize them to turn on or turn off certain routes, I guess, number one. It's going to help us understand a little bit further.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016

componenttext: So I think from mechanics, it's very easy to turn things on or off. We're just going to give notice to our customers, change booking schedules and not disrupt passengers. So we work really closely with our partners. And there's no silver bullet on the value. In our Seattle hub, it might come from connecting beyond international loyalty in California where we're less prevalent or maybe even in Los Angeles, our partners give us a much fuller schedule and allow customers where we don't have a whole lot of utility still stay in the family and in our program to travel on them. I think loyalty, codeshare revenue, all of these things at our portfolio, Dan, honestly there's no one single area that's more important than the other from my perspective at least.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016

componenttext: Dan, that's a great question, and that's a project that we are working on right now where I think the point you're making is a good one that a lot of carriers are moving to but certain numbers of life live -- live flat seats in certain markets. The other side of it is the last. We've got a long standing. We're very proud of the low-cost, low-fare position that we have. So those are the 2 [indiscernible], and there's also a simplicity element on these things. So those are the things that we're going to be balancing as we think about this decision. I think you'll hear me say more about this in the next few months, but it is an open question. I think you know the 2 sides, the 2 arguments for each side.

componenttext: Savi, maybe I'll start on the first part on capacity. So a couple of things. As you heard earlier, there's obviously decent growth on the regional side of our business and all the CIJs going away, now with 70 seats, we're going to 76 seats on the 175. So there's some good growth there. A lot of our growth is really Transcon and Midcon. 80% of it was this quarter. 100% of it will be next quarter. We'll give more details later on. But these are markets that we found to be very, very good for us and adding a lot of new revenue. As Brandon shared, these are high-level estimates again as we stand today. The Havannas [ph], all of Newarks, each of those were a point of growth, or a 3 quarters of a point of growth, so it's not hard to get to 7% already with what we've already done. We will continue to monitor this. And of course, with the new combined entity, we'll take a hard look at it. But what we've seen to date is our growth has provided good economics for this company. And if these economic conditions and their continuing strengthening of close-in bookings and the environment are still there next year, we'll continue on with our plan.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Christina, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Alaska Air Group Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded and will be accessible for
componenttext:
Good morning. My name is Christina, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Alaska Air Group Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded and will be accessible for future playback at www.alaskaair.com. [Operator Instructions] 
I would like to now turn the call over to Alaska Air Group's Managing Director of Investor Relations, Lavanya Sareen.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Christina. Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us for Alaska Air Group's Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Call.On the call today, our CEO, Brad Tilden, will provide an overview of the business and share our progress on the proposed acquisit
componenttext:
Thanks, Christina. Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us for Alaska Air Group's Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Call.
On the call today, our CEO, Brad Tilden, will provide an overview of the business and share our progress on the proposed acquisition of Virgin America. Our Chief Commercial Officer, Andrew Harrison, will share the revenue results for the quarter; followed by Brandon Pedersen, our CFO, who will discuss our financial results and outlook for the rest of 2016. Several members of our senior management team are also on hand to help answer your questions.
As a reminder, our comments today will include forward-looking statements regarding our future expectations, which may differ significantly from actual results. Information on risk factors that could affect our business can be found in our SEC filings.
We will refer to certain non-GAAP financial measures such as adjusted earnings and unit costs, excluding fuel. We have provided a reconciliation between the most directly comparable GAAP and non-GAAP measures in our earnings release.
This morning, Alaska Air Group reported a third quarter GAAP net profit of $256 million, excluding $14 million in merger-related costs and a $2 million impact of mark-to-market adjustments related to our fuel hedge portfolio. Air Group reported an adjusted net income of $272 million. And earnings per share grew by 2% to $2.20 per share. That compares to First Call lien estimate of $2.09 per share. 
Additional information about cost expectations, capacity plans, fuel hedging, capital expenditures and other items can be found in our investor update included in our Form 8-K issued this morning and available on our website at alaskaair.com.
And with that, I'll turn it over to Brad.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Lavanya, and good morning, everyone. As Lavanya just shared, our third quarter net income was $272 million, a bit below last year, but our earnings per share of $2.20 were 2% higher than last year and our highest quarterly earnings per share ever.
componenttext:
Thanks, Lavanya, and good morning, everyone. As Lavanya just shared, our third quarter net income was $272 million, a bit below last year, but our earnings per share of $2.20 were 2% higher than last year and our highest quarterly earnings per share ever.
2016 is shaping up to be a year of record profitability. Pretax income for the first 9 months of the year was over $1 billion and $90 million higher than last year. And on a trailing 12-month basis, our pretax margin now stands at just under 25%. This is an extraordinary level of performance, not only in relation to our industry, but also in relation to other high-quality industrial companies.
Some have asked what Alaska's margin should be over the longer term. This is a good question and one that we can all speculate about. What we can say definitively is that our goal is to be a leader in this industry, and that means we need to be safe, be on time, provide great service and very importantly, have both low fares and low costs. If we do these things well, we'll be in a position to lead the industry in terms of financial performance, regardless of what part of the cycle we're in.
Before we get into the details of the quarter, I'd like to touch briefly on Virgin America. Many of you have asked questions about the timing of the merger and about our ongoing discussions with the Justice Department. As to timing, we were hoping to get this done a couple of weeks ago, and we're obviously not there quite yet. The scope of issues that remain with the Justice Department is manageable, but they're important matters, and we want to take the time that's necessary to work through them. It's hard to predict the exact timing from when we'll wrap up since there are 2 parties involved. There's a process at play, and we're working through that process and we're respectful of that process. Our hope is that we'll have antitrust clearance soon.
All that said, we continue to be very confident that the deal will get done and get done in a way that benefits all of our stakeholders, most importantly, our customers. This is a pro-consumer merger of 2 smaller airlines that will bring new low-fare competition, industry-leading service and innovative product offerings for the customers we serve.
And unfortunately, what I've just shared is the extent of the comments that we're going to be able to make this morning about the review process.
As we prepare for the merger, there are 2 things our leadership team has really focused on. First, bringing together these 2 teams so everyone is aligned, motivated and working on the same things, or pulling together in other words. And doing this well lays the groundwork for number two, which is achieving the synergies of the deal, which based on everything we've seen to date, we feel confident about doing.
Ben Minicucci and his team have been working hard on the integration planning, and Ben and others will be happy to share details of the planning work during the Q&A. 
And as a reminder, this commendation ultimately positions us as the fifth largest airline in the country, an airline with a national footprint and an unmatched ability to serve West Coast travelers.
And with that, I'd like to turn the focus of this call back to our stand-alone business and our Q3 performance. It's football season, and we're all cheering on the Seahawks and our other CFO, Russell Wilson. One of the things the Seahawks do well is stick to their game plan, and I'm really proud of our folks for sticking to our game plan during our busiest summer yet.
A big part of Alaska's success is built on being safe, on being on time and on taking great care of our customers. Our team flat-delivered during the third quarter. 
Let me start with safety. You've heard us say that safety is our #1 priority. And last quarter, we were the first airline to have our new Safety Management System, or SMS, accepted by the FAA. This system was the FAA's, mandating for all airlines as the new way of monitoring, managing and mitigating safety risks, and it's a project that we've been working on for almost 5 years. I'm really proud of the teams at Alaska and Horizon for being the first airlines to have this in place. And again, leading the industry on this underscores our commitment to operating safely and to doing things right.
Second, we continue to run a solid operation, and in fact, this was one of our best quarters operationally ever. 89.1% of Alaska's flights arrived on time during the quarter, and we completed 99.8% of our flights. On a year-to-date basis, our on-time rate is 88.5%, and we expect it will be the best among the 6 largest carriers for the seventh year in a row.
Over at Horizon. David and his team have been focused on improving their operation, and their efforts are paying off as our third quarter performance went from 79.9% last year to 85.3% this year. This is especially important as we continue to grow the regional side of the business, including the addition of new Embraer jets.
And third, our people are taking care of customers. Our internal customer satisfaction score for the third quarter was 87.3%, our highest score since we started tracking this back in 2007. This is a fantastic achievement, and I want to thank our employees for taking great care of our customers over the summer.
It's no surprise that how you treat people matters. We're seeing the results as active members in our Mileage Plan have increased by 35% in the last 2 years and this in the face of intense competition in some of our markets.
Being safe, being on time and offering great service and low fares are the key ingredients of our game plan not only for customers, but also for our owners. Looking at the most recent quarter, we expect our trailing 12-month ROIC of 24% and our third quarter pretax margin of 27% will be among the very best in the industry. These are strong results, and you'll hear more from Andrew and Brandon next on the underlying actions that drove these outcomes.
As I look to the future, I'm very confident about our core business and even more excited about the future when the Virgin America merger is complete. A lot of people will say this, but I really feel it's true with Alaska. We have a fantastic group of people here who are working together, and I want to thank them for everything they're doing to make us the best airline that we can possibly be for our customers.
Now I'll turn the call over to Andrew.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Brad, and good morning, everyone. Our third quarter revenue performance was solid, with growth of 3.4% or $51.2 million. This contrasts with the industry revenue contraction of approximately 2%. We were able to sustain high load factors while incr
componenttext:
Thanks, Brad, and good morning, everyone. Our third quarter revenue performance was solid, with growth of 3.4% or $51.2 million. This contrasts with the industry revenue contraction of approximately 2%. We were able to sustain high load factors while increasing capacity at a rate more than 2x that of the industry. Our present change improved about 200 basis points from the prior quarter and outperformed the industry by approximately 40 basis points despite competitive capacity growing double digits in our markets once again.
Looking at monthly trends. RASM was down by an average of 6.5% in both July and August, yet it was up 0.5% in September. Lower September growth and strong bookings within the month, along with an improved closing yield trajectory, contributed to the strong performance during the period -- during this shoulder period. Our September load factor of 84.1% was up 2.5 points year-over-year. And while fares remain low, they appear to be stable, and we're not seeing anything to suggest that this will not continue into the fourth quarter.
Our underlying business remains sound, and we expect to continue our current momentum for several reasons. First, our revenue streams continue to grow and diversify due to our growth. We started our transcon service 15 years ago in September of 2001, with 1 flight from Seattle to DCA. Today, we serve 15 cities in this region, with 33 flights a day. And transcon service now accounts for approximately 15% of our revenues and a similar amount of our profits. We're continuing this growth with new flights to Newark from Portland, San Diego, San Jose and a third daily departure from Seattle. And here's a little fun fact. If you combined our net worth with Virgin America, we'd have up to 31 flights a day to the New York City area alone.
Second, we added Embraer 175 into our fleet a year ago, and this has been a fantastic aircraft for reaching markets in the Mid-Continent, which were too fast for Q400 and too thin for the 737. We have rapidly grown the number of markets served by the Embraer to 29. These aircraft are delivering the results we hoped for as they are creating new and profitable revenue streams supporting our mainline growth and providing greater nonstop convenience for our customers.
Even though many of our Embraer 175 markets are still maturing, in aggregate, they are profitable and already earning their cost of capital. We take delivery of 18 175s next year.
Third, this growth is buttressed by the loyalty we enjoy from our members. We believe we have the most generous and far-reaching loyalty program in the industry. Members in our credit card portfolio grew 11.5% for the quarter, with retail spend on the portfolio outpacing this membership growth. And additionally, our Frequent-Flier members grew 10%.
And fourth, our growth is enabled by offering low fares. In some recent analysis we conducted, we found Alaska's one-way fares were more than $40 or 23% lower than each of the 3 network carriers on a systemwide stage length adjusted basis. Our low fares are enabled by our low costs. We remain focused on bringing these low fares to our customers and maintaining the cost advantage that enables these fares.
I want to move to the fourth quarter now. Our Q4 growth will slow substantially to just over 3%. This brings our full year capacity growth to about 8.5%, in line with our previous guidance. However, our competitive capacity is expected to stay elevated for the remainder of the year at about 10%.
While we expect to close-in bookings strengths we have seen in September to carry through to the fourth quarter, December is expected to be softer than October and November on a relative basis as both Christmas and New Year's fall on a weekend this year, compressing the holiday travel season. We estimate this will lower PRASM for the quarter by about 0.5 point.
I also want to update you on the progress we are making on our premium cost product. We expect to complete the conversion of all 61 737-800s by year-end. We'll start selling tickets for premium class in early November for travel starting January 5, 2017. As a reminder, we expect this to add approximately $50 million in revenue next year and achieve $85 million on new run rate by the end of 2018.
With that, I'd like to touch on 2017. On a stand-alone basis, that is excluding any impact from the acquisition of Virgin America, we expect our growth to slow by about 150 basis points versus this year to slightly more than 7%. This growth comprises approximately 2 points from longer stage length and a point from the annualization of markets we already launched in 2016.
As we look at published schedules, we expect Q1 2017 competitive capacity to come down slightly to 9% in our markets, still elevated but a nice change from the double-digit increases we have been seeing for quite a while.
As we enter the last quarter of the year and look to 2017, we remain confident in our business. We are operating well, fundamentals in the economies we serve are strong, our loyal customer base continues to grow, and we continue to add new and profitable revenue streams to our portfolio.
Like everyone else at Alaska, the rest of my commercial team and I are excited about the opportunity that Virgin America presents for our business, which will allow us to accelerate our growth while bringing low fares to more customers and strong returns for our shareholders.
With that, I'll turn the call over to Brandon.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Andrew, and good morning, everybody. We're pleased to report another very strong quarter financially, punctuated by the 2% increase in earnings per share. Even though net profit declined very slightly, we're benefiting from the significant share r
componenttext:
Thanks, Andrew, and good morning, everybody. We're pleased to report another very strong quarter financially, punctuated by the 2% increase in earnings per share. Even though net profit declined very slightly, we're benefiting from the significant share repurchases that we've made since the end of the third quarter of last year.
As Andrew said, revenues grew by more than 3%. And although our nonfuel costs grew by nearly 10%, we were nonetheless pleased with our cost performance. Our nonfuel unit costs were up 1.6%, but that was lower than we initially expected for the quarter. We remain on track to have a full year unit cost reduction of about 0.5%, which would make the seventh -- this the seventh straight year of unit cost reduction.
Andrew offered some early guidance on next year's growth, but we aren't yet able to share initial 2017 unit cost guidance. Our leaders are busy compiling budgets right now. Folks across both Alaska and Horizon recognize that low costs create an important competitive advantage for higher-cost legacy carriers and are required for us to grow. We're planning to provide 2017 cost guidance on our fourth quarter call.
And speaking of guidance, I want to remind everyone that we're taking a little different approach this year by having our Investor Day in March. We're looking forward to sharing much more with you about our post-merger plan at that time.
Our earnings benefited less of a -- from less of a tailwind of lower fuel prices than in Q1 or Q2. Economic fuel costs declined by $18 million this quarter, where the year-over-year declines in Q1 and Q2 were more than 3x that amount.
With oil prices now over $50 a barrel, it's worth mentioning the improving efficiency of our fleet that will help offset rising fuel costs. ASMs per gallon improved by another 2% this quarter because of the ongoing retirement of the 737-400s and the addition of fuel-efficient 900ERs.
In fact, we've taken delivery of 21 737-900ERs since the end of the third quarter of last year. And our mainline efficiency should just should continue to get better as we finish retiring the 400s and add another 13 900ERs by the end of 2017.
As we've told you before, these new aircraft are 37 seats larger, they're more comfortable, they're more reliable and sip fuel like a Prius with wings. A 900ER brings less than 910 gallons per flight compared to 940 gallons per flight hour burned by the smaller 737-400.
Turning to the balance sheet. You might have noticed that we ended the quarter with more than $3.2 billion of cash. That total includes more than $1.5 billion that we had raised at quarter end to fund the Virgin America acquisition. At this point, we're fully prepared to close the deal once we have DOJ approval. Our treasury and legal teams did an incredible job putting all this together, and I wanted to extend a huge thanks to both of them.
We're using a mix of fixed and floating rate debt, and our weighted average interest rate on this new money currently stands at 2.37%, even after the financing. We still have more than 40 unencumbered Boeing 737 aircraft, including 20 next-generation 800s and 900ERs. The borrowing rate and the fact that we have so much remaining collateral are both a testament to the great balance sheet that we've built and incredible amount of cash flow we've been able to generate over the last 5 years.
Cash flow from operations for the first 9 months of the year was $1.2 billion, about flat compared to the first 9 months of last year. Year-to-date CapEx is just over $500 million, resulting in about $700 million of free cash flow. We expect full year CapEx to now be $680 million, down slightly from prior guidance.
There are 2 drivers. First, we elected to defer our first step -- our first 737 MAX aircraft from the fall of 2017 to early '18. The MAX will be a great airplane for Alaska, with an extra range and lower fuel burn, but with so much going on, we wanted a bit more time to bring it into service. We want to thank Boeing for accommodating our request. And second, we've lowered our estimate of non-aircraft spending as certain projects have shifted to the right. Looking forward, and as we told you last quarter, we're planning for 2017 CapEx to be about $1.1 billion, which, of course, is current Air Group hold.
Andrew and I have thrown out a lot of information on fleet changes, so I thought I'd might recap. On the mainline side, in 2016, we're adding a total of 19 new aircraft and retiring 10. And in 2017, we're adding 12 new aircraft and retiring 16, which is the rest of the 737-400 fleet.
On the regional side, we'll take delivery of our first 13 E175 jets into the Horizon fleet. And by the way, I want to recognize the Horizon team that's working on entry into service. And we'll add another 5 through our capacity and purchase arrangement with SkyWest.
We're very pleased with the strong results, both operational and financial, and our people should celebrate the great summer we had. We're mindful that there's a lot going on, a lot of hard work lies ahead, and we need to keep executing on the things that continue to make us successful.
And with that, let's go to questions.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Brad, you talked about in your -- I think it was one of the first things you said, about people are asking you about long-term margins, and you said they're going to be better than everybody else but you didn't give a number. If I were to think about t
componenttext: So Brad, you talked about in your -- I think it was one of the first things you said, about people are asking you about long-term margins, and you said they're going to be better than everybody else but you didn't give a number. If I were to think about the average pretax margins you guys did in '12, '13 and '14, it was about 14% pretax. So is that a good sort of all-else-equal guideposts to how I think about long-term margins? Or will it be a little bit lower than that given some likely dilution from Virgin? You can answer the stand-alone or pro forma, however you want.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think if this is the place where we're all speculating higher, you guys probably have a better view of what's going to happen with long-term margins in our industry than we do. But we do look at other industries. We look at other high-quality indus
componenttext: Yes. I think if this is the place where we're all speculating higher, you guys probably have a better view of what's going to happen with long-term margins in our industry than we do. But we do look at other industries. We look at other high-quality industrials. We look at sort of gaps that people are earning over their cost of capital. And so I think the industry, you would hope that as we settle down and have capacity control and have consolidation, that we settle into a place where we're earning, as an industry, margins that are several hundred points above our cost of capital. And then what we're saying is Alaska should be above that. That's sort of how we see ourselves. That's what we want to do. How you do that math, I don't think I want to be the one -- I'll just -- I think I've told you what we know and we've -- what we've always done is tried to talk about what we know and not talk about what we don't know. So I think that's where I might leave it. As to Virgin, just to be really candid, you add the 2 together. We're not issuing one new share for this acquisition. So any profit that they bring into the company is accretive to our profit. But I think you have seen the math. Virgin's historical margins are lower than Alaska. So I would expect that our company-wide margins will dilute a little bit. And Brandon, I can't remember the exact numbers, but it's not huge. Once the synergies are realized, it's not a significant decrease as I recall.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Right. Okay. Cool. And then what's on the table in terms of assuming this deal gets done, how you guys might think about communicating with The Street? You've been pretty consistent over the last 7, 8 years about not giving RASM guidance, not giving
componenttext: Yes. Right. Okay. Cool. And then what's on the table in terms of assuming this deal gets done, how you guys might think about communicating with The Street? You've been pretty consistent over the last 7, 8 years about not giving RASM guidance, not giving margin guidance. I think the stability of your earnings are better than most. Have you ever considered talking about -- I know we talked a few months ago about long-term RASM guidance, but is there -- are you guys giving any thought to how you want to think about communicating financial guidance in general once the deal closes, and in particular, giving something like annual EPS guidance like all the high-quality industrial companies do, so you could too? Right? I mean, like it's -- I'm serious. Really, you can prove that if you give me a range and you hit it year after year, your multiple will go higher. If you believe that fuel and fares are correlated, for example, you should be able to hit a range of EPS. So as you guys think about this, are you giving thought to how you communicate guidance longer-term, in general, not just RASM, but guidance in general?

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Hunter. We are thinking about it. What I will tell you is we were on the cusp of giving a lot more forward-looking disclosure and then we went into the deal with Virgin. And so we're not going to do that right now. And what I would say is I recognize
componenttext: Yes, Hunter. We are thinking about it. What I will tell you is we were on the cusp of giving a lot more forward-looking disclosure and then we went into the deal with Virgin. And so we're not going to do that right now. And what I would say is I recognize that that's what good high-quality industrials do. I would love to get there at some point. What I will tell you is that the reality of putting Business A together with Business B, we're going to have numbers that are unfamiliar to us for a while. And I think what we'll do is we'll wait until we get more familiar with those numbers and we'll get really confident on what the comps look like from our own perspective. And then once we're confident with that, we'll start giving more to you guys.

But at the end of the day, as it relates to that, from my perspective, competitive capacity is competitive capacity on our network, and we just need you to deal with that irrespective of who it is.

componenttextpreview: Yes, I don't have a number off the top of my head. But if I had to guess, I would say it's probably what we've done over the last couple of years. We've been on this course of phasing out the 400s now for a few years. Next year, they said the last 10 go o
componenttext: Yes, I don't have a number off the top of my head. But if I had to guess, I would say it's probably what we've done over the last couple of years. We've been on this course of phasing out the 400s now for a few years. Next year, they said the last 10 go out. So I think it's probably pretty consistent with what we would expect to see again on an Alaska-only basis. As we look ahead to the merger, Virgin America does enjoy a very high fuel efficiency as well, and so the combined entity should be just as well positioned.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Jamie Baker from JPMorgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Jamie Baker from JPMorgan.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: When the merger was announced, you talked about redeleveraging. And I'm wondering if you've dug deeper into the integration planning process. Have you established any timing or sort of annual progress that you hope to make in that regard? I mean, is it a
componenttext: When the merger was announced, you talked about redeleveraging. And I'm wondering if you've dug deeper into the integration planning process. Have you established any timing or sort of annual progress that you hope to make in that regard? I mean, is it a 5-year goal to return to where you currently are premerger, or where you were in March or some other time frame? Is there some annual number in terms of how much you'd like to -- how many turns of leverage you might want to decline? Anything like that?

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hi, Jamie. It's Brandon. Good morning. Maybe I'll start, and then Ben can tell you about the integration progress that we're making. We have modeled the redeleveraging that we talked about. And when we come out of the gates, we should have debt to cap, ri
componenttext: Hi, Jamie. It's Brandon. Good morning. Maybe I'll start, and then Ben can tell you about the integration progress that we're making. We have modeled the redeleveraging that we talked about. And when we come out of the gates, we should have debt to cap, right, 59%, 60% and -- but our goal would be to get down into the mid-40s within, say, 3 years or so. That's obviously dependent on the economic environment. But if we do it right, that's where we'll be. And then I think we'll stay there for a while. I think we like leverage in the mid -- low to mid-40% range. I don't see us going back down to 28% like we were pre-deal. But I think we can get there quick. And at that level, we'll have a balance sheet that looks a lot like another high -- or other high-quality industrials, and it will look very favorable compared to other carriers in the industry.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Very helpful. I appreciate that. Second question, and this is not uniquely tied to merger specifics or in the negotiations, so hopefully, you'll choose to answer. Can you assure us that you've at least identified the terms under which you would not do the
componenttext: Very helpful. I appreciate that. Second question, and this is not uniquely tied to merger specifics or in the negotiations, so hopefully, you'll choose to answer. Can you assure us that you've at least identified the terms under which you would not do the deal? And the reason I ask is that I'm just trying to assess whether the goal here is to get the deal done and give up as little as possible, which makes sense, or get the deal done only if you can assure that the -- pick a metric, ROIC remains above X. I mean, have you established a floor internally, I'm not asking you what the floor is, just trying to dig into the thought process here.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jamie, it's Brad. I think what we will say is that we've always run this business for the long term. We think about what's going to be good for all of the people that's been on this place over the long term for customers, for our employees, for all o
componenttext: Yes, Jamie, it's Brad. I think what we will say is that we've always run this business for the long term. We think about what's going to be good for all of the people that's been on this place over the long term for customers, for our employees, for all of you, for the owners of the business, and that that's the mindset we're taking as we have this conversation with the Justice Department. And so we are pushing. There are some things that we feel are important to our future success and our ability to do good things for customers, and that's what's motivating us here. But -- and I'll just say, we do have a pretty strong internal compass about what has worked for us and what will work for us in the future. So if that's an answer to your question, just there you have it, but there's just not a lot more that we can say about this.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, that will suffice. And if I could just sneak in a housekeeping question and it's, I guess, somewhat revenues and what Hunter was asking about in terms of guidance. Have you thought about how you're going to be reporting post-merger? Should we exp
componenttext: Yes. No, that will suffice. And if I could just sneak in a housekeeping question and it's, I guess, somewhat revenues and what Hunter was asking about in terms of guidance. Have you thought about how you're going to be reporting post-merger? Should we expect that you still break out regional and mainline? Or is there an opportunity to just move everything into a consolidated basis as you guide going forward? Any thoughts there? Or are we just jumping too far ahead? I'm just thinking about how do I rebuild my model.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. It's all about you, Jamie. What we'll do is we'll probably report regional and mainline, I would say. But until we have a single operating certificate, Virgin America and Alaska Airline separate results would be available on day 1 as well.
componenttext: Yes. It's all about you, Jamie. What we'll do is we'll probably report regional and mainline, I would say. But until we have a single operating certificate, Virgin America and Alaska Airline separate results would be available on day 1 as well.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just to follow up on Jamie's question about Brandon, where you would want to get to with respect to debt to cap, is getting back to the low to mid-40s still didn't get you back to an IG rating? Would that be -- would that matter? Or is it, at the very lea
componenttext: Just to follow up on Jamie's question about Brandon, where you would want to get to with respect to debt to cap, is getting back to the low to mid-40s still didn't get you back to an IG rating? Would that be -- would that matter? Or is it, at the very least, you want to do what you need to do in order to get back to the coveted investment-grade credit rating?

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, Mike. This is Mark Eliasen. Maybe I'll take a shot at that one. First of all, we're not changing our principles, and our principles got us to the investment-grade rating, and that is generating good cash flow, a conservative balance sheet, running a
componenttext: Hey, Mike. This is Mark Eliasen. Maybe I'll take a shot at that one. First of all, we're not changing our principles, and our principles got us to the investment-grade rating, and that is generating good cash flow, a conservative balance sheet, running a good company, a good high-quality industrial company. So we're going to get there, and we're confident that the rating agencies will come around when they see that and they know us well, and they will see that we're going to just revert back to our pattern. One point I'll make about the -- we aren't going to have additional debt, but because the interest rate is quite a bit lower than what we had before, our actual interest expense will be right in the range of what we've had historically. So that's a good thing even though our leverage is a little bit higher.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. And then just a second question, and this is probably -- I don't know if it's for Brad or Ben, but we had the new -- I guess another phase from the DOT as it relates to consumer protection legislation. And while there was kind of a lot of ver
componenttext: Okay. Great. And then just a second question, and this is probably -- I don't know if it's for Brad or Ben, but we had the new -- I guess another phase from the DOT as it relates to consumer protection legislation. And while there was kind of a lot of verbiage, a lot of noise, it seemed like that there were a couple of things that are going to come into play here, and one of it has to deal with the on-time performance. And I'm just curious, I mean, I know that under the new rules, Horizon doesn't meet the new threshold. But it looks like it's actually very close to the threshold, so maybe it's a 2017, 2018 type event. But if you were to include Horizon in with the Alaska numbers, where would you stack up on, on-time completion factor? Like how would you compare -- and I realize you probably have to do that analysis for the other carriers, but does it enhance? Does it -- is it neutral? Or does it take away from the numbers?

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hi, Mike. Yes, that's a great question. And it's not -- and you guys wouldn't expect that from me. I track that everyday, Alaska, Horizon, and I actually track every other carrier in the industry and how we stack up. And I will tell you today, if we combi
componenttext: Hi, Mike. Yes, that's a great question. And it's not -- and you guys wouldn't expect that from me. I track that everyday, Alaska, Horizon, and I actually track every other carrier in the industry and how we stack up. And I will tell you today, if we combined Alaska and Horizon, we would still lead the industry in on-time and combined completion rates, hands down. So Horizon, I'm looking forward to Horizon to get in the 175s, the more reliable airplane. In fact, we'd include SkyWest in that total as well. So I think it's a good thing, what the DOT has done. I mean, the customer, when they book on an airline, they really don't distinguish whether they're flying a regional airplane or a mainline airplane. And it's our commitment, it's been our philosophy all the time here in Alaska, that whether you fly mainline or regional, we will look after you like the same across all touch points.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Michael, this is David Campbell of Horizon. Ben, just 1 second. One of the things that we've turned our attention towards is a really, really clear focus on operational excellence. We've seen a 9 -- sorry, about a 7% improvement so far this year on DOT pe
componenttext: Michael, this is David Campbell of Horizon. Ben, just 1 second. One of the things that we've turned our attention towards is a really, really clear focus on operational excellence. We've seen a 9 -- sorry, about a 7% improvement so far this year on DOT performance as far as getting, I think like DOT, on, on-time performance. As far as getting out the gate, we're seeing about a 5% improvement as far as on-time arrivals. One of the challenges I think we have here in Seattle is really dealing with ATC delays. But everything else that we can control, we're driving a much, much stronger process in place. So I'm pretty excited about the focus. And I think you're going to see a continued progress on performance from Horizon. I think the second piece of this, the E175 is such a reliable great airplane, and that's going to actually help us a great deal as well. So that's going to be a really good tool in our toolbox to really take care of our customers.

componenttext: Okay. And then Brandon, you said you weren't ready to provide 2017 unit cost guidance yet, which is understandable, but just wondering if you could highlight what some of the big moving pieces are for us. I guess you've got the E175 introduction that's been discussed. But is there anything else? I think you've got a mechanics deal that's amendable. And any other sort of big items that you would highlight?

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, you're right. We do have a mechanic deal that is amendable on the Alaska side. We have what I would call a likely increase in our pension expense. Just given the returns and where rates are this year, we won't know that amount until the end of the ye
componenttext: Yes, you're right. We do have a mechanic deal that is amendable on the Alaska side. We have what I would call a likely increase in our pension expense. Just given the returns and where rates are this year, we won't know that amount until the end of the year. I think it's possible that we might have a deal with the OEM for an engine services agreement. We're still looking into that. So if that gets done, that would be a cost win for us, although that's really just a smoothing arrangement over a longer-term period. And then we do have a little bit of, I'd say, both cost and ASM headwind associated with premium class. As Andrew shared, premium class is going to be awesome from a margin perspective, both dollars -- or from a dollar's perspective on the margin line, although it does dilute ASMs a little bit and there is additional cost of serving those premium class passengers. So those are kind of the big things off the top of my head.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And then if I can just, a quick one last one in. When you retire the last 737 Classic, is there some sort of step-down in infrastructure spend or something associated with that in addition to the fuel cost savings of not -- no longer operating that airplane?

componenttext: Well, first, Darryl, we're going to have a party when the last Classic goes, at least the maintenance guys will. There will be some. We're investing in an Anchorage hangar. The Anchorage hangar can only accommodate Classics. We do need a bigger hangar up in the State of Alaska to accommodate the larger NGs. Besides that, we have tooling and spares and parts for to maintain the rest of the fleet, so we're solid there.

But again, without going into too much detail, we feel very, very good about our Hawaii 26-plus flights a day franchise, and it's performing very, very well. Very, very stable right now.

componenttext: Well, the weather, Helane -- it's Ben. Yes, it was -- we were expecting extremely high winds and rain. What I will tell you is that we got some of it, but it wasn't to the extent that we expected. We did cancel just a handful of flights, maybe about 30 flights. We accommodated most customers. We did that all in advance, so I can't tell you the dollar amounts. Maybe I'll ask Brandon.

componenttextpreview: Yes, I think it would be immaterial.
componenttext: Yes, I think it would be immaterial.

componenttext: Immaterial, yes. So we came through it pretty -- yes, we don't get to see many of those storms. So hopefully, it will be the last that we see in a while.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Andrew, taking a step back, I'm wondering if you can help us understand how codeshare agreements work more broadly. There's a broad view that there will be like a light switch. Either you have one or you don't. You turn them on, you turn them off. And so
componenttext: Andrew, taking a step back, I'm wondering if you can help us understand how codeshare agreements work more broadly. There's a broad view that there will be like a light switch. Either you have one or you don't. You turn them on, you turn them off. And so the question here is, is how do they really work? What are the various components? How easy are they to customize it? And where does the value really come from? Is it on the routes that you don't serve but your partner does? Or is it on the markets that you both serve?

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hi, Dan. Good morning. I -- that's a very good big question though. I'll keep it high level, I think, and I'll just speak for Alaska Air Group. A couple of key things here that codeshares provide us, firstly, domestically, we can connect into our partners
componenttext: Hi, Dan. Good morning. I -- that's a very good big question though. I'll keep it high level, I think, and I'll just speak for Alaska Air Group. A couple of key things here that codeshares provide us, firstly, domestically, we can connect into our partners' hubs in the middle of the country and then connect our customers to anywhere in the rest of the country. So firstly, these codeshare agreements domestically give us a lot of ability to be able to get our passengers everywhere they need to go at the times they need to go and give them plenty of choice of fares when they need to go. I think the other key component of that is also obviously the loyalty side, so our customers can still accrue elite status and miles when they fly on our partner's medal or on our own medal. And of course, redemptions. If customers want to redeem, 85% of our customers redeem on us still. And then the last piece is really international. And the international is really, really important. For our international partners, we provide huge value to help them fill airplanes. I mean, the statistics are quite significant in our hubs, especially on how many passengers we put on our foreign flag friends. In fact, for Alaska customers, it allows them to both redeem globally, 800-plus destinations globally, as well as earn and redeem miles. So overall, I would say that these codeshare relationships provide great utility. But at the end of the day, Alaska Air Group is built on its fundamental product, and the majority of customers, majority of loyalty, the majority of revenue is all based on Alaska Air Group's medal and what we do.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. But just to kind of back up, Andrew, just a little bit there. The -- how easy are they to customize them, to turn on or turn off certain routes, I guess, number one? And then secondly, does the majority of the value come from the markets that you
componenttext: Got it. But just to kind of back up, Andrew, just a little bit there. The -- how easy are they to customize them, to turn on or turn off certain routes, I guess, number one? And then secondly, does the majority of the value come from the markets that you don't serve, or because I would presume there are some markets that you jointly serve? I'm just wondering if you could just kind of help us understand a little bit further.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think for mechanics, it's very easy to turn things on or off. We just got to give notice to our customers and change the booking schedule and not disrupt passengers. So we work very closely with our partners. And there is no silver bullet on value. I
componenttext: So I think for mechanics, it's very easy to turn things on or off. We just got to give notice to our customers and change the booking schedule and not disrupt passengers. So we work very closely with our partners. And there is no silver bullet on value. In our Seattle hub, it might come from connecting beyond, some international loyalty in California, where we're less prevalent, or maybe even in Los Angeles, our partners give us a much fuller schedule and allow customers where we don't have a whole lot of utility to still stay in the family and in our program, to travel on them. I think loyalty, codeshare revenue, all of these things in the portfolio, Dan, I -- honestly, there's no one single area that's more important than the other, from my perspective at least.

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. And then, I guess, secondly here, Andrew, you mentioned the transcon presence for Alaska. And the rest of the industry has gone to a lie-flat seat in this segment. And I guess I'm just wondering what are your thoughts about this going forward,
componenttext: Understood. And then, I guess, secondly here, Andrew, you mentioned the transcon presence for Alaska. And the rest of the industry has gone to a lie-flat seat in this segment. And I guess I'm just wondering what are your thoughts about this going forward, just given the acquisition of Virgin here? Does the more upscale approach make sense? Or is the thought simply to maintain a density advantage?

headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Dan, it's a great question, and that's a project that we are working on right now, where I think the point you're making is a good one, that a lot of carriers are moving to, with a certain number of lie-flat seats in certain markets. The other side o
componenttext: Yes, Dan, it's a great question, and that's a project that we are working on right now, where I think the point you're making is a good one, that a lot of carriers are moving to, with a certain number of lie-flat seats in certain markets. The other side of it is Alaska has got a longstanding -- we're very proud of the low-cost, low-fare position that we have. And so those are the 2, and there's also a simplicity element to this thing. So those are the things that we're going to be balancing as we think about this decision. And I think you'll hear us say more about this in the next few months, but it is an open question and I think you know the 2 sides, the 2 arguments for each side of it.

componenttext: Just maybe on the capacity growth side. I'm a little bit surprised by next year's level of growth given that you are having pressure on the fuel side and you're going through this inauguration. headline: Alaska Air Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Savi, maybe I'll start with the first part on capacity. But -- so a couple of things. As you've heard earlier, there's obviously decent growth on the regional side of our business. And all the CRJ is going away, now with 70 seats, we're going to 76 seats
componenttext: Savi, maybe I'll start with the first part on capacity. But -- so a couple of things. As you've heard earlier, there's obviously decent growth on the regional side of our business. And all the CRJ is going away, now with 70 seats, we're going to 76 seats on the 175. So there's some good growth there. A lot of our growth is really transcon and midcon. 80% of it was this quarter. 100% of it will be next quarter. We'll give more details later on. But these are markets that we found to be very, very good for us and adding a lot of new revenue. As Brandon shared, these are high-level estimates again as we stand today. The Havana's, all of Newark's, each of those were a point of growth, or 1/3 of a point of growth. So it's not hard to get to 7% already with what we've already done. We will continue to monitor this. And of course, with the new combined entity, we'll take a hard look at it. But what we've seen to date is our growth has provided good economics for this company. And if these economic conditions and the continuing strengthening of close-in bookings and the environment are still there next year, we'll continue on with our plan.

componenttextpreview: Yes. So I can give you a couple of facts that I just looked up. The 900ER gets about 92 seat miles per gallon right now in our fleet, and the 800s are about 85. So as we phase out the 737-400s as planned and mentioned, we should approach that number. We s
componenttext: Yes. So I can give you a couple of facts that I just looked up. The 900ER gets about 92 seat miles per gallon right now in our fleet, and the 800s are about 85. So as we phase out the 737-400s as planned and mentioned, we should approach that number. We should be in the 80. That's going to be about 88% of our fleet will be those very large jets, and they're great airplanes for us.
